results.description:
This is a monthly event that I host at Ryles. Some of the best singers in the area show up to get backed by my jazz trio.

If you are a vocalist and want to sing one, bring your charts or just know your key for any standards and you can sing a couple with the band. 

As an audience member, this is a great show because there is so much variety. All the singers have their own unique sound plus there is a wide variety of styles from standards to bossa novas, and jazzy versions of pop and r&b tunes.

Ryles has a full bar and serves food - mostly BBQ

There are two parking lots!! - One is across the street toward Prospect next to gas station and the other is on same side of street next to 7-11. Both are marked Parking for S&S but it is ok to par there since it the same owner as Ryles
results.how_to_find_us: I will reserve a table by the windows for meetup members - look for chairs leaned up on table

results.description:
The “Little Bookworms” story time provides an age appropriate activity that fosters a sense of responsibility and compassion in the youngest visitors, from those in strollers to those in preschool. The community’s youngest animal lovers are invited to join with their adult counterparts for weekly story time. During the hour session, an animal-friendly short story is read to attendees, and we bring an adoptable animal into the room to visit. Registration for individuals is not required. Suggested monetary donation $5 per family/group (less or more appreciated as well!) and Wish List donations are always welcome!

Getting to Story Time

Story time is hosted in the Education and Training Room at the MSPCA Boston Adoption Center at 350 S. Huntington Avenue in Jamaica Plain. The Boston Animal Care and Adoption Center Education Room has its own entrance at the back of the MSPCA building. To get to the entrance drive past the first parking lot on your right when you enter the driveway. Follow the driveway until it ends and bear left. Continue past the first set of double doors to the Angell Animal Medical Center and past the second set of double doors which is the main adoption center entrance. Take a left at the end of the parking lot and you will see a set of gray stairs and railing leading up to the Education Room entrance. We use this room for other activities in the mornings, so unfortunately we cannot open the doors sooner.

What Is Read

The stories that are read include fiction, non-fiction, and poetry. Many have been awarded the Henry Bergh Children’s Book Award, which honors books that promote the humane ethic of compassion and respect for all living things. If you have a great book in mind for the “Little Bookworms” story time, please share it!
results.name: FREE Little Bookworms Storytime @ MSPCA Boston

results.description: Let’s dance. Children ages 0-5 and caregivers move and groove together.

results.description:
Winter is upon us! Let's keep the cold away by dancing to live music at the Boston Children's Museum. Join us at the Music and Movement class in the Common, on the second floor of the museum. The museum opens at 10:00am, and the class begins at 10:30am. We plan on being at the Common by 10:15am. See detailed description below. 


Admission is $16 per person (both for adults and children), infants under 12 months Free. I can let up to three people in for free with my membership card, so please send me a private message if you're interested. You can also get a library pass from your local library to get a discount. Call several days ahead to reserve a pass. 

As for transportation, you can walk from South Station, which is probably the cheapest. If you're driving, see parking info here. Parking

Please join us for some fun with music, singing and dancing!

Michi

"Sing along to music that gets all ages moving! Infants, toddlers, and preschoolers interact through sound, sight and touch and enjoy live music. Grownups and children join in with drums, tambourines, and other noise-makers. Toddlers can meet other children and participate in group activities in this safe and fun environment. All classes are led by trained music educators from Little Groove."
results.name: Music and Movement at the Boston Children's Museum

results.description:
Save the time and date: Wednesday Feb 17,    2016, 12:30pm, somewhere in Watertown.


Remember when you worked in an office,and they gave you some time to eat lunch in the cafeteria, and you actually pulled yourself away from your desk and went and ate lunch with other people? Nah, I don't remember that either, but it sure sounds like fun. And, it's the law. If your employer denied you a lunch break, you'd be filing a complaint with the state so fast. About 25 people expressed interest, which means that probably five to eight people will show up. 

The others will all have good excuses, such as, "It's too cold," "I'm too tired," "I have too much work," "I have a deadline," "my clients need me," etc. I don't want to hear your excuses, Please don't bore me with those lame-o excuses, I just want you to show up. it will be at some eatery near Mass Ave in Arlington. I will call tom'w and see if there's some place good that can accommodate eight of us for lunch. RSVP by obtaining a free ticket at eventrbire, first come, first served:

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/wednesday-217-collegial-lunch-for-people-who-work-at-home-location-watertown-tickets-21248289205


that way I'll know you're coming, and be able to contact you easily. That will also help to limit the attendance. If you think this idea can fly, please do sign up and show up, and then we can repeat this pleasure again next week. bests,


-rsr-

Ron Rothenberg

4Buyers RE

[masked]

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center
1481 Tremont Street - inside the front entrance
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!! 

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 


TALK with us FIRST !! 

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas 

Vegan Cooking Classes or 
                 Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food 
                    (using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 

* What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?
* Portion Control
* Bake...Don't Fry!
* Roasted Veggie Stackers
* No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream
* Avocados!!!
* Salad with Chipotle Hummus
* Simple Cilantro Chutney

results.description:
The U.S. Prison System – The 2016 Harvard University Center for American Political Studies Tocqueville Lecture 

Free and open to the public. Event link HERE. 

The lecture is at 4pm, after which there will be a reception (5pm) on the 4th floor of CGIS Knafel (1737 Cambridge Street). 

Wednesday, February 17th, 4-6pm

Belfer Case Study Room

1730 Cambridge Street

The Tocqueville Lecture will be given by Bruce Western, Professor of Sociology and Guggenheim Professor of Criminal Justice Policy, Director of the Malcolm Wiener Center for Social Policy, and Faculty Chair of the Program in Criminal Justice at the Harvard Kennedy School of Government … in conversation with Stephen Tourlentes. 

:: :: ::

Professor Western served as vice chair of the National Academy of Sciences Committee on the Causes and Consequences of High Incarceration Rates in the Unites States, and he is the principal investigator on the Harvard Executive Session on Community Corrections and the Boston Reentry Study. He is the author of the award-winning book, Punishment and Inequality.

Stephen Tourlentes is a Boston-based award-winning artist who has exhibited both locally and nationally. His work has been presented in a number of solo and group exhibitions, including at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Institute of Contemporary Art Boston, the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art. His work is a number of collections, including the Museum of Fine Arts Boston, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Harvard University, and the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago. Tourlentes has a MFA from the Massachusetts College of Art and Design, where he is currently an adjunct professor. 

:: :: ::

Of Lengths and Measures: Prison and the American Landscape, an exhibition of Tourlentes' photographs of prisons shot at night, from across the United States, is currently installed in the CAPS spaces on the 4th floor of the CGIS Knafel Building. 

:: :: ::

4:00 – 5:00pm, Lecture in Belfer Case Study Room, 1730 Cambridge Street

5:00 – 6:00pm, Reception on the 4th floor of CGIS Knafel, 1737 Cambridge Street

Center for American Political Studies (CAPS)
results.name: U.S. Prison System (Harvard CAPS)

results.description:
Who should join: Beginners to Advanced speakers interested in learning how to improve their public speaking for fun or professionally.  Reduce your fear and increase your confidence.


Why  members should join: Learn the basics of public speaking, challenge your current skills to be a professional speaker or just to have fun & meet interesting people.  You will also be challenged to give more challenging types of speeches such as ice breakers, humorous and inspirational speeches.

What members can expect out of the group: We have a fast paced 1 hour meeting packed with 2 prepared speeches from members as well as Table Topics where anyone is invited to speak on a suggested topic for 1-2 minutes to hone their ability to speak off the cuff.


You can also join our mentorship program and be assigned an advanced speaker who will guide you to improving your skills.

Lead meetings and presentations at work, begin your path to being a better teacher or professional paid public speaker or simply be a better storyteller.

Tuesday 12pm meeting for members and guests. Please visit for free! 

All are welcome.
results.how_to_find_us: Clarendon street entrance. Ask the desk attendant for directions to room.
results.name: Attend a free meeting as a guest and consider joining!

results.description:
Release Date: 2/26/2016

Rating: Not Yet Rated

SYNOPSIS:

Inspired by true events, Eddie the Eagle is a feel-good story about Michael “Eddie” Edwards (Taron Egerton), an unlikely but courageous British ski-jumper who never stopped believing in himself – even as an entire nation was counting him out. With the help of a rebellious and charismatic coach (played by Hugh Jackman), Eddie takes on the establishment and wins the hearts of sports fans around the world by making an improbable and historic showing at the 1988 Calgary Winter Olympics. From producers of Kingsman: The Secret Service, Eddie the Eagle stars Taron Egerton as Eddie, the loveable underdog with a never say die attitude.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.
results.how_to_find_us: The folks talking with their hands!
results.name: Weekly North Shore ASL Social!

results.description:
I am a sucker for adaptations of classic books. There have been several Shakespearean remakes, for this meetup I tried to pick two very different movies. The two we will focus on will be: Omkara (Othello remake) and 10 things I Hate about You (Taming of the Shrew remake). Omkara is a Indian drama and 10 things I Hate about You is an American teen comedy. (If you only have time for one movie pick Omkara)

We will meet at Tantric Bistro for Indian food. The place has appetizers and drinks as well for those who don't want a meal.

You can find find Omkara for free on several sites if you google for full movie and can also rent on Amazon Prime or Netflix DVD. 10 Things I Hate about You is on Netflix stream.

Other Adaptations:
O (Othello)
Much Ado About Nothing (2012)
Coriolanus
West Side Story (Romeo and Juliet)
Romeo+Juliet
My Own Private Idaho (Henry V)
Lion King (Hamlet)
She's the Man (Twelfth Night)
Hamlet (2000)
Macbeth (2015)
results.name: Film Topic: Shakespearean Remakes

results.description:
THIS IS A PAID EVENT PURCHASE YOUR TICKET HERE

Maxim Lobovsky, Formlabs

By age 25 Maxim Lobovsky was already a successful entrepreneur and startup founder. His time as a student at the MIT Media Lab allowed him to experience the power of rapid prototyping and 3D printing technologies to produce custom designs for his work. But as powerful as they were, the technology was extremely expensive. Seeing an enormous opportunity, in 2011 Maxim Lobovsky and two other colleagues from MIT founded Formlabs, a startup developing an affordable high-resolution 3D printer enabling designers, engineers, and makers to easily realize their dreams in beautiful physical form.

After a highly successful crowdsourcing campaign on Kickstarter and additional rounds of funding, Formlabs announced the Form 1, their fist prosumer model, and on September 2015 launched the Form 2, a new model with larger capacity, upgraded features and simpler usability. He continues to lead his team and organization in transforming the way we think about design, manufacturing and business.

Maxim holds an MS on Media Arts and Sciences program at MIT, and a BS on Applied and Engineering Physics from Cornell University.

Agenda

6:00 Networking and Food
7:00 Fireside Chat
8:00 Networking

Hosted By Carlos Cardenas, Director of Startup Grind Boston

Carlos’ career has focused on exploring the connections between technology, design and the human experience. He is Vice-president of THE MEME, a strategic design consultancy where he has led multidisciplinary teams in the design of products, services and business innovation strategies for start-ups and corporate clients including Samsung, LG, Microsoft, iRobot, among others. Currently developing a Design Acceleration program for start-ups and emerging businesses to harness the power of design thinking and agile design research methods for sustained business growth. Prior to joining THE MEME he was co-founder of CAPO interactive design as well as researcher at Harvard’s Center for Design Informatics.
Email: [masked]

Global Partners

Google is committed to empowering entrepreneurs around the world through programs, partnerships, and our products.

Local Partners

Workbar is an interconnected network of shared, coworking office spaces with locations in Boston and Cambridge. Made up of thriving start-ups, creative entrepreneurs, independent professionals, and enterprise teams, the interactive and collaborative atmosphere of Workbar is a motivating and productive work environment with a strong professional network.

THE MEME is a strategic design and innovation consultancy that provides engaging consumer experiences across diverse product and service platforms.

What is Startup Grind?

Startup Grind is a global startup community designed to educate, inspire, and connect entrepreneurs. We host monthly events in more than 150 cities and 65 countries featuring successful local founders, innovators, educators and investors who share personal stories and lessons learned on the road to building great companies. Our monthly fireside chat interviews, startup mixers and annual conferences provide ample opportunities to connect with amazing startups and the people behind them, tap into a strong support network, form meaningful connections and gain inspiration for the startup journey ahead. For more information visit StartupGrind.com or follow us on twitter @StartupGrind.

results.description:
This event is a double header. We'll be talking about Arduino, Internet of Things, and PHP as our main presentation and we'll also be talking about Vorlon.js as our intro talk. 

Main Presentation
Our main speaker will be Vasilis Georgitzikis. He's the creator of Codebender, a cloud based <a></a>Arduino IDE built using PHP. Three years ago, he set on a quest to build a cloud-based IDE, using PHP. He will briefly talk about codebender, what it does, how it's built, and the challenges he faced building such a complicated tool.   As a bonus, he will also touch a bit about Arduino, what you can build with it, and he'll show an example of using PHP and Arduino to control physical things.


Bio: Vasilis Georgitzikis is the co-founder of Codebender, the only company crazy enough to build IDEs for microcontrollers on the cloud. He's also a co-founder of P-Space, the first hackerspace in Greece, and in a past (forgotten) life, he used to do research for the European Union. He's now the CEO* of codebender, and he wishes he could still write code, but they don't let him do it anymore.

Intro Talk
Our intro talk speaker will be Josh Drew from Microsoft. He'll be talking about Vorlon.js, a debugging tool for webpages. It's sort of like the F12 tools built into your favorite browser, but it has one big advantage - it works remotely. With Vorlon.js, you put a single script reference on your web page and then install the vorlon npm package on your local machine (or in the cloud) and you're ready to go.

Bio: Joshua Drew is a Senior Technical Evangelist for Microsoft where he is responsible for promoting the development across the Windows ecosystem all over New England. Joshua focuses on Windows 10 and Windows Phone application and gaming development using native languages, such as C# or hybrid development using HTML5/JavaScript. As an evangelist, Joshua works with professional developers and students at workshops and on-premise events to help develop apps and games along with providing guidance on user experience design, marketing and promotion.

Agenda

6:00 PM - 7:00 PM -- Free pizza and refreshments 

6:15 PM - 7:00 PM -- Joshua Drew - Vorlon.js

7:00 PM - 7:15 PM -- General Announcements

7:15 PM - 8:15 PM -- Vasilis Georgitzikis - Codebender, Arduino and PHP

8:15 PM - 8:45 PM -- Q&A

8:45 PM - ??? -- Afterparty at Champions Bar
results.name: Arduino, IoT & PHP

results.description:
Charleene's Country Line Dance Lessons take place Wednesdays in Weymouth (OR Angela hosts the Tuesdays in Braintree) and she has a great team helping her teach the classes. Beginner lessons @ 6-7pm and Advanced lessons @ 7-8pm. This is a fun way to learn several country line dances with others and get in a nice workout. You'll then be able to join in the fun when you are out and see other people line dancing. 

What to Bring/Wear:

~Water (they do not provide drinks and you will get thirsty)

~Cowboy Boots (if you have them), boots or shoes w/ heels; no sneakers!

~Comfy Clothes (remember, you're dancing!)

Cost is $10 and I suggest bringing cash.

Please plan to arrive a few minutes early if this is your first time attending. This way you can pay at the register and we can get introduced before the fun starts.

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: TBD; FYI - This happens weekly and they don't dance if the governor says to stay off the road.


Parking: Free and ample parking on-site.

results.description:
Have you been taught to micro-manage your time and yet it seems you never have enough of it? Drawing on Christine Duvivier’s professional and academic work, this webinar leads you out of turmoil and into a more effective model, so you can avoid the three major obstacles cited by executive women. Discover positive change tools that free you to be happier, have more energy, and engage your team to reach new heights, as you learn the limits of time management and how to achieve greater impact with greater ease. Are you a leader or aspiring leader? Would you like to make a bigger impact, get promoted and make more money without burn out or family sacrifice?

What you come away with:

• Learn small changes that make a big difference

• Understand how to achieve your goals, without sacrificing your life

• Know the power of building from the positive

• Understand why positive thinking isn’t enough—and what to do instead

• Engage others to new levels of commitment that give you relief

• Learn simple ways to boost creativity, resourcefulness, and results

We will use experiential exercises, case studies, Christine's personal experience, and research to share high-impact strategies you can use to get more than you have been taught to expect in your career and life.

Our Leader This Evening


Christine Duvivier, a Master of Positive Psychology, is a leader in the red-hot field of positive psychology. Christine believes that within each of us lie tremendous untapped reservoirs of potential. Discovering the strategies and power of positive change and, conversely, releasing what holds us back, has been the defining journey of her life and work.

Today, drawing on Christine's 20 + years of mentoring business executives, parents, and leaders from around the world, along with her research in positive psychology, she guides people to unleash the best within—no matter where they stand currently. Learn about what Christine calls, The Gifts that Conflict with School (and are well-suited to leadership and success).


She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands of individuals and groups worldwide, including Fortune 50 executives, individuals, families, and communities. Author of "What I'd Say if You Wouldn't Roll Your Eyes... love notes to my child," Christine mentors and facilitates other professionals-- including leaders, physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors-- using positive approaches to get the results they want, sooner, and bringing out the full potential in themselves and others.

Clients say, "Christine helped me become the leader I am... get promoted.... turn problem staff to top performers... engage my team.... get people on board with new strategy and culture.... transform my relationships... turn around a demoralized organization... see the best in me....feel energized."

She has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17. As a mid-level employee in a 135,000- person company, she discovered how to have much greater impact, in much less time, as she followed her own vision, which was contrary to everything around her. As a result, Christine led a team that convinced the executive committee to adopt a radical new goal, went on to engage employees worldwide in a change that boosted customer loyalty 20%, and was promoted to Worldwide Director of Customer Quality and Loyalty.

While studying and working with Martin Seligman, David Cooperrider, George Vaillant and other founders in the science of positive psychology & well-being, she experienced the power of positive change when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience. Her groundbreaking research at UPenn identified paths to unleash hidden gifts and lead each of us to thrive in life.

Watch a video interview with Christine, read one of Christine's studies or listen to an audio interview and learn more on www.christineduvivier.com

Register Here for the link to join us.
results.how_to_find_us: Register Here for the link: http://www.christineduvivier.com/register-have-more-impact-in-less-time-webinar/
results.name: Christine Duvivier: Have More Impact in Less Time

results.description:
What's happening?

To celebrate the release of Go 1.6 we're organizing a world wide release party on February the 17th, 2016.

</a> Hang on, did you say Go 1.6 ships on the 17th of February?

Nope! Go 1.6 ships when it's ready. With that said, things are looking pretty good for a mid Feb release. Using the power of software estimation, a date was plucked from the aether that happened to coincide with several meetups that were already in the works.

What happens at this release party?


Go 1.6 is the 7th release of the language which has been open source since November 10th, 2009 -- that's 6.5 years since the project was open sourced and nearly 4 years since the 1.0 release. A lot has changed in the language since 1.0, so this is a great opportunity to discuss the improvements landing 1.6.

Talks

What's New in Go 1.6
We'll go through the Dave Cheney's excellent <a href="http://go-talks.appspot.com/github.com/davecheney/gosyd/go1.6.slide#1">slides from a recent Go Sydney user group. Presenters: Jen Andre, Ross Nanopoulos and Andrew Haskell.

Informal Walkthrough of Performance Differences in Go 1.6 in Production.
Presenter: Brian Hatfield.

Afterwards?

We'll head over to Meadhall to socialize and network.
results.name: Go 1.6 Release Party

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs

results.description:
Come learn the secrets of the command line (AKA: terminal, bash prompt, shell) and take the first steps toward becoming a software developer!


No matter what area of software/web development you're interested in, basic Linux command line skills are essential. Many common tools can only be installed and accessed via the command line, and others that have a graphical interface are much more convenient to use in the command line. 


TAKEAWAYS


In this course, we'll cover the basics of using the Linux command line, including:

• Navigating & searching through files and folders

• Managing file/folder permissions

• Editing files in a text editor

• Managing processes

• Installing programs

• Connecting to another computer via SSH (secure shell)


PREREQUISITES

No programming experience is required!


Please bring a laptop running Mac OS, Windows or Linux  in order to participate in the class exercises.

For Mac & Linux users - If your computer is less than 10 years old you should be good to go. You don't need to install additional software. We'll be using the Terminal program.

For Windows users - The command line program that comes with Windows is slightly different syntax than Macs and Linux,  but a Linux-like command line program is available for Windows users. Before class, please install Cygwin: http://cygwin.com/install.html

You'll also need to install the OpenSSH package for Cygwin - see the first 2 steps under Installing OpenSSH at http://www.howtogeek.com/howto/41560/how-to-get-ssh-command-line-access-to-windows-7-using-cygwin/ (you DO NOT need to complete the steps under Configuring SSH in Cygwin)


LOCATION
Many thanks to Wellist for hosting this class! Wellist is located at:

125 Broad St, 2nd floor
Boston, MA
View Google Map


Someone will be available to let you into the building when you arrive.

Interested in hosting classes? Email us at boston[at]girldevelopit.com!

ABOUT THE TEACHER

Liz is a software engineer and UI designer at a small non-profit, where she builds web applications using PHP, JavaScript, Python and Drupal. She has a BS in graphic design and a master's in library & information science, and spent 3 years working as a technical trainer, teaching web development and graphic design, before making the leap to software development.


TEACHING ASSISTANTS

This course will be TAed by Amanda Muñoz and Sean Kelly.

If you are interested in being a teaching assistant, please fill out our volunteer form. TAing is a great way to practice what you know and to get to know members of our community.

FINANCIAL NEED

A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified shortly after the deadline. Class capacity does not impact scholarship students. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer.

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!

Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.

results.description:
We'll learn about and plan for ways to support House Bill 1382: An Act Providing Community-Based Sentencing Alternatives for Primary Caretakers of Dependent Children Convicted of Non-violent Crimes.  If made into law, it would allow parents convicted of nonviolent offenses to continue caring for their children while they complete an alternative sentence like job training, counseling, or drug treatment. It would require that judges consider a person’s caregiver status before sentencing them. 


Why is Knapsack involved in this effort?  Mass incarceration most brutally effects Black and Brown people, who are more likely to face imprisonment and receive harsher sentences for the same offenses as whites.


The Judiciary Committee must take action on HB 1382 before March 16 or this critical legislation will die in committee.  We know that the time is ripe to push for this change, and that Senator Brownsberger, who chairs the committee, is supportive.


These are some of the things we can do to support the bill:

1) Reach out to people we know in the towns of members of the Judiciary Committee.  These key communities are: Franklin, Millis, Needham, Attleboro, North Attleborough, Natick, Sherborn, Wayland, Hopedale, Milton, Medway, Brockton, Easton, Westfield, Stoneham, Winchester , Salem, Andover, Boxford, North Andover, Tewksbury, Springfield, Ayer, Ashby, Dunstable, Groton, Pepperell, and Townsend
2) If you know congregations/organizations in these communities, connect with them and ask them if they'd like someone from SURJ (Showing Up for Racial Justice) to come out and talk to their group.
3) Ask congregations/organizations in these communities to please publish information about HB 1382 to their newletters, bulletins, and websites.
4) Spread the word on social media: https://www.facebook.com/events/425795017618914/


We'll brainstorm other ways to support the bill as well!


More information about the bill is in the Facebook link above, which is also where we got the language for this posting.


Accessibility Information: Community Change, Inc. is wheelchair accessible with the following limitations.  The door to the building is heavy and does not have a button to open it. The elevator doors are slightly more than 30 inches wide.  The fourth floor bathrooms are not wheelchair accessible, but the first floor bathroom is.  Please let us know your needs so we can help make the event accessible for you.

Note: We welcome intrepid winter bike riders, though there are not many good spots for parking bikes, and bicycles are prohibited in the building.  We apologize for the inconvenience.
results.name: Advocate for Justice Through Legislation

results.description:
Herbal Support for Seasonal Depression

A New England winter can be a tough prospect. Mark Twain purportedly said that if you didn’t like the weather here, you could just wait fifteen minutes – but in February you might cycle through snow, sleet, freezing rain, frostbite, and melted-enough-to-be-muddy all in one week. Add to that the post-holiday crash, and it’s no wonder people start to feel down in the dumps. What happened to the winter wonderland?

Sunflowers sleep all through the winter, and no one says they have a disorder. You’re not much different!

Herbs can’t change the weather, but they might help you get a sunnier outlook on life. In this class, we’ll focus on seasonal-affective “disorder” – taking some time to critique that particular pathologizing nomenclature – and get at the root causes of depression to seek out strategies for healing. Come learn when St John’s Wort is helpful (and when it isn’t), how to improve sleep (and why needing a little more this time of year is normal), how to make delicious herbal chai for daytime energy and resilience, and which foods are essential for a good mood and a clear mind.

Wednesday, February 17th, 2016
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at <a>[masked]</a>, or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Herbal Support for Depression

results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.

We are going to get into QGIS (formerly known as Quantum GIS). QGIS is free, open-source, and highly capable GIS software. If you've ever been curious about QGIS and want to learn more, or never even heard of it, join us! We are going to go through some of the basics of using the QGIS software, including adding data, projecting data, symbolizing and map design, and geoprocessing.

If you've been using QGIS for years, come and lend your expertise to help others get started and answer questions. 

Look for more information, including how to download the software, to be posted soon. Beginners are very welcome. Don't forget to bring a laptop.

We're back to our regular location at the CIC near Kendall Square. Check in with security when you get in the building and take the elevator to the 4th floor.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours.  Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here: https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week.  This part usually takes about 15 minutes.  The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!"  Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join.  It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in.  Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.

results.description:
Anxiety permeates our lives, often without us even knowing it. Fear stops us from being at our best. To feel better, we try to soothe ourselves through a variety of means. Some are relatively harmless such as watching hours of mindless TV, scrolling through Facebook, and escaping through our work. Others may be more harmful such as self medicating through alcohol or drugs. However, every behavior pattern we find ourselves in--even seemingly unrelated ones like overspending, needy relationships and gambling--can often be traced back to anxiety. The bottom line is that we innocently get caught up in destructive patterns because they temporarily make us feel better. While we're in the midst of them, we are able to ignore, or simply don't notice the anxious stream of thoughts constantly floating through our minds.

Unfortunately, while we may have unconsciously set out to escape scary thoughts, after a while, life can start to spiral out of control. Until one day we wake up and barely recognize the person we've become. We're paralyzed with inaction and the behaviors that made us feel better, now make us feel worse. This creates even more anxiousness. Now we have to worry about really big stuff such as our failing health, our finances and/or relationships. 


What if there was a way of seeing life differently so that we didn't need our old soothing behaviors?
What if there was a simple, yet profound understanding of how life truly works that could ease our minds? What if just by having this understanding at a deep level, our anxiety would start to evaporate on its own? While this sounds pretty lofty, there is such an understanding. One in which there's nothing to do but have an "Aha Moment." 

 
If it's true--(and it is)--we're home free.
Join us for a no cost, no strings, no nonsense talk on where your anxiety comes from and how it can be eliminated.

This meeting will be lead by Jill Whalen, the Meet Up organizer.

More About Jill:

For over 18 years Jill was a highly successful web marketing consultant. After a 6 month period of losing weight and getting fit and healthy, she woke up one day to the voice of wisdom inside her telling her it was time for a change. She immediately closed up shop and spent the next few years learning everything she could about personal transformation, health and wellness and the mind-body-spirit connection. At some point in her journey Jill became aware of just how much anxiety was constantly floating around in the background of her mind. While she had various coping strategies such as drinking unhealthy amounts of alcohol and avoiding the things she feared, something inside her told her there had to be a better way. When she stumbled upon a new understanding of how life really works and what her anxiety was actually comprised of, her reality looked completely different. Though she still gets anxious at times, her knowledge has almost miraculously made it unnecessary for her seek anything outside of herself to feel better. As a professional conference speaker, trainer and writer, Jill is on a quest to share her knowledge and experience of personal and business transformation in small groups, on a one-to-one basis and via her blog: "What Did You Do With Jill?"
results.how_to_find_us: Ashland, MA

results.description:
The hosting duties for the regular Wednesday Night Gaming are being handled by a rotating cast of regulars who are helping out the Glass-Chewing Leader of the Cartel.

Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
The Boston Dyke March is an amazing alt-Pride event that gives space and voice to those often overshadowed both in society and in the queer community. We are intersectional and inclusive -the Dyke March is for EVERYONE, regardless of gender identity, orientation, age, religion, race, background, or ability. Want be part of something big in your community while meeting new people and having fun? We'd love to have you!

In addition to the March itself in June, we plan events and activities throughout the year, have fun Committee social outings, advocate for social change, and generally be awesome. We're looking to shake things up and grow, and we want you to be part of that. We are a consensus based, grassroots, totally volunteer-run group, so every voice matters. We hope to see you there!

(Meeting is taking place in the Mass NOW and NARAL Pro Choice MA conference room in Suite 900. Office is near State, Park, and Downtown Crossing T stations.)

results.description:
LOVE love, love is all you need, right? Were the Beatles right? Love is a part of almost every song we hear. It's a longing we all want, that perfect connection with a significant other.


New relationships always start out right, then something begins to shift and before we know it things just aren’t the same. What happened? Why don’t we feel that same spark? Could it be that you and your loved one are speaking two different languages?

Join us as we explore: The Five Languages of Love: The Secret to Love That Lasts based on a Book by New York Times bestselling author Dr. Gary Chapman

There are five basic love languages – five ways to express love emotionally. Each person has a primary love language that we must learn to speak if we want that person to feel loved.

You Will:

• Identifying the Five Love Languages

• Discover Your Love Language

• Learn how to build on Loving Relationships that Last


With Love

Ellen Sklaver,


Facilitator, PSYCH-K & NLP Practitioner

results.description:
The first Metrowest Post-Divorce Meetup went very well, thank you to all who attended and participated. One of the topics that was discussed and also voted on during this group’s recent survey poll, was a desire to meet and socialize with others and get a sense of how to establish and enjoy our New Life post-divorce. So this next Meetup will incorporate that theme.

Socializing; finding new friends, hobbies, interests. Many of us find ourselves in a different social situation once we are divorced or separated. Some friends stay with us and others split away. Old routines are gone and new ones under development. What is your experience? Have you taken steps to develop your new social life? What would you like to do to develop, enrich or begin to explore new social venues, interests and hobbies? Perhaps you already have a sense of what your interests are or maybe you are figuring it all out and not sure how to get started.


Bring your ideas and questions to share with others. Perhaps we can incorporate these ideas into another Meetup in the future. Of course other topics are open to discussion but this will be the theme. Also, this group will plan a social outing shortly, so keep an eye open for that soon.

I look forward to meeting with everyone and hope you can make it.
results.name: Wednesday Night New Life

results.description:
Hey everyone. This month we are going to try something a little different and see how it goes. I'm hoping this session will be good for intro level people, and fun for expert level people too. I don't expect it'll go the full two hours, so after we finish we can hang out and talk Haskell.


James Larisch - 7:15-8:?? - Haskell Code Review


For my Networks & Distributed Systems assignments we were given free reign over which language to choose, so I decided to finally implement something “real” (much to the chagrin of my Professor and homework partner). I’d like to provide an overview of the assignment and the project structure so I can receive some feedback on how to write more elegant, idiomatic, and efficient Haskell — since I’ve mostly been writing it in a vacuum.

Bio: I’m a junior at Northeastern University and have been learning Haskell on my own for almost a year now. I’ve co-op’ed (interned) at HubSpot, a startup in Los Angeles called Gem, and am now at Sonian. My technical interests include functional programming, Bitcoin, and distributed systems. 


Logistics: 

As usual, we will be meeting at Akamai from 7-9pm.

If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.

Food:

Pizzas, salad and soda.

Afterwards:

If you'd like to stick around, a number of us tend to head down to the CBC or another pub afterwards to socialize. If you would like to give a talk or if you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to follow up here or email one of the organizers.
results.how_to_find_us: Simply come to the front door of Akamai. If you can, please plan on arriving between 6:45pm and 7pm, but there will be someone in the lobby to greet stragglers.
results.name: James Larisch - Haskell Code Review!

results.description:
I have been thinking about Youth, especially as "today's youths," seem so technically advanced compared with where I was when I was their age - regarding programming and internet stuff, etc...  that got me thinking about, what is it about youth that makes learning seem so easy, and why do we lose that.  Are there good and bad things that happen as we get older.  Is there any benefit to "maturing," if so is it worth the cost of agility, hope, wonder, etc.. that come with being young?  

CS Lewis: Some day you will be old enough to start reading fairy tails again.

Maya Angelou: Most people don't grow up. Most people age. They find parking spaces, honor their credit cards, get married, have children, and call that maturity. What that is, is aging.


Virginia Woolf: Growing up is losing some illusions, in order to acquire others.

Excited to discuss with you all, hope you can make it.
results.how_to_find_us: we'll be in the booths at the back
results.name: On Youth and Maturation

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom Rose and Chad

results.description:
Can we have FUN while letting go of stuff?  We might be used to the feeling of dread, we might even go "UUGGGGG" out loud whenever we think about our closet or garage or whole house! Are there ways we can make the process fun? If it wasn't something we hated doing would we spend more time on it and more often? Let's share stories and ideas on how we can make this fun!  

AND

What is stopping you from letting go of excess stuff? There are millions of excuses of why we don't move forward. By the end of the meetup, each participant who wants one will have a strategy to try out on their unique situation. 

Come join in the conversation!
results.how_to_find_us: DOWNSTAIRS: Find us in the lower floor at a table with tape that says "LESS STUFF MORE JOY."
results.name: Fun while letting go of stuff? What is stopping you? (Cambridge)

results.description:
Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.
results.how_to_find_us: Right off of exit 6 on 93 south, coming from Boston, TGI Friday's is on your right side at the first set of lights, across from the South Shore Plaza Mall
results.name: South Shore ASL meetup

results.description:
William wrote an excellent description so I'm going to flat out steal it:

For those of you who are not familiar, Citizen Public House and Oyster Bar is a whiskey and cocktails establishment with a bit of a hipster vibe (flannel and fixie not required). They make some delicious beverages and have a disturbingly large selection of whiskey, scotch, and bourbon for you to disinfect your gut with. It's in Fenway, not terribly far from the Kenmore T stop. There's also a garage that validates around the corner ($4 for up to 3 hours, full price after that) Street parking is possible, but requires selling either your soul or your firstborn.

Citizen does have some lovely, if overpriced, food. And if you're feeling sassy/poor, you can hop out the door, cross the street, grab a modestly priced Tasty Burger ("Mmmmm, now that is a tasty burger!"), and be back before anyone knows you're gone.

Expect to be asked to provide proof of nerdiness.

Some assembly required.
results.name: Citizenship in the World

results.description:
Objectives of event:


Inspire and Motivate these entrepreneurs to pursue their ideas, to think differently.

Demystify the world of Venture Capital, understand the advantages and how it works


In addition, the webinar could lead to creating new networking opportunities or simply making new friends!

Agenda:

Intro (15 Minutes):


Presentation of startups-innovation 

Quick intro of guest speaker Ian Knowles VC New York (See further down for Bio)

Get grounded on Venture Capital (45 Minutes):

What does it take to become a Venture Capitalist entrepreneur or work for a VC firm (skills, knowledge, mindset)? 

What does a day in the life of a Venture Capitalist entrepreneur like you look like? i.e. Tell us about your work at LB Equity a private equity fund, Spruce & Norton, Lucas group?

How should entrepreneurs approach you or a venture Capitalist firm in general (Do you look for them or should they be looking for you)?  

How difficult is it to get funded and what is it you would be looking for?

What is the value-add a VC firms brings to the table when partnering with entrepreneurs?

Things move fast, and it must not be easy to make the right decisions. How do you go about staying abreast of the market, business and economic trends, and hear about interesting new opportunities?

What’s your general feel for 2016? How does it look for Venture Capital and entrepreneurs?

From your experience, what is the biggest advice you can give to an entrepreneur? What differentiates the winners from the rest?

Do you have one inspiring story to share? (I.e. success story etc…)

Questions and answers from the audience (30 Minutes)

Presentation of guest speaker: Ian Knowles


Ian is a passionate foodie and ambitious entrepreneur. Starting his career at Perkins Fund Marketing, a Southport Connecticut based investment firm, while also moonlighting as a Chef under Michelin Starred Chef, Andy Nusser.


Soon thereafter, he helped launch LB Equity, a $35M health/beauty focused private equity fund, where he became a partner and oversaw fund development, investment sourcing/diligence, operations, negotiations and brand management. Ian has launched three brands with LBE, Including Immunocology, Youth Corridor and most recently HYD. 


In 2014, Ian founded Spruce & Norton a modern investment and development company, where he could focus his passion for food, beverage and sustainability. Spruce & Norton is currently working on initiatives to enhance the local food infrastructure in the tri-state area and is also building a brewery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Ian is also leading a team to purchase an All Natural Ginger Beer company. In 2015, Ian and Spruce & Norton arranged the $4.4M financing for a Nashville based brewer ("Tailgate") and purchased the North American rights to an exquisite Italian Brewery, Birrificio Del Forte which will launch in the US Q2 2016. 


Ian is a partner at the middle-market private equity consulting firm, The Lucas Group, where he oversees corporate strategy, business planning and finance. Ian co-founded Chelsea Ventures, an early stage venture investment firm who's mission is to back aspiring entrepreneurs who have identified a unique whitespace in a globally scalable market where the founding team has direct and distinct domaine expertise. Ian is a senior advisor to the recently formed BeyondBrands, a "Conscious" CPG Brand Development firm. 


Ian is the founder of The Big Andrew Foundation, a regional non-profit founded to financially and morally assist cancer patients and their families while enduring treatment and recovery. Through two flagship events, The Big Andrew Surf Contest and Big Andrew Car Classic, the organization has been able to provide support to hundreds of patients in New England since its founding in 2008. 


Ian lives in Williamsburg Brooklyn with his dog Cali, and enjoys reading, fitness, surfing, paddle boarding, painting and cooking!

results.name: Venture Capitalist Ian Knowles from NY - Talks With Entrepreneurs

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.   

Buy The Books

results.description:
Strategic partnerships are far different from creating, or joining, a partners program. With strategic partnerships companies can gain access to a large group of customers and the sales people who sell to them, and potentially a significant investment, without giving up any of their own equity.

George Adams will be leading the discussion. George brings over 25 years of successful executive experience creating and growing mobile, enterprise, and security software businesses. As CEO of startup ViziApps, he has created strategic partnerships with such companies as Salesforce, Intuit and AT&T. Before co-founding ViziApps, he was CEO of SSH Communications Security Inc. (recently renamed Tectia Inc.), building it from a startup to an industry leader and $400M IPO. Before that, he was VP of Marketing, Products, and Business Development, for Phoenix Technologies Ltd., helping create and expand the PC, laptop, and mobile device industries. Earlier, he launched and built key new industry-leading businesses at Sun Microsystems, Intel, Analog Devices, and Motorola. George has served on the Boards of several early stage information technology companies and spoken at numerous industry conferences. He earned an MBA from Boston University and a BSEE from the University of Miami.

Registration includes a full breakfast at the Newton Marriott Riverbend restaurant
results.how_to_find_us: We're in the Riverbend restaurant at the back of the first floor
results.name: Using strategic partnerships to build your business

results.description:
Totalcon has always been my favorite gaming convention. I love it soooo much that I am actually going to be running the board game teaching area this year. I plan on meeting friends there starting either on Monday or Tuesday this year for pre-con gaming. So, I will still be having plenty of fun and we all know that I enjoy spreading the hobby by teaching people new games.

http://www.totalcon.com/index.html

Pre-registration will open soon. I will post it here. Probably the last week of December. The convention is $20 per day or $50 for the whole 4 day weekend. The hotel is sold out for Friday and Saturday nights. Rooms are still available for the rest of the week. Most everyone that missed out on the weekend rooms are staying at the nearby Red Roof Inn.

I will be compiling a list of teaching games over the next few weeks. These events require an event ticket which cost $1.50 for each two hour block. A game like Arkham Horror might take up two blocks and you would need two $1.50 tickets. Before I started teaching games at Totalcon, I used to get the all day pass for $7.50, which allows you to play in any scheduled events. There are also many tournament games and regional qualifiers. There are crazy amounts of role playing games scheduled and available. There are miniatures, war games, a Puffing Billy competition (all train/rail games) and Diplomacy is being added this year.

 I am looking for people to teach games. If you would like to teach something this year email me at [masked] to let me know. Naturally, I am looking
for games that people are going to want to learn/play.

I am looking for any games released in 2015.

Any games designed by:

Stefan Feld, Uwe Rosenberg, Vital Lacerda, Vlaada Chvatil, Martin Wallace, Richard Breese, Matt Leacock, Eric Lang, Matthias Cramer, Phil Ecklund, Carl Chudyk, Scott Almes and Ignacy Trzewiczek.

The BGG top 50:

Twilight Struggle, Terra Mystica, Puerto Rico, Android: Netrunner, Star Wars: Imperial Assault, Eclipse, Power Grid, War of the Ring, Tzolk’in: The Mayan Calendar, Dead of Winter, 7 Wonders, Caylus, Dominion, Dominant Species, Race for the Galaxy, El Grande, Star Wars:
X-Wing Miniatures, Eldritch Horror, Lords of Waterdeep, Battlestar Galactica, Roll for the Galaxy, The Resistance, Five Tribes, A Game of Thrones, Descent, Castles of Mad King Ludwig, Pandemic, Russian Railroads, Nations, Concordia, Troyes, Suburbia and Stone Age.

2013 and 2014 Hotness:

Alchemists, Legendary: Encounters, Splendor, Lewis and Clarke, Viticulture, Istanbul, Battlelore, La Granja, Arcadia Quest, Sherriff of Nottingham, Orleans, Pathfinder Adventure Card Game, Marvel Dice Masters, Xia: Legends of a Drift System, Bruxelles 1893, King of New York, Mysterium, Euphoria: Build a Better Dystopia, Deus, Firefly,
Spyfall, Colt Express, Madeira, Evolution, Abyss, Camel Up, Coal Baron, Hyperborea, San Juan, Lords of Xidit, Zhanguo, Viceroy, Patchistory, Scoville, Brew Crafters, Shadowrun: Crossfire, Diamonds, Wir sind das Volk!, Fire in the Sky, Heroes of Normandie, Nations: The Dice Game, Medieval Academy, CV, The Stauffer Dynasty, The Golden Ages, Murano, Navajo Wars and Heroes Wanted.

This list is not exhaustive, but you should get the idea. An out of print game like Egizia would be great. As would a party classic like Cash and Guns.  If you’re not sure what you want to teach, let this list be your guide. If there’s anything you want to teach, contact me.

[masked]

Thanks in advance.

I hope to see you there!!
results.name: Totalcon 2016

results.description:
This class is an opportunity to learn or continue your practice of Shamanic Journeying. You will "travel" to meet powers animals and other helpful teachers and guides through the practice of Shamanic Journeying. We will discuss the benefits and the process and then experience two journeys. To the lower world to meet a power animal or guardian spirit, to the upper world to meet a spiritual teacher or to the Middle World to connect to the hidden folk or an element in nature. The class will be catered to the needs and experience of the class.

Shamanic Journeying allows you to lift the veil between our 3D world and other dimensions. It is a wonderful way to get Divine guidance as well as healing from loving helpers who are waiting and eager to be of assistance.

Dress comfortably. Bring a journal or notebook, You may want a scarf or eye mask to cover your eyes to aid in going deeper into the journey.

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions prior to the class.

Price for workshop is $30. Please RSVP. Minimum of 3 people needed to hold this class. Bring a friend!

Blessings,

Wendy (978)[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We are located behind the Wadsworth School in the Fuller building (lower level).
results.name: Shamanic Journeying Class

results.description:
Boston Parks and Recreation Department will be bringing the annual Children’s Winter Festival to Boston Common during school vacation week on Tuesday, February 16, from 10:00am - 4:00pm.

Among the attractions will be Snowzilla, a three-story-high inflatable snow tube slide, and SnowGlobe Live!, a 15-foot-tall snow globe that allows participants to step inside for winter wonderland photos. In addition, the Highland Street Foundation is sponsoring a week-long Winter Camp at the Boston Common Frog Pond with free skating and rentals for all ages from Monday, February 15, through Friday, February 19. For more information on the Winter Camp skating, please visit www.highlandstreet.org.

The festival will also feature a DJ from Magic 106.7, an appearance by the L.L.Bean Bootmobile, and refreshments from Essentia Water, DAVIDsTEA, and Dunkin’ Donuts. The L.L.Bean Outdoor Discovery School will present activities including, weather permitting, their Snowshoeing Discovery Course, a fun and easy way to try out the sport with expert instructors who will lead an easy guided trek through Boston Common. Snowshoes will be provided and participants should wear weather-appropriate clothing and winter or hiking boots. Additional support is being provided by the Massachusetts WIC Nutrition Program and Internet Essentials from Comcast. For more information, please call the Boston Parks and Recreation Department at (617)[masked], visit www.cityofboston.gov/parks or go to www.facebook.com/bostonparksdepartment.


http://www.bostoncentral.com/events/schoolvacationweek/p45587.php
results.name: Children's Winter Festival on the Boston Common

results.description:
Meditation practice develops concentration, which allows us to calm and steady the mind and give us clear access to our natural wisdom. This practice is 30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion.

The focus is to be present in the moment, allowing thoughts and emotions to surface. We become an internal observer of these, fostering healthy non-attachment and cultivating a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend.
