results.name: Mindfulness Meditation

results.description:
I have yet to play it, but to hear people at BGG tell it, Food Chain Magnate is rivaling Pandemic Legacy for the 2015 Game That People Will Still Be Talking About In Ten Years title. And wouldn't you know someone's put together a site where you can play Food Chain Magnate online. I have no idea how good the implementation is, but people are playing it and liking it, so what the hey, let's give it a try.

Like I said, I don't know the game beyond reading the rules, but it's a Splotter game, so don't expect it to be easy or forgiving. My impression is that it's an unholy union of 18xx, Indonesia, Le Havre, Dominion, and Age of Steam.

The Board Game Core site does not have a mechanism for setting up a password-protected game so the best course of action is to set up (a) game(s) where the invites are sent to individual users of the site. So if you're interested, leave a comment with your Board Game Core username and we'll figure out how to set up the games as we go.
results.name: Let's Try Food Chain Magnate!

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Do you love a teenager?  Do you want to help them gain greater self understanding? Teen Insight 1 will help your beloved teens learn to make conscious choices that support creating the life they really want.

For many, the teenage years are the most challenging time in life. This is when peer pressure asserts itself most forcefully and issues like alcohol, drugs, gender issues and sex often present. This is also when teenagers start to think about what they really want from life, and wonder if they can achieve it. 


http://www.insightseminars.org/uploads/6/0/0/1/60013961/4380606.jpg?432

Teen Insight I brings together teenagers from diverse backgrounds who discover that they are not alone; they all face similar challenges. What’s more, the teens experience the power of their loving heart to resolve conflicts — both inner conflicts and outer conflicts.  They learn to make conscious choices that support creating the life experiences they really want.

The teens in the Teen Insight I seminar make close connections and practice compassionate leadership. They start awakening to the magnificence of their heart.

https://youtu.be/62uX84HZ6wI

OVERVIEW 

Teen Insight I -- The Awakening Heart is a 3.5-day seminar that follows a format similar to the adult Insight I seminar except that teens typically move through their issues more quickly than adults. As a result, deeper work can be accomplished more quickly.

Resistance to being in the seminar is addressed in the early part of the seminar’s first day. By the end of the seminar most teens are looking for ways to continue the experience and maintain connection with their new friends.

The seminar structure and dynamic pace capture teens’ imagination, and includes one-to-one processes, small group exercises and whole-group activities. While similar to the adult Insight I, the Teen seminar includes more age appropriate games, dancing and fun. Both heartfelt laughter and joyful tears are keynotes of the Teen Insight I seminar.

To accommodate school schedules, the seminar has been scheduled to take place at the end of the February school vacation week in Massachusetts. 

Click here to register and secure your seat:

- - > http://www.cvent.com/events/teen-insight-i-february-18-21-2016-boston-ma/event-summary-9931a51762f94497b95ed80dba411604.aspx

(Some of the) Themes of the Seminar:
- Self-identity
- Social skills
- Self-confidence, self-esteem and self-worth
- Motivation
- Communication skills
- Relationships with peers, teachers and parents
- Inner strengths
- Win-win cooperation
- Leadership 
- Personal success
- Peer pressure
- Wise choices
- Forgiveness
- Judgment
- Accountability
- Empowerment
- Self-acceptance

http://www.insightseminars.org/uploads/6/0/0/1/60013961/7559568.png?385

The seminar teaches practical tools that the teen can use every day -- in schools, with the family, with peers, and in business.  It helps the teen identify and integrate inner and outer resources towards what the teen identifies as major goals for her life.

On the final day of the seminar parents meet in a special session with facilitators to be apprised of what to expect from their teen and to learn how to best support new positive behavior.

http://www.insightseminars.org/uploads/6/0/0/1/60013961/1450301.jpg?383

Prerequisites: 
Age 14-18. Parent/guardian consent is required.

Tuition:
Standard Tuition:$425
Audit Tuition: $100 (for returning participants)

http://www.insightseminars.org/uploads/6/0/0/1/60013961/8506688.jpg?385

results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other.

Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.

This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little value unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more meaning.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 6 years and is happy to share ideas.

-------------------------------------------

* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.
results.name: Options Monthly Meeting for Boston Traders Meetup

results.description:
We've been thinking a lot about diversity in our industry. We heard about this film and decided to schedule a screening. Since we know this is an important topic to many people in our community, we decided to open up the screening to the public. Please let us know if you'd like to attend.

CODE Synopsis:

Tech jobs are growing three times faster than our colleges are producing computer science graduates. By 2020, there will be one million unfilled software engineering jobs in the USA. Through compelling interviews, artistic animation and clever flashpoints in popular culture, CODE documentary examines the reasons why more girls and people of color are not seeking opportunities in computer science and explores how cultural mindsets, stereotypes, educational hurdles and sexism all play roles in this national crisis. Expert voices from the worlds of tech, psychology, science, and education are intercut with inspiring stories of women who are engaged in the fight to challenge complacency in the tech industry and have their voices heard. CODE aims to inspire change in mindsets, in the educational system, in startup culture and in the way women see themselves in the field of coding.

For more info: 

http://www.codedoc.co
results.name: Movie Screening: Debugging the Gender Gap - Code Documentary

Every front end needs a great backend! This is true now more than ever in today’s connected world, where it’s extremely important to have your data with you at all times, even if you are disconnected from the internet.

This month, we are joined by Gavin Bauman of Microsoft, as he walks us through how to add a powerful backend to our iOS, Android, and Windows mobile apps in just a few minutes with Azure Mobile Services. Azure also sports some other amazing features, including the ability to send push notifications and authenticate users. 

If you are building a mobile app in need of a backend as a service, this is the perfect meetup for you! Be sure to invite others you think would be interested, as well as RSVP so we can get an accurate count for pizza and our Xamarin swag giveaways (including a Xamarin t-shirt, Creating Mobile Apps with Xamarin.Forms by Charles Petzold books, and lots of Xamarin stickers).

results.description:
Join us for a lively look back at 2015 in this moderated panel discussion, and learn about best practices from some of the Boston area’s product management leaders. Be there as these executives share their real-world stories and experiences with the kinds of challenges you face in the field. You’ll find out how their roadmaps and goals played out – what worked, what didn’t, and how they plan to evolve and improve in 2016.


Under the guidance of moderator Steve Robins, the panel will consider questions such as:
- What are your top two goals from last year, and why?
- What went well? What didn’t?
- What have you learned? What still puzzles you?
- What were your biggest challenges in 2015 – and how do you plan to address them differently this year?
- How did you measure progress toward your goals last year?

IMPORTANT: There is a fee for this event.  Please register in advance on the following page to receive the discounted advance price of $20 or no charge for BPMA premium members: </a><a href="http://bit.ly/160218Meet1">http://bit.ly/160218Meet1  


Timeline for the evening: 


6:15 pm: Registration opens
6:30 - 7:30 pm: Networking (light refreshments)
7:30 - 8:30 pm: Panel
8:30 - 9:00 pm: Wrap up and additional Networking

About the Panelists:
Scott Hilton, EVP of Products at Dyn
Scott Hilton is the Executive Vice President of Products at Dyn where he is responsible for the management, marketing, strategy, roadmap and business performance for Dyn’s industry-leading portfolio of Internet Performance solutions. Scott specializes in driving growth strategies for product companies, having spent more than 15 years doing just that for SpringTide Networks, Lucent Technologies (Nasdaq: ALU), 3com (Nasdaq: COMS), and Sycamore Networks (Nasdaq: SCMR). At Sycamore, Scott was VP & GM of Mobile Broadband Solutions, responsible for establishing a new business unit, and development and launch of a new content optimization product into the mobile broadband market. Scott is also an accomplished inventor and entrepreneur. He currently holds two patents in the network space — one for virtual private networks (VPN) automation and the other for mobile location-based services. He is also the founder of Spatial Adventures, a SaaS-based mobile tourism service. Scott has a Bachelor of Science in Electrical Engineering from Duke University and a Master in Science of Electrical Engineering degree from George Mason University. He is also a military veteran, having served as a Submarine Officer in the U.S. Navy.

Bryan Dunn, Senior Director, Product Management at Localytics
Bryan Dunn runs product management at Localytics, a SaaS based mobile engagement platform that helps customers acquire, engage, grow and retain mobile app users. Bryan has experience bringing successful products to market, building effective product, engineering and user experience teams from the ground up and designing process to maximize efficacy. Previously, Bryan was Chief Product and Technology Officer at GTxcel where he designed a SaaS based publishing platform used by over 2,000 of the world’s top publishers.

Conor O'Mahony, VP Product Management at SilverRail Technologies
Conor leads great teams to build great products. Currently, Conor leads Product Management for SilverRail Technologies, who are a fast-growing start-up with offices in Boston, London, Stockholm, and Brisbane. Previously, Conor had General Management, Product Management, and Product Marketing leadership roles in companies large and small. He has experience leading Sales, Marketing, Support, Product, Design, and Development organizations. Conor lives in Belmont with his energetic young family, and enjoys running, hiking, and camping.

Erin McHugh Saif, Product Leader at Tibco Spotfire
Erin McHugh Saif is a product leader in the areas of Business Intelligence, Analytics and Cloud Business Services with extensive product management experience across several diverse industries (Cloud BI, Data Visualization, CRM systems, Business Analytics and Nonprofit Management). Erin has deep experience leading organizations through on-premises to Cloud product transformations, including waterfall to agile development methodology, license to subscription pricing transformation, engineering to development operations practices and most important, evolving to a simple, effective and delightful self-service trial, purchase and user experience. Erin currently serves as a Senior Product Manager of Cloud products at TIBCO. She manages TIBCO's Spotfire Cloud SaaS and PaaS data visualization products. She recently led a senior executive leadership team to define and design TIBCO Spotfire's next generation Cloud Business Services Architecture.


Erin has a BA in English and Political Science from Wellesley College. She has has served in a Board or Advisory capacity to CARE International, The ONE Campaign and ArtsBoston. 


Moderator:


Steve Robins, Principal at Solution Marketing Strategies
Steve Robins is the principal of Solution Marketing Strategies, a strategic marketing consultancy that helps companies to better understand and market to their customers through targeted research, segmentation, solutions, messaging, sales tools and demand generation. For the last 15 years, Steve Robins has been transforming technology firms into market-leading, customer-focused solution providers. Steve has held senior marketing roles at FirstBest Systems, EMC, Documentum, and KANA Software. An industry thought-leader, Steve started the top-rated solution marketing blog, writes a CMO-focused marketing tech column for TechTarget, helped grow ProductCamp Boston into the second largest such event in the world, and was an analyst at the Yankee Group.

results.description:
Writing database applications that are both performant and well-designed is a tricky business.
We just can’t seem to contain our persistence concerns within a persistence module. Perhaps we have a database ID appearing in our API. Or there is a service method that contains-commit ­strategy logic that we wish was managed by our ORM. The text-­book toolset of the past hasn’t helped. Entity-­relationship domain modeling, relational databases, old-­fashioned OO programming languages, and a database driver or an ORM, all fight against us as we try to write maintainable code.

Thankfully, today, we have a much richer toolset: Domain Driven Design, NoSQL databases, and F/OO programming languages. But when doing Scala and NoSQL, we end up resorting to database drivers. While very good at what they do, drivers provide a low­-level API that leaves the heavy­lifting of persistence to us.

Longevity is a persistence framework that takes advantage of all these new technologies ­ DDD, NoSQL, and Scala ­ to provide a fluent and clear API that encapsulates persistence concerns, removing them entirely from your domain model and service classes.

In this talk, we will discuss some of the core concepts of Domain Driven Design, and how they can be used to elegantly manage your persistence concerns. We’ll then look at how to apply these principles in your application using the longevity API.

Speaker bio:
John Sullivan is an 18-­year Java veteran who has been happily programming in Scala for over 5 years. He is the creator of longevity, a DDD-­oriented persistence framework for Scala and NoSQL. A seasoned software engineer with a focus on back-­end development and database integration, he is a strong advocate of the Domain Driven Design approach to software development. When he’s not coding, John enjoys posting in­-depth articles on his Scala-­oriented
blog scabl.blogspot.com. John has a Master of Science in Computer Science from UMass Boston. He is currently working as a contractor for Dow Jones in Minneapolis.
results.how_to_find_us: Let the front desk know you are there for Scala meetup and proceed to 2nd floor.
results.name: Domain Driven Design with Scala and NoSQL

We'll attend “Mass Incarceration and Gentrification: The Path to Dispossession,” a public forum sponsored by The Center for Church and Prison, Inc.  Our intention in attending is to learn more about these issues from the people most impacted by them, and to think about ways we can be involved in fighting these connected issues.


From the event description:


Mass incarceration is one thing and gentrification is another, but have you considered the intersection between the both of them? Mass incarceration and its after effects of criminal records, joblessness and lack of sustainable income for many have led to the decline in property ownership, sustainability and property transition for many families and individuals. This is especially true for urban dwellers and the Black community where over 60% of prisoners are taken from largely as a result of the war on drugs, etc.

results.description:
Design & Development = Better Together

RSVP on Eventbrite: UXPA Monthly Meeting

Many companies have designers and developers working together but most companies also have a company culture driven by one or the other.  Developer centric companies and cultures value technical solutions (Microsoft) and design-centric cultures value design over technology (Apple). The best products however come from the combination of the two. 


This talk will cover specific techniques and methodology of designers working with developers to solve problems and produce better products. The approach is integrated into an Agile/Scrum process and this has helped create products that both ship to market and push for design and usability excellence.  

About Greg Raiz

Greg Raiz founded Raizlabs in 2003 with a vision to create awesome software. Greg is a leader in the Boston and SF technology and mobile community and has worked on a wide range of problems.

Greg graduated Tufts University and got his start at Microsoft as a program manager on Windows XP.  After that, he moved back to Boston and founded Raizlabs with a focus on user experience.

Greg is active in the mobile and design community, in Boston, SF and beyond. He founded DrinksOnTap.org and AltConf and has spoken on mobile tech at many universities and events including MIT, MobileMonday, Harvard Business School, Bentley and Olin, as well as for companies like Microsoft, Fidelity, Staples and others. He has served on the boards of BostonCHI and the usability group, UXPA Boston. He is currently growing Raizlabs and recently spun off a mobile service called AppBlade.com.

Greg Raiz can be contacted at [masked]. His personal blog, Greg’s Head, covers interface design, mobile technology and user experience topics. He can also be found on Twitter as @graiz.

Agenda

6:30 - 7:00 PM – Networking and Refreshments 

7:00 - 7:15 PM – Introductions

7:15 - 8:00 PM - Presentation

8:00 - 8:15 PM - Q&A

About Raizlabs

Raizlabs is a mobile software development company with offices in Boston and San Francisco. We have been crafting award-winning apps since before the launch of the iTunes App Store in 2008. Today, we build apps across many platforms with a focus on iPhone, iPad and Android.

We believe in building software that is not just great, but memorable, inspiring, remarkable and entertaining. We work with companies to understand their users and to shape and guide their mobile strategy. We love what we do, and our passion is what keeps our customers coming back. We work with companies that share our belief in quality, user experience, and the power of great software to shape modern business.

Food Sponsor: 

Onward Search connects skilled professionals with the best jobs across the country in all areas within digital marketing and creative technology with a focus in the UX space. We know those jobs because our recruiters know all sides of the equation. We cultivate relationships. We work with communities of talent and business leaders alike. We build teams to meet the demands of today’s workplace.
results.name: UXPA: Design & Development = Better Together

The CfA would prefer that attendees not take pictures, but if you decide to, please do not use a flash.

******************************

From the CfA:


Watch It Live

Big Data to Big Art Henry "Trae" Winter, CfA

We currently live in the Information Age, where terms like "Big Data" and the "Internet of Things" are ingrained into the public consciousness. This massive compilation of data is useless without tools to aid us in comprehending what the numbers mean. These tools are almost always visual in nature and creating them requires not only a knowledge of math and science, but also an understanding of how human beings interpret and interact with the world around them. We will explore a few large datasets and the tools developed to visualize them, and see that the boundaries between art and science are very often blurred.

Please RSVP truthfully. 

If you end up on the waiting list and you REALLY like the topic you can show up anyways as this is a public event.

Thanks!

results.description:
Who said it was cold in Boston this time of year? Well, this month's OpenStack Meetup will add some more cool! Harry Sutton and the HPE team join us a co-sponsor this month.


Freezer is a project in incubation in Openstack, which means it's under development but not yet ready for prime time. So what is it? It's a Backup as a Service project, with features that include strong encryption, client-side backup utilities, snapshots, and the ability to do a complete disaster-recovery restore of an entire Openstack infrastructure.


There are lots of moving parts, and lots of issues continuing to be worked, but come and listen to a general overview of the project and get familiar with this evolving critical piece of the total OpenStack puzzle.


Our session will be led by Harry Sutton, a Distinguished Technologist with Technology Services, Enterprise Group, HPE. 

Reminders:

• A light dinner and soft drinks will be provided courtesy of HP ~ 6:15pm and we will kick off the sessions ~ 7:00pm.

• If you are interested in giving a Lightening Talk shoot us a note with a topic or just come to the session ready to speak!

• DON'T FORGET - for security reasons, the NERD center requires attendees to show a government issued photo ID in order to gain access into the building.

• Parking: Best option for parking is the NERD center parking garage which charges a flat rate after 4pm.
results.name: OpenStack Meetup: What's in the freezer?

This is Four Week Training in Beginners Qi Gong

Join Gifted Qi Gong Instructor Patty Gage for a 4 Week Introduction Practice of Qi Gong - Qi Gong provides a gentle journey relieving the following:

(No experience required)
Take control of your health and well-being at any age or fitness level by practicing Qi Gong, a system of Chinese movement that removes energy blockages in the body.  The emphasis of this class is to reduce stress, increase energy, quiet the mind, and enhance the immune system to bring the body into harmony and balance.

Qi Gong increases the body’s energy (Qi) through gentle stretching, low-impact movement, deep rhythmic breathing and acupressure massage. The slow, relaxed movements synchronized with gentle breathing and mindful intent help to relax and release tension, developing a stronger mind/body connection.  Practitioners of Qi Gong report less tension, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. Practicing Qi Gong can relieve many ailments such as: back, neck and shoulder problems, gastrointestinal conditions, arthritis, fibromyalgia, hypertension, low immune function, headaches, and insomnia.  Therapeutic Qi Gong exercise is a prescription for health, longevity, and happiness.

Bio
Patty Gage is a Certified Qi Gong Instructor trained by Dr. Aihan Kuhn, Qi Gong and Tai Chi Master at Chinese Medicine for Health. Patty was introduced to Qi Gong in 2008 by David Silver, a certified YMAA Qi Gong instructor on Cape Cod, MA and continues to practice with him.

results.description:
Deepening into the practice of Speaking Circle turns will support you in continuing  to develop full presence in front of groups.  Being in Relational Presence with your audience is the key.

Relational Presence, the foundation of Speaking Circles, is a precondition for all masterful communication. When this state becomes your default mode of approaching every communication, you effortlessly step into a natural flow. 

Developing your capacity for Relational Presence is like strengthening a muscle that has been neglected. Unlike the struggle that physical workouts are for many, this exercise is designed to be highly pleasurable. There may be some initial confusion, discomfort, self-doubt but hang in there and do the reps no matter how it feels or what you are thinking.  With practice you will find . . . 

* Speaking Circles support you to access your natural public presence, along with your capacity to unselfconsciously express passion and purpose.

* Reach hearts, minds and souls every time through the practice of being in a Speaking Circle.

* Transmit your message and content with ease to groups of any size by practicing attunement with one listener at a time.

* Give up conventional notions of "public speaking" and discover the magic of authentic intimacy with audiences.
results.name: Deepening into Speaking From Presence

TINY HOUSES: A VERY DIFFERENT APPROACH TO HOME OWNERSHIP

ALT+Library returns in 2016! The presentation focuses on the basics of planning for and owning a tiny house on wheels; both its challenges and advantages, offering insights unique from the currently popular tiny house themed TV shows. From approximately “how much” to “where to live”, it addresses options for their general design, and heat, hot water and electricity choices, among other components. Living in a tiny house year-round is a topic of rapidly developing debate. Learn why something so “cute” and compact could cause so much discussion!

Our friends at PhotoFly Travel Club have invited us to another cultural and life changing adventure to Southeast Asia! This time we’ll be exploring the world famous Halong Bay and other highlights of Northern Vietnam before heading onto our one of a kind Cambodian Adventure. 

Go here to sign up: http://www.photoflytravel.org/northern-vietnam-cambodia-group-tours/

5 days in Northern Vietnam will take us through the Old Quarter of Hanoi to an interesting and delicious street food tour. A 3 day exotic cruise in Halong Bay will complete this part of the journey in the best way possible! This breathtaking secluded harbour has 2,000 limestone islands rising from the emerald waters of the Bac Bo gulf. It is one of Vietnam’s most scenic regions and has been referred to as the eighth Wonder of the World. 

A 7 day exploration of the Siem Reap (Angkor Wat) area in Cambodia is the perfect introduction to this incredible country. We’ll be indulging in in-room massages, temple trail adventures, & some truly life changing experiences in remote villages! 

* 4 nights/5 days of unforgettable Northern Vietnam (Halong Bay & Hanoi) 

* 6 nights/7 Days of unforgettable Cambodia (Angkor Wat, Siem Reap, Lake Tonle Sap)

* Charming boutique hotels & unforgettable village stays…

* Breakfast Everyday

* 8 Lunches & 6 Dinners Included

Vietnam (4 Nights):

* Hanoi highlight city tour (Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Presidential Palace, One Pillar Pagoda,  Ho Chi Minh Museum, Temple of Literature (Awesome photographs of the grounds and architecture here!)

* Unique Street Food Experience (Lunch and privately guided tour of the hidden but true taste of Hanoi on a discovery walk-through of Vietnamese street cuisine and culture)

* Explore the Old Quarter- (Right outside our hotel, lots of great photos to be taken along the old streets, each well-known for a specialized industry. Silk clothing ready-made and tailored, embroidery,  silver products, and so much more can be found at the different merchants.)

Cruise Halong Bay!

A great way to see spectacular Halong Bay is a slow cruise through the seemingly never-ending bay of islands. Lay in the sun, enjoy a selection of the freshest seafood, and take photograph after photograph. On our itinerary, the aim is to get off the beaten track while maintaining a leisurely pace. The size of the vessel allows passengers to get much closer to Halong Bay’s natural wonders, such as its pocket lagoons and small fishing communities.

* 2 night/3 Day all inclusive cruise of the best & off the path destinations in Halong Bay

* Deluxe cabins w/ ensuite bathrooms and air conditioning on traditional Vietnamese style “Junk Boat”

* Explore Bai Tu Long Bay (The largest part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site, most beautiful, off the path, and by far least crowded!) 

* Explore, kayak, and swim among hidden beaches, lagoons, and magical sea caves!

Cambodia (6 Nights):

* Multiple in-room massages to wrap up our bustling days in Cambodia

* Siem Reap! (Guided tour: Great Temples of Anchor, guided temple trail tour through 2,000 years of history! A day of amazing PICTURES!)

*  Free time in Siem Reap to shop, eat, explore town, or head back to the temples!

* Cambodia’s Great Lake (Tonlé Sap Lake ranges in size from 1860 square miles to 4500 square miles every year during the dry and wet seasons! Observe the wonders of rural khmer life where the locals live on the lake, literally (houses on stilts)!

One of a kind village stay!

We will be heading off to the village of Koh Ker. After you wake up to the sounds of the village, witnessing village life in a way you never could from the “highrise” views of a tree house accommodation, you can see what life was like, perhaps two thousand years ago. This is truly a dream come true for photographers, want to be anthropologists, and lovers of native cultures. After a hearty breakfast is served, we will explore the village and meet some of the people. We’ll supply an abundance of school supplies and other necessities before bidding fair well to our new friends (all donations are included in the cost of the tour and handled by the travel club team but we do encourage guests to bring more. Never can have too much!). Before departing this peaceful place we’ll have a special guided tour of temple complexes older than Angkor Wat where very few tourists go! We’ll end up back in Siem Reap at our charming hotel.  You will have an evening to tour the town on your own and taste the local flavors for dinner. A group dinner option will be available! 

 * As always this entire trip will be amazing for photography and one photographer will be on hand to help those who want to learn more about using their camera’s, taking better pictures, etc. (PhotoFly Travel Club adventures are laid back when it comes to photography. They are not workshop style based tours and you do not need to be an avid photographer to join. All are welcome!)

* All transfers & taxes Included

* Domestic Flight Included from Hanoi (Vietnam) to Siem Reap (Cambodia) (HAN–> REP) 

* International Airfare is not included. We are happy to help you find a good flight as always! (Flying into Hanoi International Airport in Vietnam (HAN) on February 18th 2016 and departing from Siem Reap International Airport (REP) in Cambodia on February 28th 2016)

*Don’t forget to e-mail us for the daily itinerary of these Northern Vietnam & Cambodia tours ([masked])

Join Us!

Price: $[masked]

*Single Supplement: $595.00

OR

Deposit: $600.00

Go here to sign up: http://www.photoflytravel.org/northern-vietnam-cambodia-group-tours/

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description:
Have you ever wondered why some people  just ooze sex appeal and charisma?  Would you like to feel more alive and "on fire" in your life?  

At this month's MetroCharles Heartbeat Salon we'll have a fun opportunity to explore the power of Eros energy in our lives. Come join us! 

Our Topic This Evening:

What is EROS?

Eros energy is so much more than sex...

It is your life force, your charisma, your passion; it is energy that you can ride to an expanded state of consciousness.

When cultivated, your Eros energy can help you to:

• Connect more deeply;


• Expand your ability to give and to receive love;

•  Become more magnetic and charismatic;

•  Attract more love and connection;


• Break through your limitations and fears;


• Act from your aligned desire;


• Increase your ability to manifest;


• Increase your capacity to experience pleasure and joy in your day-to-day life;


In this experiential workshop we will begin to explore
 ·  How to sense and follow your Eros energy
·  What happens when you open up to this energy 
·  Techniques to begin to work with this energy in your life

To prepare ....

1) Bring a willingness to experiment
2) Be ready to have some fun!

http://youtu.be/1EWdqyTEGH8


Our Leader This Evening

Trish Blain is an event organizer on the Personal Growth Network, and also the founder and organizer of several meet up groups, including EROS: Exploring Love, Sex and Soul.  A renaissance teacher/leader, her passion and expertise lies in the intersection points of spirituality, sexuality, social entrepreneurship, creativity, and evolutionary consciousness.  

She will be inviting other renaissance souls to join her new venture and living your life "all-in", very soon. The Ollin (pronounced "all-in") Institute will be a gathering place for training, evolutionary community and a platform to create together.

Links

Most Important:

  * Join our Heart Conversation on FaceBook

For Newbies:

results.description:
As you may know, Green Cambridge, Inc. is an environmental advocacy non-profit working to promote sustainability and environmental awareness in Cambridge. We recently finalized our Cambridge 2030 Goals for Environmental Sustainability, which outlines our vision for a future in which we respond appropriately to the growing dangers of climate change and the ongoing destruction of our natural environment.

These goals include creating an efficient and clean energy supply, reducing waste and carbon emissions, conserving important natural systems, and tapping into the innovation economy that makes Cambridge so unique. We want these goals to represent the views and ideas of a diverse set of Cambridge community members - which is why we have incorporated feedback from many community groups who share our desire to see these goals become a reality.

We are now reaching out to the Porter Square Neighborhood Association to ask for your formal endorsement.

Can't make it? We'll be repeating some type of event the third Thursday of every month! Plus, our organizing and planning meetings happen the first Thursday of every month. Also check us out on Facebook, Twitter, and at <a>www.greencambridge.org.</a>
results.name: Green Cambridge 2030 Goals presentation to Porter Square Neighborhood Assn.

results.description:
Consumer electronics is in transition. We are shifting from creating value and defining products using electronics to creating solutions using software. Consider the smartphone: is it a telephone, or is it a gaming unit, a calendar a camera or a television? With other form factors we can mix or match parts to create a desktop computer, a television, a home control system or whatever we can imagine. Many single-use devices and classic limitations no longer exist. The Internet is central to this revolution. It is a byproduct of creating connectivity solutions using any available means. The Internet represents a fundamental change in how we build systems and in what it means to communicate. You simply click on a URL and you're "there". You don't worry about wires or reserved frequency. You can just assume that the packets will appear at the destination most of the time. Using software defined relationships as building blocks is very different from traditional hardware-based engineering. Welcome to the new world of software and the Internet. There's no dependence on providers or networks. For the IEEE these changes present an opportunity and challenge. Devices are becoming connected, opening up new frontiers as we create and share our own solutions and become less dependent on service providers. We're at the very earliest stages of an exciting new world.

Bob Frankston is a Fellow of the IEEE, the ACM and the Computer History Museum. He is on the Board of Governors and is a Distinguished Lecturer for the IEEE Consumer Electronics Society. He writes the Bits Vs. Electrons column in the IEEE/CE Magazine. He has been online since 1966 and was co-developer of the first electronic spreadsheet and has been honored by the IEEE for his contributions to home networking while at Microsoft. He received BS degrees in both Computer Science and Mathematics and Master's and Engineer's degrees in Computer Science and Electrical Engineering all from MIT. Since leaving Microsoft he has been doing angel investing and advising. He is currently working with entrepreneurs and established companies on the issues we face as we transition to a software-defined connected world.

The meeting will be held in the new meeting auditorium at the Verizon Technology Center. The address is 60 Sylvan Road, Waltham, MA 02451. The entrance is by the far corner - with the picnic tables out front - and not the tower or the new building. It is most easily reached by the West Street entrance.

Verizon requires us to provide a list of attendees in advance, so we cannot do registration directly in Meetup.  If you want to come, you need to register at http://Frankstonfeb2016.eventbrite.com, but admission is free.

We will be taking the speaker to dinner at Green Papaya after the talk at about 9pm.

results.name: Using SW Defined Relationships to Build the Internet of Things w Bob Frankston

results.description:
More Welcoming Energy!

Energy is the bridge between mind and body, inside and outside, Self and Source.  Our bodies are designed to perceive energy through our emotions and other body-based sensations. 

Love, happiness, joy, peace and pleasure reflect the healthy flow of energy.  Sadness, fear, anger, emotional pain and suffering are calls for help from the energy body.   They reflect dysfunctional energy patterns such as blocks and reversals.

Blocked energy causes a build up of pressure and "hardening" of the energy.  The harder the energy, the more uncomfortable.  Energy is blocked by thought, habit, and reaction patterns in the energy field.  Blocked energy can be unblocked for healing and renewed receptivity to the juicy, healthy and pleasurable energies of life.

We help energy flow by welcoming, encouraging, supporting and intending our energy to soften, flow, and move in, through, and out of the body. 

This very direct process of gently dissolving, flowing and releasing energy to recover the healthy, natural flow is taught in a system called EmoTrance.  

To learn more, go to <a>www.emotrance.com.</a>   You can sign up with them to receive free downloads.

We will continue to review and practice other important energy self-care techniques to help us all ground, center and align our energies for learning, emotional well-being, health and optimal performance.
results.name: Welcoming Energy - Feeling, Flowing, Healing, Enjoying

results.description:
S</a>CATV's Potluck & Lecture Series presents Boston Open Screen's Organizer Phil Healy on Thursday, February 18th from 7-9pm at SCATV. SCATV's Potluck & Lecture Series presents: How to Launch an Open Mic for Filmmakers with presenter Phil Healy. **SPACE IS LIMITED to about 30 people, RSVP to Erica Jones at [masked] to secure your spot!**

In the spirit of collaboration & community, please join us for our next Potluck and Lecture Series on Thursday, February 18th at 7pm. It is free and open to the general public. We will hear from Phil Healy, organizer of Boston Open Screen, whose goal is to create a safe space for filmmakers to showcase their work. Their mission states, "Open Screen is Boston's one and only open mic night for movies! Whether you sold your home to finance your 35mm masterpiece, or you made it last night in your basement -- if your movie is under 10 minutes, we'll screen it." We love this mission and we support it!

Bring a dish to share if you can. Come on by for the food and filmmaker fellowship. We hope you can make it and please spread the event information to your network!


About Phil Healy: Phil Healy is a Boston based film maker, comedian, and all around no-do-gooder. He's worked on both coasts (Boston, New York, & Los Angeles) on various projects for various companies (MTV Networks, Paramount, Sony, Comedy Central, etc.). His feature length documentary 'My Name Is Jonah' and shorts such as 'Vampire!', 'Accidental Love', and 'Shook' are making their way around the film festival circuit as we speak. Phil co-directed, co-wrote, and co-produced 'My Name Is Jonah' which has already played on 4 continents while on it's film festival run and has been getting great to tepid reviews. You can check out one review from popular cultural website <a href="http://www.bleedingcool.com/2014/06/16/my-name-is-jonah-is-pure-weird-america/">Bleeding Cool News. Phil also has a podcast he does with fellow 'My Name Is Jonah' producer Jon Caron called, 'Sock Talk'. They don't talk about socks. He currently resides in North Reading, MA with his beautiful and thoughtful wife along with their two mischievous wiener dogs. To pay most of his bills, Phil works in Public Access Television teaching community members about video production and how to offend people without really trying as per his online series, 'Video of the Day'.
results.name: How to Launch an Open Mic for Filmmakers with presenter Phil Healy

Cambridge meetup is back! We are going to have this event every other week!


http://www.championscambridge.com/


As usual, please bring your driver's license or passport, if you would like to have alcohol. They are strict about IDs, No IDs no booze.  But people under 21 are welcome as well to this event  - Champions is almost as much a restaurant as a bar and you need not order a drink.


You are responsible for your own consumption and please start and settle your own tab. Please bring your Credit/Debit card or cash and start your tab with the waiter.    Please be sure to tip - we suggest 20% as it is a lot of extra trouble for them to do separate tabs, but it saves us work and allows people to leave at different times.  But first be sure that the tip is not included already - it usually is not but occasionally is, at 18%, if there is a large group, in which case you need not tip additional.  (If you know the price of what you ordered, and add 7% MA meals tax, and that is the total, they have NOT added in the tip.)

RSVP required. Please sign up. If you RSVP "Yes," but your plans change, please change your RSVP to "No" so others can sign up. Deadline for reservation is 3PM as we need to get an accurate head count for the reservation. On nights when we are expecting many people, we limit the RSVP number to 27. However, if you'd like to attend, but can't RSVP, send a message to an organizer, as we may be able to get you in.


Champions is located at MIT/Kendall Sq. station. If you come from Boston side, you will see right in front of the T exit. It is part of the Marriott. Even though the address is listed as 50 Broadway, you can really only see it from the Main street side.  We are usually either in the separate room toward the Marriott lobby, or else at two long central tables in the room to the right of the host station.

results.description:
Come join us over fab food and drinks at PRECINCT KITCHEN as we discuss The Storied Life of A.J. Fikry, by Gabrielle Zevin! Here's a description:


"In this sweet, uplifting homage to bookstores, Zevin perfectly captures the joy of connecting people and books. A. J. Fikry, the cantankerous owner of Island Books, is despondent after losing his beloved wife and witnessing the ever-declining number of sales at his small, quirky bookstore. In short order, he loses all patience with the new Knightly Press sales rep, his prized rare edition of Tamerlane is stolen, and someone leaves a baby at his store. That baby immediately steals A. J.’s heart and unleashes a dramatic transformation. Suddenly, the picture-book section is overflowing with new titles, and the bookstore becomes home to a burgeoning number of book clubs. With business on the uptick and love in his heart, A. J. finds himself becoming an essential new part of his longtime community, going so far as to woo the aforementioned sales rep (who loves drinking Queequeg cocktails at the Pequod Restaurant). Filled with interesting characters, a deep knowledge of bookselling, wonderful critiques of classic titles, and very funny depictions of book clubs and author events, this will prove irresistible to book lovers everywhere." --Joanne Wilkinson


Hope to see you there--it sounds like a great book club book!

Diane

venue.name: Phillips Auditorium, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

results.description:
Events for the Public

The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics sponsors a variety of free programs for the public. Among these events are Observatory Nights held on the third Thursday of the month (excluding June, July and August). Observatory Nights feature a nontechnical lecture and telescopic observing from the observatory roof if weather permits. The lectures are intended for high-school age and older audiences but children are also welcome. We also sponsor a variety of other special astronomical events throughout the year. No reservations are necessary, but seating is limited to the auditorium's capacity. Admission is free.

These events--unless otherwise noted--are held in Phillips Auditorium (at the rear of the CfA complex near Madison Street and large parking lot), 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, about 1 mile west of Harvard Square. Parking lots marked for Observatory Staff are open to the public on event nights. Parking is free.

The Observatory does not host private events.

Monthly Observatory Night
Thursday, February 18, 2016
7:30 pm: Big Data to Big Art


Henry "Trae" Winter, CfA


We currently live in the Information Age, where terms like "Big Data" and the "Internet of Things" are ingrained into the public consciousness. This massive compilation of data is useless without tools to aid us in comprehending what the numbers mean. These tools are almost always visual in nature and creating them requires not only a knowledge of math and science, but also an understanding of how human beings interpret and interact with the world around them. We will explore a few large datasets and the tools developed to visualize them, and see that the boundaries between art and science are very often blurred.

For more information, including accessibility, or to sign up for the events mailing list, call the Public Affairs Office, (617)[masked] or email [masked]. Please request sign-language interpretation at least 2 weeks before the event. Current sky information is available.

Entrance is at the west of the CfA complex, near Madison Street and large parking lot. The CfA is easily reached by public transportation. From the Harvard MBTA Station (Red Line), take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses, Huron Avenue trolleys) and get off at "Observatory Hill."

Source(s): http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/publicevents

Also available via their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ObsNights
results.name: Big Data to Big Art - Monthly Observatory Night

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
Roast Battle returns to The Davis Square Theatre.
255 Elm st. Somerville, MA

The Boston Comedy Festival
in association with
Shaun Bedgood and Matt Kona present...
Roast Battle Boston III
Anthony Scibelli vs Kate Procyshyn
Kayla Avery vs Woody Wood
Spanky Fournier vs Terence Pennington
Anthony Costa vs Jason Cordova
Ian Barton vs Tim Sturtevant
Sounds by KeyJ McGee of The Van Burens
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/roast-battle-boston-tickets-20998091858 for tickets

Roast Battle began at The Comedy Store in Los Angeles by co-creators Brian Moses and Rell Battle and has expanded to comedy festivals and new venues around the country.
It's a no holds barred display of verbal violence. Comedians go at each other one at a time, for three rounds with guest judges deciding who is the victor. It's been packing The Belly Room in LA on a weekly basis since 2013 and for the last few months at New York Comedy Club. After a successful debut in November at The Boston Comedy Festival and a jammed show in January, Roast Battle Returns once again to Davis Square for a truly unique one night only spectacle.

"You win Roast Battle by preparing. The comedians have worked as much as two weeks on it, getting to know your opponent, researching them, sizing them up. Roasting is writing. Usually the best writers win Roast Battle. It's kind of like boxing -- if you train hard, you win. Roast Battle is like Fight Club for comedians, it's like Bloodsport. If you like your comedy raw and uncensored, Roast Battle is for you."
-Jeff Ross, author of "I Only Roast the Ones I Love: How to Bust Balls Without Burning Bridges."

"Roast Battle is comedy at it's most immediate -- a fight-night for comics where the only real rule is to be ruthless. Other than that, anything goes."
-The Village Voice

"Thick skin is recommended."
-TimeOut New York

"The biggest can't miss show in comedy. The ultimate "you had to be there" experience."
-The Interrobang

Challenge Group #3!

SUBJECTS 08-10

08: Landscape: Wide Angle/Panorama
Explore panorama stitching and create a wide sweeping landscape.


09: Artistic: Shadows
The opposite of light is dark, the absence of light is shadow. Interpret this into a shadowy masterpiece.


10: Portrait: Environmental
Show a subject in their natural habitat. Their place of work or hobby is a great start. Tell their story with the environment

*** Upload 1 or 2 images per subject max.
*** Please try to Caption your work.
*** Please make constructive, appreciative comments on a minimum of 2 other images for every image you post.

results.description:
How to Work a Room with Better Networking Skills at North Shore Business Forum’s Meeting on Friday, February 19, 2016

                             Charlene St. Jean, Owner, Purple Diamond LLC

Do you cringe at the thought of stepping into a room full of strangers at a party or business event? Are you frustrated at attending one networking event after another with little to no results for all your efforts? Would you like to be equipped with a plan, conversation points and some basic techniques so that you feel more comfortable in a crowd and learn how to convert contacts to clients?

Featured speaker Charlene St. Jean, owner of Beverly, MA-based Purple Diamond LLC, will present “How to Work a Room—Networking 101,” offering insights on the best way to make a memorable impression on people you meet and teaching you how to utilize your time at a business event more effectively. [Please note: Charlene was our scheduled speaker for February 5, but we cancelled the meeting for a snow day, so she has graciously agreed to present her talk on February 19.]

About the Speaker: Charlene St. Jean is the owner of Purple Diamond LLC, a Beverly, MA-based advertising agency and marketing coaching company that coaches small to mid-size companies on affordable and effective ways to market and advertise their business. Before starting her own agency in March 2008, Charlene achieved senior account executive status selling television commercial campaigns in the Boston and New England market and received numerous awards for achievement in her field. Through her marketing business, Charlene has contributed significantly to the growth of over 100 companies on the North Shore. Her enthusiasm for the services she offers and her abilities to connect with other business owners at events have been instrumental in her company’s success. From wearing her signature color purple to using simple techniques as she works a room, Charlene understands how to leave a lasting impression and coaches her clients to do the same!

For businesses that struggle with social media marketing, Charlene offers training, strategy sessions, and competitive packages for managing social channels. Charlene’s company was nominated for Beverly’s Small Business of the Year in 2012, and won the 2014 Greater Beverly Chamber Business Award for Sole Proprietor of the Year. Charlene currently serves on the Executive Board of Directors of the Greater Beverly Chamber of Commerce, was a past Board Member of the North Shore Business Forum, and a member of the Economic Community Development Committee for the City of Beverly. For more information, contact Charlene at [masked], or visit http://www.purplediamondmarketing.com.

The North Shore Business Forum, Inc. (NSBF) is a group of small business owners from Boston’s North Shore who meet on the first and third Friday of each month for informal lectures given by business owners on a wide variety of topics. Members give a 30-second introduction of their business at each meeting. All business owners are welcome: future, past, profitable, experienced or beginning. Meetings are from 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. (registration starts at 7:15) at Acapulcos, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. The $10.00 admission fee includes a breakfast buffet. No pre-registration necessary.

Contact: Brett Kirkpatrick, NSBF President,[masked], Email: [masked].

**  WEATHER-RELATED CANCELLATIONS  **
If the Beverly, MA public school system announces a “no school” snow day on one of our scheduled Fridays, then the NSBF meeting for that day will be cancelled. Check the NSBF Facebook page for updates as well. (See our “About NSBF” page for more information.)

Note:  Pose will be the same as the Saturday 4-hour sessions, so if you want to get a REALLY long pose, sign up for both.  Model is Nathalie.

Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.  

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Four hours each Friday morning, 10:00- 2:00pm. You can come individual days by paying $20 (members) or $30 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
Where:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/mrdnil6b7bd2rel4v3rmnxqn5ia

Long-established concepts of multi-stakeholder, hybrid, or solidarity cooperatives are getting new urgency and vitality from the Platform Cooperativism movement which calls for an Internet of Ownership. It is a vision for online platforms that share democratic ownership and governance with their stakeholders, especially those who contribute their labor and personal data. Millions of people rely on a social network for communication and a relatively small number of people build the platform.
How does Platform Cooperativism affect you? What other movements does it intersect with?

Please come with your thoughts and questions for a roundtable discussion. I will share what I have learned from coordinators and players in this new space, but the space is very new in a lot of ways and you should be part of defining it! Learn about some global, national and local efforts in this movement too!


http://platformcoop.net (videos)
http://internetofownership.net (directory)

There is also a local meetup planned in Cambridge, MA on Monday - 2/15
http://www.meetup.com/agaric/events/228640449/
results.name: Virtual Meetup - Platform Cooperativism and You, Building Tools for the Future

results.description:
Do you want OTHER people to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in McCormack Senior Center.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery in North Andover - often from other sites, also).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely from this meetup or others: Craigslist, EventBrite, local schools - colleges, graduate and professional schools, academies, training programs, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in South Boston

McCormack Task Force
345 Old Colony Ave.
Next to St. Monica's Church
(Near Andrew Red Line)
Inside Task Force building 
Fridays 2:30 - 3:30 PM (Show up by 2 pm for setup)

Each Friday, from 2:00 - 4:00 pm

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Friday midafternoon $2/bag of produce at McCormack Senior Center in mSouth jBoston.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 2 pm (maybe as late as 2:30 pm) and work until 4 pm (can leave as early as 3:30 pm if we've finished).

http://www.buzzfile.com/Home/Map?m=7790814

Near Columbia Road, Andrew Red Line stop - about 7 minutes walk, 0.3 miles

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 

Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Please e-mail organizer with your e-mail address and cellphone (in case we need to converse about this more, or contact you before the event).

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 

TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!! 

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.  

TALK with us FIRST !! 

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas 

Vegan Cooking Classes or 
                 Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food 
                    (using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 

* What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag? 
* Portion Control 
* Bake...Don't Fry! 
* Roasted Veggie Stackers 
* No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream 
* Avocados!!! 
* Salad with Chipotle Hummus 
* Simple Cilantro Chutney 
* More $2 bags of Produce! 
* Drink your greens!

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
No qualifications - no limits
We have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.
Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
The last several months we've been on a quest to find a new venue for Meet and Greet One More Time.  We've been concentrating on the Newton Center area since it's on the T for our public transit folks and centrally located with lots of available parking for those of us driving.  We've been looking for the right balance of ambiance and good food/drinks, reasonably priced.

I think we found it!  The Deluxe Station Diner.  It's located in the old train station building that's right at the Newton Center T stop.  It has a very comfortable feel to it; warm and friendly.  We sit at the bar if we have a small group.  We grab a table  for a larger group.

They have a number of interesting specialty drinks.  I have tried the Blueberry Lemonade and the Apple Pie.  Believe it or not, those are both vodka drinks.  They were both very good and reasonably priced.  The kind of drinks that you need to be careful with because it's easy to forget there's alcohol in them.

I'd classify the food as "comfort food".  We've had the burgers, mac & cheese, curried chicken, meatloaf, chicken pot pie, and fish & chips.  Everything has tasted great and was reasonably priced.

Several large municipal parking lots are nearby. Meters are free after 6:00 pm.

MBTA: Green Line, “D” train, Newton Center stop. When you come up the stairs from the train tracks, you are on Union Street. The diner is inside the old brownstone Union Station.

Bus #52 from Watertown Square (www.mbta.com for schedule and exact route).

Driving:

From the Mass Pike (east-bound):
Take exit 17 and make your first right after the set of lights, onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From the Mass Pike (west-bound):
Take exit 17 and go straight off the ramp. After the ramp, you will go through two sets of lights. After the second set, turn left at the sign that says "Newton Centre/Boston." You will be making a 180-degree turn and should stay in the right lane. Take your first right after the 180-degree turn onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From Route 9:
Take the Newton Center/Centre Street Exit. Follow Centre Street until you reach Beacon Street. Take a right onto Beacon Street and park in the parking lot on your left or on Beacon Street.

results.description:
I had to cover a lot... so please read all the text below.

Here's a video to get you started. Don't let the length intimidate you. Just focus on the first few minutes but do as much as you like.


http://youtu.be/aV8dS2m9Adc

I'm really excited about this event. I've been working on this for a few months... 2 Hanson Rec Commission meetings later, increasing my liability insurance, signing my life away in a contract, approval from the town administrator and what seems to be 50 trips to this place. I have permission for us to do a series of Beginner Salsa Lessons. (swing lessons to follow if this is a success) I'll post 2 to start so please help me make these a success by giving it a shot. You'll have a blast trust me!


Our instructors have years of dancing experience, plenty of personality and of course I'll be providing the sound system with some great music. I've taken group lessons before and the music was too fast, esp in the open dance time. So we're going to gear this to 2 left footed neanderthal dancers like me.


The Hanson Rec Commission members are very excited about this and want us to succeed. So thank them when you see them at the event.


Our plan is to have weekly dances for 2 hours. The first hour will be a lesson and the 2nd an open dance. These will be geared for beginners so don't be afraid. To You Salsa veterans - please come because we'll need your help too... and you can show off during the open dance hour.


Once per month we'll be having a bartender for a 4 hour dance. A little wine might loosen up the hips a little ;-) This first dance will be for 2 hours. The 2nd dance lesson on Feb 26th will have the bar and be open for 4 hours. (7-11 see the post for the 26th)


Gender equity? of course ladies bring a man with you but for the first few lessons gender equity won't be a huge issue. Nevertheless, put the pressure on the men you know, in the group and out, to make it to this. It's gonna be a blast !

Please post questions below.

DIRECTIONS - Please use your GPS. For those of you who have never been, Hanson is only 30 min from Plymouth and Braintree. And only 15 min from Hanover or Brockton. See it's nice and centrally located. Camp Kiwannee is right on rt 58 with plenty of parking.

The cost is $10 per person - a very reasonable price. FYI - I don't make a dime on this. Camp Kiwanee gets a percentage of the door and the remainder goes to the instructors and those working the door.


Here's a few pictures of Needles Lodge at Camp Kiwanee. It's a gem right here in our little one-horse town of Hanson.

That's only about 2/3rds of the room. They were rehearsing a play in the other third. I'll get better pictures up there soon. But you get the idea.

the entrance... love this place... Old world charm...

results.description:
Come and join us for an evening of fun and shared energy. How often do we get an opportunity to be real with each other in Boston?

At TurnON, we play three communication games (just talking, no touching), and you can participate at whatever level feels good to you. Imagine meeting new people in an environment where they feel comfortable to express themselves and challenge the edges of their comfort zones; a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation. That's what we have created.

TurnON events give you the opportunity to look deeper into yourself, through other people putting quality attention on you, asking questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening - really listening – to your responses. What comes up might surprise you!

It's amazing how connected we can end up feeling - even in a room full of strangers - when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston.

TurnON Boston is an organization that teaches Orgasmic Meditation, otherwise known as OM. The games we play at TurnON events are designed to create the visceral sensation of Orgasm/OM in your body, without actually doing the practice. At the end of the evening, we will give you a brief description of the practice of OM and information on how to learn more.

$10, payable at the door.

Please note the slightly different time from usual, and plan to arrive on time (7:00) - we will lock the door promptly at 7:10!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square.


 http://tedxtalks.ted.com/video/TEDxSF-Nicole-Daedone-Orgasm--2
results.how_to_find_us: Entrance is on the corner of Cedar and Dudley Streets.
results.name: TurnON Boston
