results.description:
This evening we’ll experientially explore the grand question of “Who am I?”. Are you just a small, limited, physical being separate from everyone and everything else?

It’s so easy to slip into feeling that way, regardless of your beliefs, isn’t it?

Through a combination of instruction, discussion and easy guided meditations, Ann will help you to connect to your sense of Spirit, to feel like you’re “so much more”, and to open you up to delightful new possibilities.

You’ll leave feeling fully relaxed, fully loved, and with an expanded sense of who you are and what you’re capable of.

To encourage and support your practice and our community, if you pay for 4 guided meditation sessions, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check), to be used within 4 months of your payment.  You can also choose to pay for one class at a time for $20. These fees help to cover all of my costs and the significant time I put into running and preparing for all of the events and the meetup itself. Thank you! Please RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner. Feel free to invite family and friends, too!

End time is approximate, as we often run over-time, and I welcome some "hang out and chat" time before leaving.


Here's the basic description and format for all of our guided meditation sessions, with a more specific focus/theme each time we meet, as well.  Of course, you do not have to commit to attending every time, however, the more you attend, the more you will benefit; and the better we'll get to know each other!

Guided Meditations for Experiencing Greater Inner Peace, Love, Ease and JOY!

Are you aware of the many benefits of meditating, but can’t get yourself to do it, or it’s too difficult to do on your own?

Do you enjoy the collective energy and ease of guided group meditations?

Meditation can be one of the easiest and most effective means to living with greater harmony, happiness and well-being. It’s also an opportunity to peacefully transform your problems, your fears, and any pain and stress in your life into something more positive.

I also consider meditating one of the most direct and easiest ways to connect to your greater Spirit-Self, and to access all that it has to offer you.

By participating in these transformational group guided meditations, you’ll experience how simple,delightful and easy it can be. You’ll learn and practice:

• Simple yet profound techniques you can easily do for yourself for any length of time that is comfortable for you.

• How to easily get into a meditative state to deeply relax and to create positive, pleasurable feelings, including inner peace, love, ease and joy; and how to bring that into your daily living.

• Techniques to help you release stress and anxiety, and to shift your perspective and experience of those issues to a more positive perspective, instead.

• How to connect to your inner resources and your best self, to solution consciousness, and how to activate your body's natural healing response.

We have a different theme each time we meet to help you build and reinforce positive thinking patterns, beliefs and inner narratives that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy.

We typically have 2-3 guided meditations, with discussion and instruction in between to help you carry the positive feelings and lessons experienced into your day and life.

This is a perfect time to let go of stress and "busy-ness", and to fully let go and relax into bliss. Come with whatever intentions suit you, and the evening is still sure to satisfy. It always works out magically that way.

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class.

To encourage and support your practice, if you pay for 4 sessions, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check), to be used within 4 months of your payment.  Or, you can pay for one class at a time for $20.  Just RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner.

“I'm leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, full of love, and excited about bringing more spirit into everything I do. I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned tonight will help me very much. Thank you!!! "

"Great meditations! I had a marvelous experience with each of them and a lot to take with me: powerful imagery, good feelings, and new techniques for connecting myself with the Universe. Loved the “love ripple”!”

"I truly value our time together. I tried two other guided meditation classes with other instructors, and I enjoy your classes the most. Why? Because you give us time to reflect, journal and share. It really helps to deepen my experience and expand my perspective. And honestly, I relate more to your meditations and love the sound of your voice. Your guided meditations are like group therapy for the soul."

Class leader (and meetup organizer): Ann Ide, M.A., has been leading guided meditation classes for years, and is also a certified master practitioner in Neuro-linguistic Programming and Hypnotherapy, and certified NLP Life Coach. Ann coaches people to move beyond their personal struggles, to new levels of harmony, happiness and success. With her expert questioning, inner exploration processes and personal change interventions, clients become able to more easily create the happiness they desire.

results.description:
Two and a half hours of piano karaoke at The Green Room --- a wonderfully intimate venue in the heart of Union Square, Somerville.

LEMONS INTO LEMONADE:

As some of you know, the Green Room inadvertently double-booked us for our January session. Due to a wonderful classical piano concert scheduled during our regular time slot, unfortunately, we were unable to utilize the space. Elise was unaware of the problem until half an hour before start time.

The Green Room has graciously waived our entire rental fee for the next month, so we will be asking for a $1 donation for our February session --- just enough to defray the cost of Elise's Piano Karaoke website fee, SoundCloud fee, etc.
THANK YOU for hanging with us through January's confusion!


Much more info here:

http://www.pianokaraoke.net

and

FAQ page

COST: $5+ requested donation at the door (to defray venue rental, piano tuning fees, Meetup organizer fees, etc.)

NOTE: The exterior door of The Green Room is a little tricky --- lift the handle UP instead of pulling it down!

PARKING: metered parking is available in the neighborhood. It's also OK to park in non-metered spots on residential streets if you do so for two hours or less. We've noted one ticket so far, so if you're staying longer than two hours, please plan on shifting your car's parking space before two hours go by.

results.description:
Organizer: Steve Blum [masked]


=========================

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event. Sometimes the questions won't show up if you use a phone or tablet to RSVP so use a computer. 

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself as well as others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate. Contact me if you have any questions. 

=========================

What We're Doing...

The plan is to climb two of the NH 4,000 Footers -  Mt. Eisenhower (#11 @ 4,780'), and Mt. Pierce (#27 @ 4310') This is a plan that has been modified due to expected high winds at 5000ft.


We will achieve the summit of Mt. Pierce via the Crawford Path.  At this summit, we will determine if conditions are safe enough to continue along Crawford Path to Mt. Eisenhower and return the same way we came to our vehicles. (10.2 miles)  If winds are excessive in my determination, we will proceed to Mt. Jackson via the Webster-Cliff Trail, then descend to our awaiting vehicles via the Webster-Jackson Trail. (8.3 miles)


Since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety you will need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards. Use this link for more information about the summits and trails:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/4-Mt-Monroe-5384--11-Mt-Eisenhower-4780--27-Mt-Pierce


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

•http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.34041990304885&lat=44.24189911060989#.VsclTOa2GSo

Guests are not permitted - all participants must be members of the group.


Dogs are not permitted

Trip Summary...

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10 miles and climb about 3,900 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours 15 minutes to complete this trip. This event is considered to be ADVANCED because of the terrain, pace, distance, and elevation gain.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

What to Bring...

REQUIRED WINTER GEAR: 
Light traction: Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound trail crampons. Knockoff brands are totally unacceptable. Dull spikes are unacceptable!
Mountaineering snowshoes: Tubbs Flex ALP, Flex VRT, Flex TRK, or Mountaineers; MSR Lightening, Revo, or Evo; TSL Symbioz Elite or Expert; Atlas Aspect, Endeavor, or Series 10/11/12 
Mountaineering crampons:  10-12 point crampons with prominent front points--be sure they FIT your boots in advance! 
Insulated, winter, waterproof hiking boots. Trail runners and summer boots are unacceptable. Hard plastic mountaineering boots are not such a good idea (I'll only accept plastic mountaineering boots if you routinely hike and snowshoe up to 15 miles with them and are comfortable doing so). 
Clothing: NO COTTON CLOTHING WHATSOEVER.  Full rain shell, heavy insulated mittens, gaiters, gloves, face mask, balaclava, goggles, winter hat, plenty of warm synthetic and/or wool layers for top and bottom. 
Emergency/Safety/Other: 2 headlamps with spare lithium batteries. Sleeping bag and emergency bivy or space blanket. Insulated ground pad. 1st aid kit. Insulated water bottles (or wrap your bottle(s) in a heavy sock). 
Food: Enough food and water for the duration of the trip.
More info on winter gear: http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Directions...


We will meet at the AMC Highland Center, Rt. 302, Bretton Woods, NH.


Use this link for customizable driving directions; merely insert your starting location to replace the Boston start.


https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Boston,+MA/AMC+Highland+Center+at+Crawford+Notch,+Carroll,+NH/@43.3122308,-72.3608855,8z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m13!4m12!1m5!1m1!1s0x89e3652d0d3d311b:0x787cbf240162e8a0!2m2!1d-71....


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls). At the leaders discretion, this hike will be canceled, or modified, by noon on Friday, Feb. 19th in the event of inclement weather or otherwise poor hiking conditions.


Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

results.description:
As of the morning of February 4th, this event reached full capacity. To anyone who RSVPed after this time, we are thankful for your interest, but we have no more space. We will definitely be having events like this one in the near future. Stay tuned! 


We're hoping that you are already building a team for our upcoming Flicks4Chicks short film contest which launches for sign-ups on February 14th.  One of our fantastic sponsors Talamas has offered to hold a FREE camera and lighting workshop on Saturday, February 20th.


It's well-known that camerawork and lighting are powerful tools in storytelling that can change the audience's mood and perception of a scene. So if you'd like to learn how to use those tools to your advantage, you're going to want to attend this event!

This workshop will be led by Michael Duca and Lisa Sene of Talamas Sales and Rentals. During the workshop, they will discuss how elements such as camerawork and lighting can be used effectively in storytelling in production. 

Example scenes will be screened and deconstructed visually, explaining not only how those results were achieved, but also why those choices were made with the overall story in mind. Audience members will have the opportunity to set up and shoot a practical scene to apply what they learn right away.

Michael Duca is a graduate of the New England Institute of Art and began working in the industry at 16. He started working at Talamas as an intern, and is now the lead technician in the video department. He is well respected for his immense technical ability, understanding of workflow, ergonomic gear design and usage, lighting technique, and experience in the field.

Lisa Sene is a steadicam operator who yes, really will run around with that heavy camera strapped to her! Lisa has kept it steady on productions all over the country, and looks forward to the new challenges that come with every project. Her favorite part about being a steadicam op is being able to directly participate in the creative side of production. She holds a BA in Cinematography from Emerson College, and has a strong background in theatrical lighting, both of which contribute to her understanding of visual storytelling.

The workshop will run from 9:00AM to 3:00PM and a light lunch will be provided. 


Please also RSVP to Talamas directly: http://www.talamas.com/events/dont-move-camera-move-story

We hope to see you there!


ALSO stay tuned for Talamas's second workshop on Audio for Film and Video with Sennheiser's Dave Missall, March 24th 7:00 - 9:00PM.
results.how_to_find_us: 149 California Street
results.name: Don't Move the Camera, Move the Story!

http://harvardxdesign16.com/#failurexdesign

We would like to invite you to the fourth annual HarvardxDesign conference hosted by students groups from the Harvard Graduate School of Design xDesign Club, Springboard: Harvard College's Design Club, the Harvard Business School Design Club. The conference will be held at the Harvard GSD on February 20th.

This year's theme is "FailurexDesign" and will focus on the necessity and sometimes inevitability of failure in the design process. Creative leaders in tech, branding, graphic design, e-commerce, and design entrepreneurship will be speaking on how to overcome obstacles, how to recognize productive failure, and how to avoid pitfalls at crucial points in the design process. Come hear PepsiCo, IDEO, Etsy, and other exciting design leaders share their candid experiences with failure in the design process.

Also join Shana Dressler and Marianne Aerni of 30 weeks for an additional afternoon workshop the following Sunday, February 21st. 30 weeks is a design founders program that equips designers with the necessary entrepreneurial skills and knowledge base to start impactful companies. 60 students will be able to join Shana and Marianne at the GSD for a workshop on IDEATION and VALIDATION: finding ideas to be passionate about and identifying ideas that are prone to failure.

Cape Ann in Winter
What would motivate you to bird the coast on a cold winter day? How about the possibility of seeing alcids, white-winged gulls, and lots of ocean ducks, loons, and grebes? We will visit a number of birding hot spots along the Cape Ann coast to observe the many species that call this area their winter home. Please dress in warm layers and bring lunch, water and snacks. We will be driving from location to location (minimum walking). If you would like to carpool, please post your willingness to drive or need for a ride to the Arlington Birds list. Meet at the Fisherman's Statue in Gloucester at 9AM. The approximate ending time is 1PM (depending on weather conditions and numbers of birds). Directions: Follow Route 128 north to Exit 14 - Route 133 - Gloucester. Turn right and follow Route 133 for about 3 miles to the stop sign at Western Avenue. Turn left onto Western Avenue, cross the drawbridge and look for the Fisherman's Statue on your right. Jim Guion

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

results.description:
Boston is a great city to walk anytime. In addition to the rich history, you are never far from a good shop, restaurant, tavern, or restroom. February is good because the days are short, the weather is cold and unpredictable, and you have a need to get out and do something a little more active.


This adventure starts with a 90 minute guided tour on the Freedom Trail to Faneuil Hall.

Around Faneuil Hall after the tour, we can visit Haymarket, have some light refreshments, poke around the shops, or watch a street performance.   After that we may head over to the USS Constitution by water for the 30 minute tour of Old Ironsides. 

The Freedom Trail Tour departs at 11 a.m. sharp from the Visitor Information Center, Boston Common, 139 Tremont St.  Tickets may be purchased online or at the Visitor’s Center.  To purchase a public tour ticket online ($12.00) please click here.

Suggested Parking:  Boston Common Garage, 44 Charles St., Boston ($18).  Contact me via meetup if you are interested in car pooling with us.

Click here for maps, directions, and parking information

Frequently Asked Questions

I am planning on taking the 1:58 pm ferry boat from Long Wharf Boston to the USS Constitution  ($3.25 a ride).  Great view of Boston from the water!  After the 30 min free tour of the ship, we’ll return on the 3:11 pm ferry. Bring a valid state or federal-issued id to board the USS Constitution.


If you decide to hang out at Faneuil Hall, head over to Hilton’s Tent City camping store, or otherwise disengage, that’s fine.  You are welcome to join up again for the dinner option. 

Dinner option in the North End:   L’Osteria 104 Salem St. (or as group decides)


Total walking distance about 5 miles. Wear good walking shoes and dress for the weather, rain or shine.  A back pack will come in handy if you buy some groceries at Haymarket.

Emerson “Tad” Baker is Professor of History at Salem State University, and the award-winning author of many works on the history of early New England. He will discuss his recent book which sets the Salem Witch Trials in the broader context of American history from the seventeenth century to the present, and examines their enduring legacy. The talk will include a discussion of some of the many genealogical connections the author encountered in researching the book.

This event is being presented by the Essex County Genealogical Society.  They are planning a brown bag lunch at noon, and invite us to join them for that.  They have a brief business meeting, then the lecture happens.  They're a wonderful resource if you're interested in researching your family tree.


I've never been to this venue.  Let's plan to meet inside.  The event is free!

results.description:
Hi Urban Sketchers of Boston - let's sketch the Boston Public Library!

Meet in lobby at Dartmouth St. entrance at 12:45pm.  We'll disperse at 1pm, sketch for 2 hours, then meet back at 3pm to share out work.

About the site we will be sketching on Saturday:

According to its website, the Boston Public Library has a collection of over 23.7 million materials, which makes it one of the largest municipal public library systems in the United States. With 9,090,261 volumes The Boston Public library is the second largest library in the USA followed by The Harvard academic Library (not public) with 16,832,952 volumes. Both in the state of Massachusetts.


Tha Architect


The McKim Building (built 1895) in Copley contains the library's research collection, exhibition rooms and administrative offices. When it opened in 1895, the new Boston Public Library was proclaimed a "palace for the people." The building includes lavish decorations, a children's room (the first in the nation), and a central courtyard surrounded by an arcaded gallery in the manner of a Renaissance  cloister The library regularly displays its rare works, often in exhibits that will combine works on paper, rare books, and works of art. Several galleries in the third floor of the McKim building are maintained for exhibits.


The History


In the mid-19th century, several people were instrumental in the establishment of the Boston Public Library. George Ticknor, a Harvard professor and trustee of the Boston Athenaeum, raised the possibility of establishing a public library in Boston beginning as early as 1826. At the time, Ticknor could not generate enough interest.

In 1839, Alexandre Vattemare, a Frenchman, suggested that all of Boston's libraries combine themselves into one institution for the benefit of the public The idea was presented to many Boston libraries, however, most were uninterested in the idea. At Vattemare's urging, Paris sent gifts of books in 1843 and 1847 to assist in establishing a unified public library. Vattemare made yet another gift of books in 1849.
Josiah Quincy, Jr. anonymously donated $5,000 to begin the funding of a new library. Quincy made the donation while he was mayor of Boston. Indirectly, John Jacob Astor also influenced the establishment of a public library in Boston. At the time of his death, Astor bequeathed $400,000 to New York to establish a public library there. Because of the cultural and economic rivalry between Boston and New York, this bequest prompted more discussion of establishing a public library in Boston. In 1848, a statute of the Great and General Court of Massachusetts enabled the creation of the library. The library was officially established in Boston by a city ordinance in 1852. Mayor Benjamin Seaver recommended to the city council that a librarian be appointed. In May 1852 the city council adopted the recommendations of the mayor and Edward Capen was chosen to become Boston Public Library first librarian.

Eager to support the library, Edward Everett collected documents from both houses of Congress, bound them at his own expense, and offered this collection to help establish the new library. At the time of Everett's donation, George Ticknor became involved in the active planning for the new library. In 1852, financier Joshua Bates gave a gift of $50,000 to establish a library in Boston. After Bates' gift was received, Ticknor made lists of what books to purchase. He traveled extensively to purchase books for the library, visit other libraries, and set up book agencies.

To house the collection, a former schoolhouse located on Mason Street was selected as the library's first home. On March 20, 1854, the Reading Room of the Boston Public Library officially opened to the public.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the lobby at the entrance at Dartmouth St. at 12:45pm
results.name: Let's Sketch the Boston Public Library!

results.description:
Imitation of Life is a 1959 film starring Lana Turner, Sandra Dee, Dan O'Herlihy, Susan Kohner, Robert Alda and Juanita Moore. When they first meet, Lora Meredith and Annie Johnson have a good deal in common. They are both single mothers struggling to make a life for themselves and their daughters, Susie and Sarah Jane. Lora is an aspiring model and actress who needs someone to look after Susie when she goes out on photo shoots or casting calls. Annie is an African-American who desperately wants a healthy home environment in which to raise her daughter. As Lora's career blossoms, she spends less and less time with Susie. While Annie is devoted to her daughter and would do anything for her, the fair-skinned Sara Jane is resentful of the racial bias around her and does everything to hide her origins.

This program is sponsored by the Friends of the Thomas Crane Public Library.
results.name: Classic Film Series: Imitation of Life (1959)

results.description:
We're doing a fun 10-week training program! All levels are welcome, and you don't need to be able to make it every week. In week 1, we timed ourselves in a few key events (e.g. 100 freestyle), and now we're doing a training program to get ourselves faster. At the end of 10 weeks we'll time ourselves again and see how much we've improved! If you can't make a week, don't worry, you can still come to the other weeks.


The 10 weeks will include clinics on technique, flip turns, and any special requests, as well as some good sets to get us swimming faster. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.


---------------


The pool opens at 2pm, so we meet to go in at 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

Bruce Vega and Alex Rhalimi will present how energy deregulation is the and what that means for ecologically-informed visions of human life on the planet.

Warren Buffett and Bill Gates each has said that energy deregulation is the biggest transfer of wealth in the history of business, and it's ongoing (from The Motley Fool).

Learn about direct carbon reduction (vs. offsets) and sustainability impacts.


When you arrive, ask to speak with Maynard Clark. Mention that you're from this meetup.  Say specifically that you're there to enjoy the discussion on "Are Solar and Wind Energy going to supplant 'dirty fuels'???"

Thursday evening discussions with community forming.
Discussions and Q&A will follow each presentation.

results.description:
HEEC Presents a screening of "This Changes Everything"
with Discussion to Follow 

What if confronting the climate crisis is the best chance we’ll ever get to build a better world?

Filmed over 211 shoot days in nine countries and five continents over four years, This Changes Everything is an epic attempt to re-imagine the vast challenge of climate change.

Directed by Avi Lewis, and inspired by Naomi Klein’s international non-fiction bestseller This Changes Everything, the film presents seven powerful portraits of communities on the front lines, from Montana’s Powder River Basin to the Alberta Tar Sands, from the coast of South India to Beijing and beyond.

Join the Harvard Environmental Action Committee and the Harvard Extension Environmental Club for a screening of this incredible film.

Free and open to the public! Snacks will be served.

Harvard University ~ Sever Hall Room 113

Link to the film trailer:

results.description:
Art PLUS M & M a win- win! Co posted to the mega group calling itself Social Fun.  68 total signups between the two groups so far.

..."9"? It's our ninth event there! Always a sensation.

On this tour you're advised to stay with the group because there is so much more to see!!!

CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets (free for Cambridge residents with Drivers License proof, otherwise $15), meet & greet then at 2:45 we're OFF!    
  FOLLOWING THIS WE HEAD ACROSS HARVARD YARD TO FELIPE'S FOR REFRESHMENTS IN HARVARD SQUARE AT 4 :45 short walk across Harvard Yard about 15 mins. 
    
For the 9th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor strait to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight, Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel, The incredible Call to Arms model sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones' works.  Then we get to the Bernini statuettes.   
  Below: Jacob and the Angel by Gustav Moreau

HOSTS WILL PASS THROUGH SOME GALLERIES BECAUSE THERE WILL BE SO MUCH MORE TO SEE. 

At 3:45 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the host) --note the sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir  & Van Gogh's last painting --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria.

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 we head to Felipe's.

HEADS UP the cafeteria closes at 4 PM! But if you sneak in your own beverage from your locker nobody will be checking ...
  ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license with a Cambridge address. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.
results.how_to_find_us: Just inside the main entrance at 2:30
results.name: Harvard Art Museums Meetup - 9.

results.description:
Art plus M & M = win win! Co-posted to Boston Cultural Nomads.

CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets, and Meet & Greet then at 2:45 we're OFF!   
   
For the 9th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor. Then we go into the Tobey Gallery right there & pass through to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight (image below-- the man in the painting who is pursuing her is not in this image which defines it), Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel (image below), The incredible Call to Arms mini study sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones's works.  And don't forget the room for the great 16th cent. sculptor statuettes by Bernini.
   
NOTE-- hosts will not linger at some of the galleries but PASS RIGHT THROUGH  others because there will be MUCH MORE to see after this.  So GO! stay with the company. This is a meetup enjoy the company; if you want to come earlier to linger at your fav places do that then.  

At 4 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the hosts) --note the weird sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir and other masterpieces --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria. 

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 to Felipe's in Harvard Square. That is a 15 minute walk through Harvard Yard.  

HEADS UP the cafeteria closes at 4 PM! But if you sneak in your own beverage from your locker nobody will be checking ...
   
ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.

http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-7he8jlARtuM/VJmDezIHhRI/AAAAAAAEzwg/v9Rn311tEa8/s288/DSC00954.JPG

results.description:
We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are very few RSVPs.

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or Chinatown on the Orange Line.
Also a short walk from Park Street or Downtown Crossing. 

• From Boylston Station, go south on Tremont Street (away from Boston Common),  then take a right onto Stuart Street.  The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

• From Chinatown Station, go west on Boylston Street (toward Boston Common), then take a left onto Tremont Street. Turn right onto Stuart Street. The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

There is a map of the area below. If you have trouble finding us, please feel free to call or text me at[masked]-2923.  Also you can call or text if you come after we have left for Chinatown, although then there is a greater chance I will miss the call.

Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

The Meetup does not end at 6 - instead, some time around there, we usually go out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards to eat family style - anyone who wants to come is welcome. The cost is usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks for which people pay their own way).  We are open to restaurant suggestions.  However, I am not willing to get into dividing up large numbers of orders on one giant check, which is why we generally go to Chinatown and split everything down the middle.  If you don't want to eat at all, you can come and just enjoy the company for free.  

Please BRING CASH if you can and want to go to dinner - many of the restaurants limit cards to two per table, so if a lot of people have no cash it can be a problem.

Stuart Street view
results.how_to_find_us: We usually have several tables pulled together at the highest point of the food court nearest the elevator.
results.name: Saturday Social Meetup at City Place

results.description:
Gotta love Maggie Smith. And the rest of the supporting cast is pretty great too.

About the film:

The magnificent Maggie Smith (“Downton Abbey,” The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, the Harry Potter series) shines in the hilarious and touching story of Miss Shepherd, a homeless woman of uncertain origins who “temporarily” parks her van in the driveway of playwright Alan Bennett (Alex Jennings) in North London—and ends up staying for 15 years. Arrayed in a mismatched panoply of rags, Miss Shepherd is hygienically challenged, violently allergic to classical music, maddeningly stubborn and guided by messages direct from the Virgin Mary. What begins as a begrudged favor by Bennett grows into a relationship that will change both their lives. This “mostly true” story, based on the memoir and play by Bennett (The History Boys, The Madness of King George, Prick Up Your Ears), was filmed on the actual street and in the house where it happened; it is directed by Nicholas Hytner, working with Bennett for the third time. With a supporting cast of Jim Broadbent, James Corden, Frances de la Tour, Roger Allam and Dominic Cooper.


Afterwards we'll go to an area restaurant for discussion.

Hope to see you there!

Lisa

results.description:
Hello South Shore Lunch and Spiritual Discussion members,

I wanted to announce that my organization, Better World Meditation is having an event with Meditation, music and a Vegetarian Dinner, on Saturday, February 20th at 5:30PM. The location is the Theosophical Society in Boston located at 21 Maple Street, Arlington,MA. I know this may be a distance for you, if you have an adventurous spirit, we would love to have you come. We have had 3 events in Arlington so far. If you want to see who has RSVP'd for this event, go to our other meetup page which is Meditation, Live Music, and Vegetarian Dinner So far,we have 18 people who have  RSVP'd for the February 20th event.

Below is a copy of the description of this event as it reads on our other meetup page:


Hello Friends and Seekers,

We will be having a unique combination of activities all in one inspiring evening. A Guided meditation for calming the mind, spiritually oriented live music and a Vegetarian Dinner. The event is sponsored by Better World Meditation, whose mission is to create a much better world through spiritual practice.  Our activities are appropriate for both newcomers who want to learn to have a calmer mind as well as experienced meditators. This is a great way to connect with other spiritually awakened souls  I will also be performing on guitar and singing at the event. My songs are inspired by my spiritual path and are focused on:Meditation, Kindness, God, and  Creating a Better World. I will include some chanting and meditative music during the meditation and more upbeat songs after the meditation.

Date: February 20th (Saturday) at 5:30PM

Location: Theosophical Society In Boston, 21 Maple Street, Arlington, MA

Cost: $15

Since we are advertising this event on 2 different meetup pages,You may RSVP for the February 20th event one of 2 ways listed below:

1) When on the" South Shore Area Lunch and Spiritual Discussion"  meetup page which you have been using so far:  click on the top Meetup that says: Meditation, Live Music and Vegetarian Dinner.   Next: click on the green box: I'm  going

2) go to our other meetup page which is:" Meditation live music and Vegetarian Dinner". Next: click on the top Meetup ad that says:  Calming Meditation,Heart Filled Music And  Vegetarian Dinner. Next:  Click green box: I'm Going

Admission: $15 (Includes Meditation, Concert and Dinner)


For More Information:

E-Mail: [masked]:

www.betterworldmeditation.com

Telephone: (617)[masked]

Much Peace and gratitude

Steven Kriger

results.description:
We will journey inward in a time-honored shamanic method of inner consultation. It is a way of communicating with your inner or spirit self and retrieving information. Your inner self is in constant communication with all aspects of your environment, seen and unseen. You need only journey within to find answers to your questions. Be prepared, however, for whatever insights you may receive, whether you like them or not.
The spirit healing journey is not always what people expect, and sometimes there is uncertainty as to what one should experience in altered states. The ecstatic trance is an individual journey into non-ordinary reality; therefore, experiences vary from person to person and from journey to journey. Once you enter a trance state, the rhythm or sound of the drum tends to change. The drumbeat may appear to speed up or slow down, while the sound may grow louder, softer, or disappear. You may experience a change in body temperature, feel energy flowing through your body, or find yourself twitching, swaying, or rocking. It is not uncommon to hear sounds or voices. You may even smell specific aromas. You may see colorful patterns, symbolic images, or dreamlike visions. Some people may find that they have a highly developed inner vision while others may rely more on instinct, intuition, or intent.
During the spirit healing journey, one's awareness transcends ordinary reality. In journeys to the Lower World, one may experience the sensation of falling, sliding, or spiraling downward into or under the Earth. In Upper World journeys, one may experience the sensation of rising, floating, flying, or spiraling upward through the air or sky. Journeys to the Lower World involve the movement of awareness to a level beneath ordinary reality and Celestial journeys involve movement to a level above ordinary reality. Lower levels are denser, lower in frequency, and more involved with the physical body, the earthly plane, and material reality. Higher levels are higher in frequency, less dense, and subtler.
You will experience at least two spiritual journeys. You do not need prior journeying experiences but an openness of the process and possibilities. Elaine is a training and practicing Shaman and will safely lead you on your journey. Please bring a yoga mat, blanket, something to cover your eyes (scarf), and journal as you may wish to write your experiences immediately following the journey. $10 Any questions or to register please contact Elaine [masked] or[masked]
results.name: An Evening of Shamanic Spiritual Healing

results.description:
Full Moon Gong: with Dharam Singh, Guruatma Kaur, and Siri Tapa Kaur

New Moon Gong: with Guruatma Kaur

 What to expect: Preparing ourselves with a Kundalini Yoga set we will create a body-mind balance for change and healing. While in this state the sound waves of the gong and bowls induce an extended state of effortless meditation and relaxation that facilitates the movement of prana through the body and psyche for healing. In this way, the gong is a tool that magnifies and focuses the power of the yoga experience.   


We will finish with tea, treats, and joy! 

Please bring a thick blanket or cushion to lie on and a shawl to cover with!   

“The Gong is the first and last instrument for the human mind, there is only one thing that can supersede and command the human mind, the sound of the Gong. It is the first sound in the Universe, the sound that created the Universe. It’s the basic creative sound. To the mind, the sound of the gong is like a mother and father that gave it birth. The mind has no power to resist a gong that is well played.”  -Yogi Bhajan, Master of Kundalini Yoga   

Yoga & Gong: Guruatma Kaur: An IKYTA certified teacher and devoted student of Yogi Bhajan, Guruatma Kaur has been enthusiastically teaching Kundalini Yoga since 1979. She is lovingly dedicated to encouraging clarity, excellence, and relaxation into one’s True Self.  

Gong:  Dharam Singh began an exploration of sound as a saxophonist and flutist in the Bronx, NYC - an environment immersed in the rich music and culture of Africa by way of the Caribbean, Boriqua, African American and the counter culture, which gave him a multicultural perspective on musical language.   His passion for the transformative power of sound and music has found a place in the use of the Gong as he came to develop a unifying aural language that removes the separation between Head and Heart, Body and Soul. It is these frequencies, tones and harmonics, already given by Nature that he simply lives to share.  Dharam is a long time student of Yogi Bhajan and a resident of Guru Ram Das Ashram, where he is the go-to guy for anything related to Gong Yoga, including buying one - www.gongsongs.com He is part of the 'three-some' that leads the monthly Full Moon Gong event 

Meditation: Siri Tapa Kaur, a Reiki Master, Sat Nam Rasayan Practitioner, and certified Kundalini Yoga Teacher lives a life committed to being healthy, happy, and available to all. Everyone who knows her is touched by her open-hearted, compassionate mother energy. 

Note: in case of any date discrepancy between this Meetup and the website, please believe the website!
results.how_to_find_us: Yoga at the Ashram is located at the Baba Siri Chand Yoga Center at Guru Ram Das Ashram, 368 Village St in Millis, MA 02054
results.name: Full and New Moon Yoga, Gongs, and Meditation

results.description:
As the pursuit of excellence in the Southern Rhone Valley has marched on throughout the last few decades, a handful of the the best villages, or communes, have been elevated above the rest, and have earned the privilege of labeling their wine with their more-prestigious commune names. 

Some of these communes may add their names to the Cotes-du-Rhone-Villages appellation, while others have even been granted their own AOC in recent years. 

While most of these wines cannot quite match their well-known neighbor Châteauneuf-du-Pâpe for its unique combination of power and finesse, they can deliver most, if not all, of the power  -  and do so at less than half the price. 

That makes Gigondas, Rasteau, Vacqueyas, Cairanne, Lirac, Laudun, Vinsobres, and Signargues go-to wines for the savvy wine consumer. 

Please bring a bottle that clearly bears one of the Rhone Valley's commune names like those listed above; we will not be including Côtes du Rhône or generic Côtes du Rhône-Villages in this tasting. These commune wines typically sell for $20-$40. 

Please bring your bottle of wine in a paper bag, 4 glasses and a food item to share.
results.name: Southern Rhône Valley Commune Wines

results.description:
As another part of our winter program, we will be doing a workshop about editing night photos Jurgen-style in Lightroom, something we successfully did once before.


The way we will do this is that YOU need to submit photos that you wish to be edited. Either a photo with which you have real problems, one where you don't know what to do with or one that you think is good, but needs an extra kick. Problems with white balance, a photo with mixed colors, issues with composition or camera settings, no idea how to convert to B&W, how to bring out the stars in the sky or correct for keystoning? Trying to throw me off and see me fail? We will tackle it.

This will be a live demo and discussion, not a lecture, and I will show you what I would do with your images or how I would process them differently, but will also take your suggestions on what to try out. Most importantly, while I'm doing this, I will explain Lightroom's development module to you. I will *not* be talking about the other modules. Also note that you don't need to use Lightroom, you can still learn from the improvement steps or try to recreate them in Adobe Camera Raw, which is very similar to Lightroom.

Here is what you need to do and if nobody follows this, we won't have anything to do. I need every participant to submit to me no more than three images, but you NEED to send me your original raw data file (.NEF, .CRW, .ORF etc). Alternatively, you can send me a .DNG file (Adobe's raw format) or a .PS Photoshop file (leave the original as an untouched layer!). I will NOT accept or demonstrate JPG files, the editing latitude is not enough to make substantial improvements. Your files will remain confidential and I will delete them after the workshop is done. I encourage you to embed your copyright information!


See comments for how to submit images.

If you want us to see what you have tried or if you want to compare before and after, select the photo in LR, then choose from the menu PHOTO - SAVE METADATA TO FILE and send me the sidecar file, the .xmp file with the same name in the same location as your raw file. That xmp file contains all the edits that you made to it. We can save those and then change to what I would do, afterwards compare your and my versions. So, if you have a Nikon raw file named _JML7470.NEF, you also need to send me the _JML7470.xmp file.

If you are interested in

- using Lightroom to edit

- how to use the LR development module

- how to improve your photos (with or without Lightroom)


- how to tackle complex white balance or other issues

- how to see Jürgen sweat


then this workshop is for you. If you have no interest, whatsoever, in learning about Lightroom, editing or improving photos, or if you can teach this workshop without breaking a sweat, by all means, come to chime in, anyway. :-)

Your files NEED to be named in the following manner, please do not submit unnamed files!

LASTNAME-FIRSTNAME-YOURNUMBER.ext

for example

Lobert-Jurgen-_JML7392.NEF  and Lobert-Jurgen-_JML7392.xmp

I need your files no later than Friday evening, 19-February, 10 pm, files submitted after that may not get considered. Depending on the number of participants, we may not get to edit all of your photos but I will try to edit at least one of them.
results.name: Workshop: Editing night photos in Lightroom and Camera Raw

results.description:
Let's dance salsa!

Saturday Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party on Saturday featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away!

9:00-10:00 pm:  Beginner & Intermediate. Salsa Lessons
10:00-2 am: Dance Party * No Partner Required

Lets meet at 9 pm (facing the stage) at the right side of the stage.

There are some tables alongside the wall. These tables are typically first come, first serve, so if we all arrive at the same time and early, we can occupy these tables.

I will make some Meetup signs and try to post them at these tables.  These tables can serve as our meeting point through out the night.  Last time I asked for permission and  management informed me that posting signs was not allowed.  I may not ask for permission this time and discretely post a night flat on the table.  

I also have some neon/glow-in-the-dark bracelets and necklaces that I plan to wear and pass out to members of the group so we can recognize each other more easily.

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 

Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds.

This should be a super fun event and a super friendly event for salsa beginners and the advanced dancers.


I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.

Wear comfortable shoes!

Joana

******************************************************************************************************************************

Event Details

Beginners Very Welcome

No partner required

$12 - Admission includes lesson and party

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant (No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)

Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar

Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 10% merengue/cha cha

***********************************
Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St.

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr)parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk.

Please note that the Night Salsa parties are 21+.

* Don't forget your ID!

http://www.havanaclubsalsa.com

results.description:
Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event. Organizer: Amal @ (617)[masked]


What we are doing:

Don't want to chase the Whites this weekend but still get out and breath? Come hike the Blue Hills Reservation south of Boston! We will be meeting at the Reservation Headquarters on Hillside Rd (near Houghton Pond) and take the Skyline trail eastward. We will hike out for ~ 7.5 miles and then turn around for a 15mi RT/ 2400ft elevation gain.  It should take ~5-6 hrs to complete, depending on our pace (I'm guessing!). 

We will keep a brisk pace (>2.5-3mi/hr or so), but this is not meant to be a trail run. We will stop for snacks/drinks. While  the elevation gain is not as significant as in the Whites, keeping a faster pace will make this a more challenging experience.  Please be sure that you have recently completed hikes of similar effort and/or distance. Please answer the few questions, as everyone will be screened. 

What to Bring...

Weather forecast  for Sunday is supposed to be in the 50's, so we likely won't need microspikes, but since this is New England weather, anything is possible! So please bring them along...as well as some food and water.

Lastly, as Michael Blair would say: "We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you."


This event is considered to be INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. DO NOT SIGN UP FOR THIS TRIP UNLESS YOU HAVE DONE A SIMILAR HIKE DURING THE PAST THREE MONTHS. 

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself or others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate.


Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at Reservation headquarters, 1/4 mile north of Houghtons Pond, beside the State Police Station.
results.name: Feeling the Sunday Blue(s)

results.description:
Join us to discover the 3 secrets to capturing the spirit of a festival, parade or special event.  This will be a great way to kick off the Year of the Monkey. Due to great weather, the Parade that was canceled last weekend will be held this Sunday. It is going to be 50 degrees out! Grab your camera and join us to learn how to take better pictures.

 I am just back in town and so happy to be taking a group to Chinatown for this experience in learning how to take stunning photos of special events. There will be music, food, dancing and fabulous costumes for us to capture with our cameras. I will design  a series of creative photography challenges to help you build specific skills during the event. 

Some of the topics I will cover in the workshop will be:

• Timing and positioning so you increase the chances of getting the lucky shot.

• Composition of subjects within the frame and in relationship to each other.

• How to use elements of color, light, texture, and motion to evoke emotion and tell a story. 

• How to simplify the shot so you capture the essence of the moment.

• What are the recommended camera settings if you want to go off auto and catch the lions in action. How to prepare so your photos are in focus and properly exposed. 

The great thing about a festival is that no one cares if you are taking photos. So this is the perfect opportunity to get comfortable taking photos of total strangers.  

How we will work:

WE will meet at 9am at a coffee shop where I have reserved a space for us. I will give a full hour workshop on camera settings, composition, and creative subject selection before we go out into the crowd. We will discuss lighting, color balance, and shutter speeds, but don't worry if you are a beginner, I will help you get set.

Then from 10-11 we will shoot behind the scenes to catch the pre event set up action. Often you can capture the most interesting shots while people are getting into costumes, putting on makeup and getting organized. I find this is a key to the success of photographing an event.  

Finally at 11am the parade will get underway and you will be ready to capture the scene. This is a vibrant, colorful dynamic event that plays out on the streets of Chinatown. We will be right in the middle of the fun so you won't miss a thing.


This special workshop on street photography at special events will introduce you to a step by step method for gaining confidence in photographing people in action.  This is a essential skill for travel photographers, family photographers, and anyone interested in capturing  moments of life in a way that tells a story. 

I hope you can join us. The tuition for the class is $45.00 and includes all instructions and handouts so you can practice the skills again next time you are at an event. 

I am limiting the group size to 10 so please RSVP right away. More details will be provided once I have the full class participation list. 

We will officially end the class at noon but the event continues all afternoon so you can keep shooting and practicing what you learn. 

closest T stop is Chinatown on the Orange line. Parking in Chinatown is not recommended. Best to park at the Boston Common lot and walk over from there.

Looking forward to seeing you this Sunday.

Suzanne

Photo by group member from previous workshop.

results.name: Fun Photo Workshop: Chinese New Year Lion Parade Street Photography

results.description:
We'll explore Marblehead on  rail trails, streets, and paths for awhile. Before we slow down for some of the more historic sights. 

Plan on spending 4- 5+ hrs  Mileage 7-10?

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. I am committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up. 

Please note this is not a beginners’ hike. It is for intermediate level hikers and beginning hikers who keep in fit condition doing other things. You should be in good enough physical condition to keep up and stay with the group going at a moderate pace. Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared.Bring water and lunch/snacks and dress in layers.

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own. We hike in light rain or showers, but heavy rain or extreme temperature cancels.

No dogs and no guests are allowed on hikes. Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event. 

Please remember that I am a volunteer, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

 By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:
Remember: I am a volunteer. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet on the Washington St side
results.name: Historic Marblehead

results.description:
This is a 5 mile loop around Hickory Hills Forest and Lunenburg conservation land. It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. Walk over to the trail head and make our way around the forest. Wear sturdy shoes or boots. Sneakers are OK, however we do encounter streams from time to time,. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags.
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:30 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.
results.name: Trail Hiking/Walking

Meet to paint the model for a five week pose- Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $75, non-members for $90.    Three hours each Sunday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at


http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html 

PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

results.description: Join our experts for an exciting hike in the wilderness of Estabrook Woods, the largest contiguous and undeveloped woodland within 30 miles of Boston. Located just two miles north of Concord, this wild tract of land has more than 1,200 acres of woods, hills, ledges and wetlands and offers an extensive network of trails to explore. We'll take you on some of our favorite trails where you'll have a chance to see the abundant wildlife that inhabits this area. Please make sure you wear appropriate hiking clothing; waterproof footwear (if possible) and dress for the weather (layers; no cotton). Please bring a small day pack with extra clothes, snacks, water and any personal medications you may need.  Ages 8 and up are welcome.  Hope to see you on the trail!
results.how_to_find_us: The Trailhead Parking is the Malcolm Preserve on Stearns St. in Carlisle MA. Stearns St. is off 225 just east of Kimball Farm Ice Cream, after turning onto Stearns St the Malcolm Preserve parking lot is 0.6 mi on the left.
results.name: Hike Estabrook Woods

Two floor of vintage wares and artisan creations, live music, DJ, beer and wine. Shake off those winter blues and spend some time with us at the flea. Free admission.

Susan and I will plan to be there at 10am.  Join us for brunch afterward at Highland Kitchen right down the street - please RSVP to brunch through the separate meetup.  Thanks!

More info here: http://www.thesomervilleflea.com/Home.html

The Somerville Flea is an open-air market bringing together vendors, artists, musicians and connecting them with Somerville and surrounding communities.  The majority of our vendors deal in vintage and antiques that have been reclaimed restored and repurposed.  We also include artisans that celebrate traditional means of production.  In addition, you will find a farmer’s stand, neat snacks and some of the top musicians in the area, playing live.

results.description:
NOTE: This is a continuation of  the classes started on Sunday, February 7th.


This is a 4 week course. If you RSVP for this date you are RSVPing for the complete 4 week course. Please only RSVP if you are committed to attending to the whole series.


This course introduces students to the basic principles of 3D modeling, such as how to navigate in 3D space, what 3D models are made out of, and how to create simple forms and objects. The software used will be Sketchup, a free program that is excellent for beginners and professionals alike. Students will learn the ins and outs of the program, from basic techniques to advanced modeling concepts. This series is for people who have not already taken a 3D modeling class at HATCH.


Requirements:


• A free copy of Sketchup. 

• A CAD-capable laptop or desktop. The computer must have a discrete graphics chip or a very new (last three years) onboard graphics chip.


• A three button (minimum) mouse.


• You must be an experienced Windows or Mac user.


• You should be able to utilize keyboard shortcuts and understand how to use computer file systems.


*If you need a laptop please contact the organizer, we have six laptops available for use. We prefer that you use your own for this class.*

If you are bringing your own computer, please pre-load Sketchup Make. You can download it from <a>www.sketchup.com.</a>
results.how_to_find_us: We're located in the Arsenal Project (formerly Arsenal Mall). Park in the lot near Old Navy entrance, you'll see a big yellow-green sign over the doors. HATCH is between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: Introduction to 3D Modeling (4 week class)

Ski Committee show and go Sunday XC ski series. Meet at noted touring center at 10 am for 5-6 hours of moderate paced, led machine cut track kick and glide skiing. Novice to advanced skiers welcome, we will ski a few hours, return to the lodge for lunch, then ski a few hours in the afternoon. Group will likely break into a faster and more moderate paced group; extremely fast (and skaters) or slower skiers are welcome to self-guide. These are show and go trips on machine groomed and patrolled nordic centers, no need to pre-register. Participants should self-pay for the center trail fee. We recommend beginners take a group lesson before attending one of these trips. All trips ski off at 10 am sharp, arrive in time to get your skis waxed and gear together; look for leaders at trail head near lodge. Trips may go in marginal conditions, but lack of snow and/or rain will likely cancel the trip. Consult leader with questions.

Leader Carla Schwartz at [masked]

results.description:
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/arduino-workshop-tickets-19957408145

This workshop is for anyone who has never played around with Arduino before and those who have played around a little bit but aren’t entirely sure about how the basics work. It’s easier than you think!

We will put together basic single component electrical circuits, learn about analog and digital, input and output, basic programming concepts, practice very basic Serial communication, and briefly cover basic virtual prototyping.

In case you haven’t noticed the key word here is "basic."

Students will create three simple circuits highlighting analog and digital forms of input and output. Get started with the Arduino programming environment; briefly discuss programming and virtual prototyping.

Concepts that will be covered include:

Using a breadboard
Ohm’s Law
Digital and Analog
Input and Output
Arduino programming environment basics
Serial Monitor usage with text, variables and pin states

Instructor: Sajin George
results.name: Arduino Workshop

results.description:
Greater Boston Oasis meets every week for engaging speakers, live musicians, and the opportunity to connect with the community. Details of the speakers, musical guests, etc. will be posted in the individual meetups as they are confirmed.

Doors for the event open at 10:00 AM for coffee and conversation, with the program starting at 10:30. We hope to see you there!

=========================================


This week, instead of a main speaker, we'll be having a potluck brunch! If you'd like to bring something, please sign up in the comments, here in the meetup group, or at the Facebook event at https://www.facebook.com/events/233270863677155/. Please let us know if you have any dietary restrictions so that we can ensure that they're accommodated!

If you do plan on bringing something, let us know by posting it in the spreadsheet here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Jj8vmjc8GPBicBdxabDyrT5KBkW5kNsfyXpuyXIWSaU/edit?pref=2&pli=1#gid=0


=========================================

Oasis meets in the Teen Center at the YMCA. To find the room, enter through the lower entrance (on Dartmouth Street, by the swimming pool), and follow Oasis signs from the front lobby to the Teen Center on the second floor. (Note: the stairwell to the Teen Center is NOT the stairwell in the front lobby. That is Stairwell A. The Teen Center is located at Stairwell B, next to the Yoga Studio. Oasis volunteers will be available to help provide assistance, and signage will be posted.

=========================================

Greater Boston Oasis is a secular community dedicated to providing for the human need for social and intellectual community, for those people who may not want or be able to have those needs met in a church or other faith-based community. 

Our Core Values are:


People are more important than beliefs

Reality is known through reason

Meaning comes from making a difference

Human hands solve human problems

Be accepting, and be accepted


Atheist or agnostic, freethinker or skeptic, deist or theist, all those with whom those values resonate are welcome to celebrate the human experience.
results.how_to_find_us: Follow signs from the entrance to the Teen Center room. Use the Dartmouth Street entrance, and head to Stairwell B. Teen Center is on the 2nd floor.
results.name: Weekly Sunday Gathering - Potluck Brunch

What to expect: This monthly meeting typically begins with an introduction all around for the benefit of any first-time attendees, and discussion of any announcements, upcoming events, etc. We then move on to a topic of interest to atheists (usually) chosen beforehand. Sometimes participants bring print-outs of articles, research, or books to share on the topic, and sometimes people just come with a story or opinion to share.

We loosely moderate the topical discussion to give everyone a chance to participate. Then the conversation often flows onto other related subjects, sometimes in smaller conversation groups around the table.

If you have any ideas for meeting topics, please let any of the co-organizers know. We can also add announcements or "mini-topics" on the agenda if there's anything you'd like to share with the group.

results.description:
A 2 hour walk through field and forest.

Owned by the town since 1969, Rock Meadow Conservation Area is located less than two minutes from Beaver Brook Reservation on Mill Street. The land is comprised of 70 acres of undulating meadows, wetlands, streams and woods. The state has designated the area as an important grassland and a natural habitat for plants and animals that have been forced from former farmland. Rock Meadow offers hiking, birding, biking, picnicking and wandering opportunities. The area is also the home of Belmont's community gardens. It resembles the meadows in the south of England. It is the home of Belmont's community gardens (Victory Gardens). Originally owned by McLean Hospital in 1895, a farm was created to provide food during WWII.

This is a picture of the sign for the Rock Meadow parking lot. On the other side of the street, about 150 feet away, is a similar sign for the Lone Tree parking lot. The Rock Meadow parking lot will get full, so some people will have to use the Lone Tree lot and walk over to Rock Meadow. The walk will begin from the Rock Meadow parking lot.
results.how_to_find_us: look for the turn-off heading downhill to a small parking lot
results.name: Rock Meadow - Belmont

results.description:
The MFA is doing a retrospective of the films of Stanley Kubrick. This is one I've not seen in a while and never on the big screen. There will be discussion afterward at one of the MFA's dining areas.

From the MFA website:
Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb by Stanley Kubrick (USA/UK, 1964, 95 min.). Few films have responded to their times as much, or in as unlikely a fashion, as Dr. Strangelove. Its darkly satirical story turns the fearful days of the Cold War upside down, revealing a dangerously irrational world in the process. The plot revolves around a desperate attempt to prevent World War III when a deranged US general dispatches an American plane to drop nuclear bombs on Moscow. With life on earth in the balance, US leaders try to stop their own bomber before it triggers a deadly Soviet doomsday device.

And remember, you can't fight in here; this is the War Room!
results.name: Dr. Strangelove at the MFA

results.description:
I have always wanted to see this!

Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb by Stanley Kubrick (USA/UK, 1964, 95 min.). Few films have responded to their times as much, or in as unlikely a fashion, as Dr. Strangelove. Its darkly satirical story turns the fearful days of the Cold War upside down, revealing a dangerously irrational world in the process. The plot revolves around a desperate attempt to prevent World War III when a deranged US general dispatches an American plane to drop nuclear bombs on Moscow. With life on earth in the balance, US leaders try to stop their own bomber before it triggers a deadly Soviet doomsday device.

Synopsis and film notes by Gordon Arnold
Montserrat College of Art

After the movie we'll go to dine and discuss.  Uno's is a good default, but I'm looking for a brunch spot that may accommodate 12.  Open to suggestions.  I'll try to lock in the spot a week ahead of time to aid in your decision.

Added 2/17/16 --For dining and discussion afterwards I'm looking at Uno's, the cafeteria in the MFA, or maybe brunch at Thortons across the fens.  A brunch reservation might be required so we really need folks to chime in and say they'd be up for that or not.  Also feedback on the other two places.  I'll mail this out to the current "yes" responders as well.
results.how_to_find_us: Up front on the right just after the movie.  Moving slowly to the restroom area, and then departing to dine and discuss.
results.name: Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb

results.description:
Our speaker for February is Benjamin Wolfe - we'll be learning about food microbial communities and fermentation!

Plus, we'll be singing some cheesy songs like 'Eat It' by Weird Al and 'Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go' by Wham!

_

Benjamin Wolfe is an Assistant Professor of Microbiology in the Department of Biology at Tufts University. His lab uses food microbial communities to address fundamental questions in microbial ecology and evolution. Benjamin is a passionate promoter of microbial literacy through teaching and writing. He has taught food microbiology courses at the Harvard Summer School and Boston University's Gastronomy Program and has taught classes or workshops at Formaggio Kitchen, the San Francisco Cheese School, and for artisan food guilds across the country.

remember, the Democracy Center is an alcohol free venue. So as much as we love fermentation, please don't bring any beer.

results.description:
We actually had 7 people attend this event!


Think of this as a creative mini-retreat. It's designed primarily for writers—of all experience levels, working in any genre. Although we've booked the space for 6 hours, you're welcome to arrive and leave whenever you like. 

WHAT WE'LL DO: 

• 11:30 a.m.: Doors open.

• 12:15 p.m.: Write to easy creative prompts (if there's interest). 

• 1 p.m. sharp: Begin writing.

Although we'll be in the same large room, we'll be writing in companionable silence, talking only during breaks. If you'd like to have a conversation with someone, you're welcome to step outside or head to a nearby coffee shop.


• About 4:15-4:30 p.m.: People will be invited to briefly share from their work, if they wish. (Sharing is optional and time will be limited.) No one will critique anyone's work unless the writer requests feedback. 

• 5:30 p.m.: Clean up and depart. 

AMENITIES: The Braintree Community Arts Center is a newly converted two-story house about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the road (Route 37). We'll have the house all to ourselves for the day. It's bright, pleasant, and equipped with tables, chairs, restrooms, a coffeemaker, a fridge, a countertop range, free parking, and Wi-Fi. I will provide a few books for inspiration, and an extension cord and power strip for power.

WHAT TO BRING: Yourself, your writing projects and writing implements (computer or  writing notebook and pen, or journal). Bring your own beverage. Feel free to bring a snack to share—but that’s entirely optional.

COST: $15 (cash or check), regardless of how long you stay. This goes toward space-use costs and our Meetup fee.  

HOW TO RESERVE A SPOT: RSVP "yes" using Meetup's RSVP function. The RSVP list is our official headcount for the day, so it's the only way to sign up—emailing the organizer or posting messages on the site won't hold a spot.

CANCELLATIONS: If we need to cancel due to weather or any other reason, we'll post a message on the Web site and e-mail all "yes" RSVPs as far in advance as possible. 

REMINDER ABOUT ABOUT RSVPs: Your RSVP is a reservation, and we're trusting that you'll honor it. If you can't make it, please change your RSVP from "yes" to "no" at least 24 hours in advance. If you cancel with less than 24 hours notice, or if you RSVP "yes" and then don't show up, you'll be asked to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

Looking forward to seeing you!
results.name: Meet to write in companionable silence
