results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$2/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $15/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.

results.description:
WARNING: this event will start at noon (30 min earlier than usual)  because the courts won't be available after 1:30 PM. 

We have rented 3 badminton courts at the BU Fitness & Recreation Center (regulation full sized courts).  The BU facility is immaculate and a fantastic place to play.


The fee (payable online when you RSVP) gets you into the BU Fitness & Recreation Center to play badminton for an hour and a half.  Part of the fee is for the court time and the rest is for your meetup group to cover other expenses, i.e. rackets, shuttlecocks/birdies, meetup.com fees. All fees collected go to pay the Group's expenses.

We have rackets and shuttles for everyone!

Expect to play doubles. The host can help to match up pairs but members are free to join in any game they want.  The courts are reserved only for Boston Badminton members.

Before asking a question, please read through the following FAQs:

Q: The meetup is full, can I come regardless and pay at the event?
A: No, there is limited space to make sure everyone gets to play. A few spots typically open up before the event.

Q: It's my first time, how do I find you?
A: Go to the BU Fitness & Recreation Center reception (see directions below), and tell them you're here with Boston Badminton. They'll tell you where the courts are, check you're on the list, and make you sign a waiver. The meeting point is on the courts.

Q: I am a BU student, do I get a discount?
A: No, BU charges us the same regardless of whether participants are at BU or not.


Directions:
Please click here for a google map to The BU Fitness & Recreation Center.  The easiest way to get to the FitRec center from within Boston is to take the Green Line (B)-Boston College to Saint Paul St.  Parking is limited but available.  Please click here for parking information.

Plan to grab a drink locally after if we have interest.

The club has full locker room and shower facilities.

Note: In addition to agreeing to the Meetup's Liability Waiver, all members must sign a Waiver of Liability Form in order to use BU's courts. This form is available at the front desk at the FitRec center.  We may ask you for your full name in order to help BU and the meetup comply with the liability procedures.

Let me know if you have any questions and I hope to see you there!

Liability Waiver

By attending a Boston Badminton meetup, you hereby agree to the terms of the following Liability Waiver:

The purpose of the following Liability Waiver is to protect Boston Badminton meetup members and group leaders from liability in case of accident or injury. All members must agree to the Liability Waiver in order to participate in the group and its activities.

As part of my membership to Boston Badminton on Meetup.com (hereinafter “Boston Badminton”), I hereby freely and voluntarily agree to the following Release, Acknowledgment of Risk, and Waiver of Liability:

In consideration of the opportunity to participate in events, activities, classes, and programs conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates in any venue, and to use equipment located therein, I, on behalf of myself and my minor children, do hereby release, hold harmless and forever discharge and agree not to sue Boston Badminton and its trustees, officers, agents, founders, members, volunteers and employees (together, "Meetup.com Group") from any and all claims, responsibilities or liabilities for injury or damages resulting from or arising out of my or my family’s use of, presence in, or participation in activities conducted at any venue rented or owned by Boston Badminton, whether or not caused by the ordinary negligence of Boston Badminton. I understand, recognize and acknowledge that certain activities conducted by Boston Badminton or taking place in venues rented or owned by Boston Badminton are potentially hazardous. I also acknowledge that it is my responsibility to follow instructions for any activity or use of equipment, and to seek help from the volunteers if I have any questions. I further understand that, notwithstanding precautions taken by Boston Badminton, sports and fitness activities involve a risk of injury and/or death. I/we are voluntarily participating in these activities and using equipment and machinery with knowledge of the dangers involved. I hereby agree to expressly assume and accept any and all risks associated with my participation in activities conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates. I have read the foregoing and hereby agree to be bound by same.
results.name: Badminton @ BU, SUN 12-1:30 pm (2/21/2015)

results.description:
LEARN, EXPLORE & PLAN for TRAVEL in 2016 with the Onyxbirds.

The Onyxbird tradition continues...let's escape to a world of travel options and HUGE savings!

Learn about new and exciting travel opportunities — budget vacations, cruises, tours, adventure travel, weekend getaways, exotic destinations, luxury escapes, vacation rentals and more — and book trips at INCREDIBLE savings, right on the show floor!

With more than 250 exhibitors expected to participate, the Boston Globe Travel Show is sure to have something for everyone!

TRAVEL SHOW SCHEDULE

Friday      February 19th    5:30P   - 8:00P

temps high 40s cloudy 0% chance precip

Saturday February 20th   10:00A - 6:00P

temps low 50s partly cloudy 8% chance precip

Sunday    February 21st  10:00A -   4:00P

temps low 50s partly cloudy 0% chance precip

If you want to meet up with Obirds, SUGGEST you review the schedule of cultural performances and culinary presentations as well as the list of exhibitors and the floor plan to figure out what you want to do and see. Then make a comment with the day and time you plan to attend, This link has details, http://bostonglobetravelshow.com/


Annual Northeast Craft Beer Pavilion!

Over 25 breweries offering nearly 50 different beers (limited tickets).

3:30P - 6:00P Craft Beer session in the Beer Pavilion on Sat Feb 20th SOLD OUT

Cultural Performances and Entertainment!

Culinary Presentations featuring top chefs preparing exotic dishes with sample bites given away to those in attendance.

Hear from travel experts such as Patricia Schultz (1,000 Places To See Before You Die author) and Robert Rose (RAWTravel TV)

Children's area has Games2U and The Cookie Monstah 

REGULAR TRAVEL SHOW TICKETS ($10 online / $15 onsite)

Use one of these promotion codes, 'aruba16' or 'cruise16' to get FREE tickets online at this link, https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-boston-globe-travel-show-tickets-19432761914 These FREE tickets do NOT include entry into the Beer Pavilion. Online ticket sales end at 11:59 PM Friday February 19th.

Suggest you wear comfortable shoes and dress in layer.

Onsite coat check costs $3 per item checked.

Check out the following link for details and/or to get tickets, http://bostonglobetravelshow.com/

It is very easy to get there by the Silver Line (SL4) from Dudley to South Station or Red Line subway to South Station. Then from South Station take any Silver Line to the World Trade Center. Look for the World Trade Center and Travel Show signs.


If you decide to drive here are a few parking options;

1)  cheapest - Necco Garage 10 Necco Street 02210 $5 flat rate with credit card. 20 minute walk.

2) closest  - Seaport Hotel Garage 1 Seaport Lane 02210 $13 for 1 hour $24 for 2 hours $29 for 3 hours $32 for up 6 hours $34 for up to 10 hours with cash or credit card. 1 minute walk.

3) Marine Industrial Park Garage - VPNE Parking 12 Drydock Ave 02210. Either $5 flat weekend rate or $15 event rate with cash or credit card. 15 minute walk.

results.description:
If you could picture a magic box, filled with everything you need to live a life free of limitations and fear, what would you need to be included in that box? This workshop will provide you with those tools to release what is holding you back, and help you to move forward.

You will be introduced to a variety of methods for self-care which include:

ENERGY HEALING:  You will learn basic  daily practices to improve your health. Reiki, EFT, Tapping, and deep breathing techniques.


ENERGY/SPACE CLEARING: You will learn three easy ways to clear yourself, your home, and your workspace of energy that doesn't serve you in a positive way.

RAISING YOUR VIBRATION: You will be uplifted through Music, Dance,  Prayer, Gratitude and Meditation.


OTHER THINGS: You will explore Essential oils, Crystals, Stones, and more.

Leading This Workshop Are:

Bev Gerstein:Bev holds a M.S. degree in Psychology & a B.S. in Education. She provided crisis intervention as a therapist & director of a local hotline. In recent years, she began a spiritual journey & is a Spiritual Therapist, Reiki Master/Teacher & Certified Life Coach.

Ellen Sklaver:

Ellen holds a B.S. degree in Personality Psychology. She is a Motivational Coach & Facilitator for the North-of-Boston Law of Attraction Meet-up Group, since 2010. She is also Certified as a PSYCH-K & Neuro-Linguistic Programming (NLP) Practitioner.
results.how_to_find_us: We are right above McGill's Convenient Store, on the 2nd Floor. Please Use Street Parking.

results.description:
Sunday is supposed to be a nice day in the 40s.  We can grab food after if there is interest.

The movie:

Set in Dublin Glassland tells the story of a young taxi driver (Reynor) who gets tangled up in the world of human trafficking while trying to save his mother (Collette) from addiction.


Reviews:

Los Angeles Times: "In the movie's best scene, as mother and son dance to an old pop song, the look on Reynor's face speaks volumes about loss and hope. It's a look that's going to be breaking hearts on screen for decades to come." Spirituality and Practice: "A moving drama that reveals the struggles of a compassionate caregiver at the end of his rope." NPR: "The film is an intensely descriptive, head-to-the-ground mood piece . . . Glassland is the satisfyingly tangled love story of a boy and his mama." The film enjoys an 82% positive rating at 

RottenTomatoes.com

.

results.description:
We want to make our services available to everyone. Some can’t spare the time for one of our standard appointments, or can’t afford even our low-cost/pay-what-you-can consultation option. Recognizing this, we will offer short, focused mini-consultations, including one herbal preparation, for free to all comers. This is your opportunity to talk with a practicing herbalist, share any health concerns you may have, and receive personalized education in the preparation and use of herbs.

Sunday, February 21st, 2016
1:00pm – 5:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The consultation and one preparation are free. (Donations are accepted.)

For this free clinic day, we cannot schedule specific individual appointment times – everything will be first come, first served. If we have a high turnout this may entail some wait time. We expect the mini-consultations themselves to run approximately 20 minutes each, plus 5-10 minutes for preparation of herbs.

Please spread the word! We would especially like to reach out to underserved individuals who would not otherwise have access to herbal medicine.

Please note: this is not a medical clinic: we are not doctors, we are not dispensing medical advice, and we are not diagnosing or treating any medical conditions. We are providing information and education from the perspective of traditional herbalism. The herbal preparations we provide are to be considered samples to aid in your personal investigation into the effects of herbs in your own body.

If you plan to come by, it helps us if you RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at <a>[masked]</a>, or calling[masked]-5274.

http://commonwealthherbs.com/free-herbalist-mini-consultations/
results.name: Herbal Free Clinic Day

results.description:
Please join us for a pleasant afternoon of competitive party bridge.

Bertucci's has its own parking lot, a welcoming atmosphere, and hearty food (including all-you-can-eat salads and soups).

Please sign up by Saturday afternoon, the day before the game. If at least 5 players have not registered by then, the game will have to be cancelled for that week.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play. No formal training will be offered, but this is a social, casual event, and bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed at any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: SUNDAY BRIDGE  AT ALEWIFE "T"

results.description:
Boston OM Center presents

Penetrating with Love:
An Exclusive Coaching Circle with Sharon Day


Get in

...a 3-week series with Sharon Day, co-director of your Boston OM Center. During this eight-person coaching circle (kept small so you get personal attention) learn from a woman who’s willing to reveal everything, giving you the ins and outs of how to untangle your self-limiting wiring and expand your capacity for having much, much more. Includes instruction on how to map the principles of Orgasmic Meditation (OM) onto your relationships, your sex, and your life, and personalized assignments (the fun kind). 

Sharon brings her nearly two decades of professional coaching along with her recent two years of deep immersion in Orgasmic Meditation. She connects with you swiftly and deeply, illuminating hidden obstacles, revealing your brilliance, and waking you up. 

Immerse

…in a rich discussion on the things that can usually only be whispered about, freeing your sex and desire, awakening powerful parts of yourself, and integrating your revelations into your life through exercises and practices. You can let yourself come out, sink in and get saturated with orgasm, and rediscover your innate capacity to transmute problems into fuel.

Get out

…and take what you’ve learned into your life and the world. Become the man or woman you yearn to be in relationships. Have more confidence in sex, work, and in life. Remember who you are at a core level and play with living your life from that empowered place. 

• Be seen and heard deeply

• Experience a discernible shift—something suddenly feels open, lighter, or clarified.

• Have insights and “Aha!” moments, even during other participants’ sharing 

Bring your most frustrating or stuck challenge—that one that seems to cling to you like a barnacle—to be transmuted into a power-source; or your most exciting new growth-edge to nudge a leap forward!

This three-session series (or just drop in for one or two) is open to all. Invite a friend!

Three Sundays, February 14,  21, & 28 2016

1 - 3 PM 

Please be there by 12:50; we begin on time

FREE PARKING ON SUNDAYS

3-session series for $147.00

Single-session drop-in for $67.00

To register, send a blank email to
[masked]


The Boston OM Center teaches about relationships, intimacy, sexuality and purpose through a practice called Orgasmic Meditation. Orgasmic Meditation is a partnered wellness practice where a man or woman strokes the upper left-hand quadrant of a woman's clitoris for 15 minutes in order to increase connection, sensitivity, and intimacy.   Any questions, text/call Sharon 404.931.8486.

www.turnonboston.com

results.name: Penetrating with Love: An Exclusive Coaching Circle with Sharon Day

Hi Soccer Comrades! Today is going to be unexpectedly warm for February.  Why not come and kick the ball around for an hour or so beginning at 1:00 PM?We will do this at the turf field of Belmont High School as we did a few weeks ago.  We have no official claim to the field, so hopefully nobody will kick us off.  A few things to remember:

This is the "kinder and gentler" friendly, coed, game for people of all ages and nobody should get too serious: we want to avoid any injuries.

Each player should bring a WHITE shirt and a BLACK or DARK BLUE shirt, so as to make team formation easy. 

Somebody should bring a ball and some cones to mark the field.  (I always do, but I hate everybody to rely on me).

Everybody should bring some water or something to drink, even in this cold weather.

You can find the location at Google Maps with the link: https://www.google.com/maps/@42.39523,-71.1674112,17z

The turf field is located just to the right of the Viglirolo Skating Rink

results.description:
Do you have a health issue you'd like to talk to an herbalist about?


We want to make our services available to everyone.


Some can’t spare the time for one of our standard appointments, or can’t afford even our low-cost/pay-what-you-can consultation option. Recognizing this, we will offer short, focused mini-consultations, including one herbal preparation, for free to all comers.


This is your opportunity to talk with a practicing herbalist, share any health concerns you may have, and receive personalized education in the preparation and use of herbs. Whether you've never seen an herbalist before and just want to learn more, or you've worked with herbs for years, this is a great opportunity for you to get personalized information - for free!

Sunday, February 21st,[masked]:00pm – 5:00pm 25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline


The consultation and one preparation are free. (Donations are accepted.)


For this free clinic day, we cannot schedule specific individual appointment times – everything will be first come, first served. If we have a high turnout this may entail some wait time. We expect the mini-consultations themselves to run approximately 20 minutes each, plus 5-10 minutes for preparation of herbs. Please spread the word! We would especially like to reach out to underserved individuals who would not otherwise have access to herbal medicine.


Please note: this is not a medical clinic: we are not doctors, we are not dispensing medical advice, and we are not diagnosing or treating any medical conditions. We are providing information and education from the perspective of traditional herbalism. The herbal preparations we provide are to be considered samples to aid in your personal investigation into the effects of herbs in your own body. If you plan to come by, it helps us if you RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.

http://commonwealthherbs.com/free-herbalist-mini-consultations/

results.description:
In his last monthly talk at the Humanist Hub, Greg Epstein attempted to offer a humanistic perspective on insecurity: acknowledging we all feel it, and reflecting on what may at times even be the upside of feeling insecure.


This month, Greg will follow up on that talk by diving in to what you might call the ultimate insecurity: feelings of despair.


If despair is the opposite of and/or the absence of hope, that likely means that anyone who has ever felt hope has likely also experienced despair. And that means...just about all of us have.


For humanists, atheists, agnostics and others who don't believe there is a god or supernatural power to give us hope, what do we do when we have the familiar feeling that there is no hope? What do we do when we feel despair? When and how should we admit it, to ourselves and others? How do we support ourselves and one another through the hardest feelings? How do we create a society and community where it is okay to feel awful about life sometimes, and where despairing feelings don't need to lead to desperate outcomes-- and where, in fact, being honest with ourselves and others about the hardest aspects of life can actually allow us to experience more joy and connection?


Inspired in part by a beautiful book called Stay: a History of Suicide and the Philosophies Against It, by Jennifer Michael Hecht (one of Greg's favorite authors in general), this talk will aim to give us a chance to accept some of our darkest places, in order to show how we often have incredible gifts to offer to ourselves and the world around us, in spite of or even because of that with which we struggle.


If you've ever personally struggled with feelings of despair and wanted to understand them better, or if you've ever had a friend or a loved one who has, and you want to understand them better, or if you just want to help the Humanist Hub become an even healthier community, where people can come as they are and help make the world a better place-- this session is meant for you.


Join Greg Epstein for his monthly talk at the Hub: with food, music, discussion circles, and more. Childcare available for kids 5 and up. Email [masked] to reserve a spot.
results.name: Greg Epstein: What Do We Do With Despair?

results.description:
Nectar is a talk-free dance inspired by conscious and ecstatic dance. It is a space to enjoy and explore embodiment, physical expression, and the body’s wisdom. After an unguided warm-up period, the Facilitator-DJ leads a brief opening circle on a theme or guided practice, followed by a playlist of music—beginning spacious and mellow, gaining intensity, and arriving back into stillness. Participants are welcome to move, dance, and be still as their bodies desire. Nectar closes with a sharing circle in which participants are welcome to speak about their experiences in the dance.

Nectar is offered primarily for adults. Children are welcome with adult accompaniment provided they can follow the talk-free and intentional structure and be mindful of their impact on others in the space. Kids under 6 can come for free, and ages 6-12 for half price ($5-7). $10-15 for adults.

Nectar was created by Amorn O’Connor and Harrison Blum, and is supported by a rotating crew of Facilitator-DJs.

Please note that many more people attend than RSVP via Meetup!

Also, I'm delighted to announce that my anthology is now in print-- Dancing with Dharma: Essays on Movement and Dance in Western Buddhism . It shares the voices of 27 people doing work at the intersection of movement/dance and Buddhism, from Buddhist lamas and nuns to professional choreographers to dance/movement therapists. It's divided into the sections of Movement, Dance, Performance, Ritual, and Theory, then concluding with 11 Guided Practices chapters that guide readers in some of the modalities previously described. Please help spread the word to individuals, schools, libraries, etc. that may be interested! Also, having folks write Amazon reviews is super helpful.

results.name: Nectar

THE STORY

Everyone needs help sometimes. This is one of those times. John was diagnosed with several brain tumors that have wreaked all kinds of havoc with his body. He had surgery in mid-January. So far - the prognosis is good - all benign. However, he currently can't drive and can only play music on a VERY limited basis. This leaves him with an income that's next to nothing. This is expected to continue for him for up to a year. His wife, Julia has a new job, however, it doesn't start until 02/01 and at this point there is no income stream for either of them. Medical and living expenses are piling up.

The music community will come together in a tribute to benefit Mr. & Mrs. Johnny Blue Horn, keeping in mind that John has volunteered for many benefits for others in need. 

Please join us if you can!

results.description:
Instead of the 1 book/month selection.  I thought maybe we will try genres and themes.  For the month of February 2016, our theme is "Love Letters".  If you found a book that you love, please leave comment or bring it to the bookclub to surprise us.

To All the Boys I've Loved Before (To All the Boys I've Loved Before, #1) by Jenny Han

F-M YA romance


Love Letters to the Dead by Ava Dellaira

Coming of age story


Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda by Becky Albertalli

M-M YA romance.  The YA librarians in my area are in love with this book.


To All the Boys I've Loved Before (To All the Boys I've Loved Before, #1) by Jenny Han


To All the Boys I’ve Loved Before is the story of Lara Jean, who has never openly admitted her crushes, but instead wrote each boy a letter about how she felt, sealed it, and hid it in a box under her bed. But one day Lara Jean discovers that somehow her secret box of letters has been mailed, causing all her crushes from her past to confront her about the letters: her first kiss, the boy from summer camp, even her sister's ex-boyfriend, Josh. As she learns to deal with her past loves face to face, Lara Jean discovers that something good may come out of these letters after all.

Love Letters to the Dead by Ava Dellaira

It begins as an assignment for English class: Write a letter to a dead person.

Laurel chooses Kurt Cobain because her sister, May, loved him. And he died young, just like May. Soon, Laurel has a notebook full of letters to the dead—to people like Janis Joplin, Heath Ledger, Amelia Earhart, and Amy Winehouse—though she never gives a single one of them to her teacher. She writes about starting high school, navigating the choppy waters of new friendships, learning to live with her splintering family, falling in love for the first time, and, most important, trying to grieve for May. But how do you mourn for someone you haven't forgiven?

It's not until Laurel has written the truth about what happened to herself that she can finally accept what happened to May. And only when Laurel has begun to see her sister as the person she was—lovely and amazing and deeply flawed—can she truly start to discover her own path.

Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda by Becky Albertalli


Sixteen-year-old and not-so-openly gay Simon Spier prefers to save his drama for the school musical. But when an email falls into the wrong hands, his secret is at risk of being thrust into the spotlight. Now Simon is actually being blackmailed: if he doesn’t play wingman for class clown Martin, his sexual identity will become everyone’s business. Worse, the privacy of Blue, the pen name of the boy he’s been emailing, will be compromised.

With some messy dynamics emerging in his once tight-knit group of friends, and his email correspondence with Blue growing more flirtatious every day, Simon’s junior year has suddenly gotten all kinds of complicated. Now, change-averse Simon has to find a way to step out of his comfort zone before he’s pushed out—without alienating his friends, compromising himself, or fumbling a shot at happiness with the most confusing, adorable guy he’s never met

Groups are wonderful! They help bolster your commitment and motivation, they supply you with opportunities to get ahead on your journey, and they provide support from the other members.
But when it comes to EFT, groups are even more wonderful! Not only is there a synergy created between the tappers increasing the potency of healing received, but even when the tapping isn't related to your particular problem, you still bet to borrow benefits from it!

Note that the amount of people allowed in the tapping circle is limited to 10. If you need to cancel your reservation, please do so at least 3 days in advance so that someone else can come in to the event...

Please arrive early. Doors will open 15 minutes ahead of time and the tapping circle will begin promptly at 2 pm. Late comers will not be allowed in. A late arrival not only disrupts the flow of the circle, shatters the feeling of safety so necessary in healing work, but can also prevent the facilitator from pacing the circle well.

Fee: $20 in advance, $25 at the door.

See you soon!

results.description:
“Equality cannot be achieved under conditions of nearly complete separation...The primary goal must be a single society, in which every citizen will be free to live and work according to his capabilities and desires, not his color.” (from The Kerner Report, 1967)

This February meeting's topic:

Assumptions and experiences we have regarding diversity in our neighborhoods; how can we help to enhance our communities with more integration and increase racial equity?

Please feel free to read this article:


http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/07/white-flight-alive-and-well/399980/


...and/or post additional ideas/articles that come to mind regarding racism in the suburbs, especially any recent current events.


---------------


Below is the general information about this discussion series, posted every month. Post above this is information unique to this month's meeting:

The mission of this monthly group discussion series is to promote awareness of inequality, to build community, and to develop skills that address dismantling racism and oppression within a diverse, compassionate, and culturally sensitive environment.


"A window of opportunity won't open itself." - Dave Weinbaum


Even those of us living in the suburbs care about, and have a role to play in, the anti-racism movement. From frustration, fear, and anger to empathy, passion, and solidarity, this work can bring up a lot for everyone. Our supportive group discussions can help us get some clarity, perspective, and encouragement through the process. We will focus on a different topic each meeting, sometimes including films and discussions about printed materials …encouraging member feedback to help guide future topics.

All are welcome: People of Color, white people…people new to this topic and those involved and active for many years. Come with questions and/or experience to share with others wanting to learn more.

Hosted by Deb and Carlin, members of Boston Knapsack Anti-Racism Group.

If interested, please join Knapsack and RSVP to this meeting date (with no further obligations). Please change your RSVP if your plans change and you can no longer come so we can plan accordingly.

Feel free to post questions here too. We look forward to hearing from you!

Parking is available on the street, and behind and beside the church. Come in the door at the parking lot side of the church, lower level.

Public transportation unfortunately does not go to Medfield.  But most likely someone going to the meeting would be available to give rides to/from the Framingham commuter train station, Riverside T station, or elsewhere. Leave a comment about your needs and we will try to get you to the meeting if you want to join us! Car-pooling rules!

Future 2016 dates: plan for 3rd Sunday of each month, same time. We will post here if that changes.
results.name: Anti-Racism in the ‘Burbs (Medfield, MA)

The entrance to the gym is on Cambridge Street opposite Harvard Market. The nearest intersection to the entrance is Cambridge Street and Roberts Road. The nearest T stop is Harvard Square. The gym is about a ten minute walk from the T stop. Parking near the school on Sundays is generally easy to find, as meters and residential parking rules are generally not enforced on Sundays (parking signs should say "EX SUNDAY" or similar).

results.description:
BEGINNER TANGO: Absolute Beginning

Beginner Tango course is meant for people who either never ever danced Argentine Tango, took few classes long time ago or took few lessons quite recently but are not sure what they know or if they are ready for next level.

You will learn basics necessary to progress further. The material is presented in very organized manner allowing smooth progress from class to class. 

Please note that even if you dance other dances like salsa, swing, zouk or any of Ballroom or American Style dances, even if for years you took ballet, jazz, hip hop or any other of solo dances, you need to take the Beginner level class. The axis, the basis for the dance, musicality and partnership is completely different. Taking those 4 classes might be the life changing experience for you. It is obvious that having dance background helps, but it shall also give you enough experience to know that the basic classes are THE MOST IMPORTANT ONES, as they create a base for all your learning experience. What you don’t know will always and always chase you.

 It’s good to take this course to put all your information in order. You gain the necessary vocabulary and learn all the basic movements to be able to easily follow the explanations in higher level courses. Please respect our commitment to excellence. And make it your own.

No partner necessary. Join at any time – though we do recommend starting at the beginning of the cycle (see: http://www.ultimatetango.com/boston-classes.html for dates). You can take this course as many times as you find necessary for you.

The full course consists of 8 90-minutes classes plus exam/graduation even (about 4 hrs).


SIGN UP NOW: https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/ws?studioid=208847&stype=-7&sTG=25&sView=week
results.how_to_find_us: Follow your intuition and detective instincts. Still cannot find it? Email us at: ultimatetango@gmail.com

On the third Wednesday of the month, the Framingham Artists' Guild gets together for a demonstration. On the following Sunday (3rd or 4th), there is a peer critique group from 2-4 p.m. on the third floor of the Danforth Art Museum in Framingham Center.


We bring 1 or 2 pieces of art to discuss with the group. Many of us bring pieces that are in progress and/or we've reached a wall with. I've been surprised at how much my painting has improved and how helpful it is to meet with other artists once a month to see what we're doing as a group. It is also a nice break in the winter. We bring some munchies to share (byo coffee, tea, etc.) if you wish, and the atmosphere is very friendly and relaxed.

Class Description:


Explore questions such as:   "What kinds of meditations are there for me to try?"   "Am I doing meditation right?"  "How do I establish a foundational practice?"

This course is a great place for any beginner to start.

Also, it's a great next-step for anyone who has attended the Free Community Nights that are part of this meetup group. This course goes deeper into the nuts-and-bolts foundations of how and why to meditate.  It has more structure.

The Meditation Toolbox gives you a taste of what it means to meditate. Over the course of six weeks, this course introduces you to a number of the currently popular formats for meditation: Mindfulness, Creative Visualization, and Progressive Relaxation.

Six Sundays 3pm to 4:15pm. 


2/21/16, 2/28/16, 3/6/16,  3/13/16, 3/20/16, 
(no class for Easter Weekend 3/27) 
our final class is on 4/3/16 
4/10/16 - Reserve for snow make-up

Registration: 
Register here using meetup and pay with your credit card.  The system will automatically instruct you on how to use paypal.  The fee for all six classes is $120.

Space is limited to 25 students.  It is likely that this class will sell out, so please register ASAP.  Because this class sells out every time, there will be no refunds. 


The following is the detailed schedule.  
Each class will follow this schedule. 

2:45pm Arrive early.

Participants should plan to arrive by 2:45pm. This will give everyone time to settle in and find a comfortable seat. We will have the doors open even earlier, by 2:30.  So, it's fine for you to be early.  Also the "chit-chat" time can be the most fun part of the class!

3pm Official start time for class.
The teacher will start giving instructions for how to meditate starting exactly at 3pm.  There will be time to ask any questions you have.  We always start right on time.

Each class includes  


a) Instructions
b) Meditation time, between 15 and 30 minutes, depending upon participant requests. 
c) Wrap-up Discussion

4:15pm - end of class.

Seating:
Our space has a number of chairs and some floor cushions you can borrow. 
Many of us will be seated on the floor. For comfort, you might want to bring a beach towel.   It's also nice to bring a water bottle for yourself.  There is a water cooler, but not cups. 

Teacher:
Gena Bean will be teaching. 

MindfulBoston's Craftsman Teachers will be assisting with this class as part of preparation for their training.

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE:  Panera Bread in Porter Square Shopping Center

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Panera Bread is right next to Dunkin Donuts. If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Sean
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.

results.description:
Join the oldest established permanent floating Community Walk in Cambridge and Environs.  Join the Community Walkers and walkers from five other meetup groups.   Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Weekly Multigroup Community Walk at Fresh Pond + dinner at Shangri La 2/21 4:30

results.description:
After our incredible Soup Swap event, it was a no-brainer for me to organize a Chili Swap for February, but this time it's going to be purely a VEGETARIAN Chili Swap!


Seeing that we have several vegetarians in our lil' cookbook club, I plan to schedules a few feasts and food swaps this year that celebrate delicious (and meatless) recipes.


Being a vegetarian isn't required in order to join this event . . . just your chili recipe needs to be. So, have fun with it!


Feel free to invite your friends. Please add them to your RSVP so we can get an official head count. 

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

HERE'S THE SCOOP . . .

1. Pick 1 recipe. Whether it's a family favorite, or one you've ripped out of a magazine  . . . this event is the perfect opportunity for your culinary ideas to shine. This is a vegetarian event, so double check the ingredients to make sure your recipe qualifies. NOTE :: Once you know what chili you want to make, please post it in the comments section. This will help avoid duplication and inspire a better variety of chili recipes.

2. Containers. I find that the 4 cup twist top storage containers are PERFECT for traveling and storing in the fridge or freezer. Plus, 4 cups of chili makes for a lovely dinner for 2 (or an individual lunch and dinner). See image below. Market Basket has the best selection (or order online). Remember to buy the 32 ounce size. NOTE :: You may want to lightly wash them before filling them with your chili. Sometimes the new plastic smell can be a little too much.

3. How to prepare? Now that we're all on the same page with the containers, let's discuss how many to bring. Each person is asked to bring a MINIMUM of 8 containers — 6 for swapping + 1 for donating + 1 for sampling. You are welcome to bring more than 7 containers, if you're feeling ambitious enough—I say go for it! Essentially, whatever amount you bring for swapping, that's the amount of you'll be bringing home. For example, if you bring 9 containers for swapping, you'll leave with 9 different chilies! NOTE :: Even though 10-20 of us will be coming together for this event, you do NOT have to bring 10-20 containers of chili.

4. Sampling the chili. I'm going to have chafing platters set out to display our chili for easy sampling. No crockpots needed. One less thing to carry . . . hooray! The tables won't really be near an electrical outlet, anyway. So, of the 8+ containers you're bringing, set one aside for sampling. I'll have bowls set up in the chafing dishes for easy access. There will be plenty of spoons, miniature cups, and chips for tasting. NOTE :: Please bring a list of all the ingredients in your chili (or copies of the recipe are great, too). This will be super helpful for everyone involved. Thanks!

5. Swapping rules. Though there will be a great variety of chili for this event, you will NOT be bringing every type of chili home. If you brought 6 containers for swapping, you will be choosing 6 different chilies to take home. During the "tasting" portion of the event, you will be making note of the chili you'd like to potentially swap. NOTE :: There's no guarantee you're going to get the exact chili you want. It's up to the other person to decide if they want to take YOUR chili home, too. I know, it sounds confusing. I'll explain everything at the event. Trust me . . . it's going to be fun and no one will go home empty-handed!

6. Empty-handed. That leads me to the charitable part of the event. With the abundance of incredible food we'll be sharing together, I feel compelled to have each of us donate a container of chili for those in need. So, I've connected with some local families to whom we'll be giving our chili. The following Monday, I'll drive to their homes to deliver the food. This small gesture will make a huge impact on these families. Thank you for doing your part to make this donation possible.

• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • •

Jodi Bee Bakes is the venue for our vegetarian chili swap. I'm really excited to have you meet Jodi and check out all of her incredible vegetarian baked goods. She is so talented!


I'll have water available for us. Jodi also serves teas and coffee.

Other than that . . . let's make some awesome chili and stock our freezers for this frigid time of year.

Again, feel free to invite your friends! Even if they are not members of the cookbook club, they are more than welcome to participate in our Food Swap events. Have them follow the directions listed above, and add them to your RSVP (so we have a head count). The more the merrier, I say!

Feel free to comment with any ideas, questions, or some fun stories!

I hope you can join us.

Warmly,

Jessica
results.name: Food Swap — Vegetarian Chili

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>

group.name: And That's Why You're Single Events - Boston

results.description:
No need to wait for summer to plan some fun getaways in New England!

Come to this free presentation on the book Inns and Adventures: A History and Explorer's Guide to New Hampshire, Vermont and the Berkshires with author Alison O'Leary to get inspired about day and weekend trips.

HIKING -- HISTORY -- HUMOR -- HOSPITALITY

Alison will take you on a virtual trip to secluded swimming holes, scenic bike paths, historic sites and comfy local inns. You'll learn about Thoreau's cold and lonely night on a mountain, how NOT to prepare for a hike, New Hampshire's Eskimo, and trout-crazed fishermen.

Books will be for sale after the event.


Multiple Meetup groups are invited, so allow extra time to network and plan trips!

group.name: Events for Single Professionals of Boston

results.description:
Potluck starts at 5, discussion at 6.

Anthropologist Frederique Apffel-Marglin will discuss her experiences in the Peruvian Amazon, covering the discovery and use of biochar (terra preta) to render poor soils exceptionally fertile, and examining the indigenous cultural worldview that hold valuable lessons for today's global civilization.  You can view an excellent video on her work here.

Professor Apffel-Marglin is founder of the Sachamama Center for Biocultural Regeneration, and is the author of five books, the editor or co-editor of an additional eight books and the author of more than fifty five articles and book chapters. Her interests cover ritual, gender, political ecology, critiques of development, science studies and Andean-Amazonian shamanism. Her areas of specialization are South Asia and the Amazonian Andes.

We're a small non-profit so a $10 donation is requested, but no one will be turned away based on ability to pay.

Helen Snively's house is about halfway between Central Square and Inman Square. Take the MBTA red line to Central Square, exit the station walking down Massachusetts Avenue in the direction of Harvard Square (away from Boston). Walk five blocks and make a right on Lee Street, then walk two blocks past Harvard Street and Broadway. Cross Broadway onto Fayette Street (which will be in front of you), walk down Fayette and make your first left onto Fayette Park (a private way). Helen's house is at One Fayette Park, immediately past the first driveway on the right.  It's a green 4-family. Come up on the first porch and look for a no. 1 on the door.  If you have questions please post to this Meetup,  or call Helen at[masked]-1326.
results.name: Biochar, Amazonia and Global Warming: An Anthropologist's View

results.description:
This was Doreen's idea, from a conversation we had the day of the anniversary party :)

Baby Boomers. Generation X. Generations Y and Z. The Greatest Generation. All of us (or maybe just some of us?) supposedly belong by birth date and place to some sociological entity called a generation, that ties us together in some way and makes us stand out collectively from others. What generation are you? Do you identify with your generation, either in what it meant then or what it means now? Or are you one of those "in between" types (raising hand) that can't figure out which  generation was starting and which was ending when  you were cutting your chops on early adulthood? What lessons has your generation learned as it has gotten a bit older? Or is all this generation stuff a bunch of malarkey and we're all just individuals?


For discussion source material, there's lots of stuff out there written about generations, but here's the Wiki entry on the topic for a starting background:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generation

And a discussion in The Atlantic:

http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/03/here-is-when-each-generation-begins-and-ends-according-to-facts/359589/


Be there or be square!
results.name: My Generation

This event is a combination of a Match Live event and Speed Dating.  Join other fun and friendly singles for a casual and comfortable singles party that you won't want to miss.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

$20 ADMISSION INCLUDES:

*Light Appetizers

*Ice Breaker

*Amex Gift Cards for Ice Breaker Winners

*Supplies/Name Tags

PRE-PAY HERE: http://mixnmatchboston.eventbrite.com

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Here is how it works..

-Upon arrive you will be given a name tag with your code name and number..

-You will also be given a sheet where you can keep track of everyone you meet.

-We will have an ice breaker games throughout the night where you will have a chance to meet others at the event and write down the code names and numbers of those you wish to make a connection with.

-At the end of the night write down the names and the numbers of the people that you met and would like to see again.  You will then hand in your sheet and we will send you the contact info for all the people who have a mutual match with you! You will be able to choose up to 10 people for potential matches.

The Night Will Feature:

Ice Breaker game with prizes -Full menu is available (pay as you go)  -Music played at conversational levels

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending will be coming on their own. 

 What are the age ranges? This event will cater mostly to 20's-late 30's's.

results.description:
We are meeting at the Publick House in Brookline.  Each month we'll have a member driven topic to discuss.  Feel free to offer one in the comment section.

New Idea:  Let's talk about how one creates a Libertarian Society in modern politics.  Large moves?  Small moves?  Have you ever gotten someone to adopt a more Libertarian stance?  Do you have examples or source materials of how others have found success?

This can be challenging in a group that lean toward individualism and independence.  However, isn't there some responsibility as a citizen to educate others and share ideas so that they don't get forced on us through government?  How do you stop a growing government if you don't work together outside of government?

Hope it won't be too cold or snowy to prohibit joining in the conversation.

Thanks!

Chris
results.name: Libertarian Monthly Meetup: How to create a Libertarian society

results.description:
Join Talener for a breakfast program on How to Ask your Boss for a Raise 


Program Overview:

Ready to speak up for what you want? Looking to earn more money in 2016?  Come to this bizworkshop to learn how to feel confident talking to your boss- from how much you should ask for, to the best time to make your request, and finally score the raise you deserve. Planning and preparation are key when you ask for a raise and this workshop will help you with that.

Program Schedule 


8:00 a.m. - 8:30 am 
Registration check-in & continental breakfast 

8:30 a.m. – 9:30 a.m. 
Presentation

9:30 am - 10 am 
Q&A / wrap-up

Speaker -  Rob Laughlin

Rob Laughlin has been an integral part of the growth and success of Talener.  After graduating from Colgate University in 2010, Rob eagerly joined the New York City office, learning the ropes of staffing, technology, and relationship management.  He made such an impact in NYC, which he was asked to help build and develop Talener’s offices in San Francisco and then Boston. As the Director of the Boston office, he has had several teams and dozens of new hires training under him- learning all facets of technology staffing.  From managing the QA & Software team to taking on the challenge of Product & Project Management- his depth of market knowledge within these areas is unmatched.  On a daily basis Rob maintains a staff of 19, keeps up with tech job trends, regularly attends meet ups, and helps candidates get the best role within top companies in Boston.
results.name: BizWorkshop: How to Ask your Boss for a Raise presented by Talener

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
This is part 2 of the 2 part series with Amazon on technical interviews and resumes.

This event will be the workshop portion.

There will be mock interviews with Amazon employees and also personal resume reviews.

The limit to this event is 25 people. If you are unable to attend after you get on the attending list, please change your RSVP to a ‘no’ so that other members will be able to attend.

We realize this attending list will fill up very quickly. We want everyone to get the information and help that they want, so we will have another event soon on mock interviews and/or resume workshops. This event probably won’t be with Amazon, but we will find an equally talented group of hosts so that all of our members who want this kind of help can get it.

As always, WWCode events are intended for ALL women (trans/cis), trans men, and genderqueer folks who are interested in attending. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly and committed to matters of social justice as an organization. Select events may be open to the general public, which will be clearly noted in event descriptions. If you have any questions (or identify differently and want to attend), please message the Directors of this Network.
results.name: Part 2 of Find your next Tech job by: Amazon

results.description:
Come check out a first of its kind event from the MIT Enterprise Forum at the MIT Media Lab with Joi Ito, Paul Brody (formerly of IBM Adept) & others. The event will feature demos from Grid Singularity and LO3 energy, startups that are using Ethereum in energy industry applications. 

Register Here: http://www.mitforumcambridge.org/events/the-blockchain-enabling-a-distributed-and-connected-energy-future/

With the energy industry trending toward a distributed and connected future, entrepreneurs and industry leaders have an opportunity to look ahead for solutions they can start building today. Bitcoin’s underlying protocol, called “the blockchain”, is a distributed consensus-driven infrastructure enabling trust between connected assets. While currently considered only a financial tool, the blockchain’s actual capability is extremely broad.

And just as advances in TCP/IP created vast opportunities for the internet, the blockchain is enabling us to rethink the basic infrastructure of how energy is distributed, accounted for and secured. For example, microgrids could become more resilient with peer-to-peer communications. P2P enables intelligent electronic devices to share information directly without the need for a centralized system.

Also data about the asset activity, and hence the value, can be exchanged instantaneously 24/7, giving rise to new business models and applications for many distributed energy sources as well as increasing the security and reliability of the grid.

We will also have a live demonstration by Grid Singularity on how blockchain can be used in the energy sector.

Join us to learn:

• What is the blockchain, really...isn’t it just a financial tool?

• Why blockchain is and isn’t like the internet. 

• How can entrepreneurs and industry leaders leverage blockchain technology? 

• What is the business impact, opportunities and potential disintermediation? 

• What are the regulatory hurdles and how might blockchain help us address issues of national security?

Our distinguished panel will be moderated by:

Scott Clavenna, CEO, Greentech Media, Inc

Panelists:

• Joi Ito, Director, MIT Media Lab

• Paul Brody, Ernst & Young, America’s Strategy Leader, Technology Sector; Leader, global strategy on Blockchain

• Ed Hesse, CEO, Grid Singularity


• Lawrence Orsini, CEO, LO3 Energy

Sponsored by ConsenSys, GuardTime, and MassCEC

http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/mit-cleantech-committee-explores-how-blockchains-can-distribute-renewable-electricity-1544492
results.name: The Blockchain: Enabling a Distributed & Connected Energy Future

results.description:
Your next big client could be standing right next to you. But how will you answer the question “What do you do”? Whether you make the connection with that prospective client may depend on how you respond. Many solo professionals struggle to figure out how to talk about what they do in a way that gets other people interested in them.

If you have this problem, Andrew Winig can help. He is Your Elevator Pitch Coach. As an entrepreneur and business owner, he discovered that business networking success starts with an engaging 30-second elevator pitch.

During his dynamic and interactive presentation, you will:

• Learn and practice answering the only three questions you’ll ever be asked at any networking event. 

• Learn to develop your own answers to those three questions – answers that are personalized, natural, authentic, and engaging answers.

• Learn advanced techniques you can use immediately to start business conversations, discover relevant connections, and inspire prospects to call you.

• Our natural and conversational approach will open up more opportunities to grow your consultancy and expand your referral network.

The cost is $45 for members and first time attendees. All others are $55. Late registration for members is $55 and $65 for all others. Please remember to go here to register http://spconsultants.org/event-2113757 or bring a check or cash to the event.

Talk description:


Psst! Have you heard about Telerik's newest runtime, NativeScript? It's that thing where you write JavaScript or TypeScript, CSS and XML and create a cross-platform mobile app for iOS and Android using one codebase. Even better, we are integrating Angular 2 as a first-class citizen, working closely with Google to get everything working. Come learn about NativeScript and how it can help you accelerate your app development, as well as how it's leveraging Angular 2. 

Speaker Bio: 


Jen Looper is a Developer Advocate at Telerik with over 13 years' experience as a web and mobile developer, specializing in creating cross-platform educational and fitness-oriented mobile apps. She's a multilingual multiculturalist with a passion for hardware hacking and learning new things every day. Visit her online at http://www.ladeezfirstmedia.com, or via Twitter @jenlooper.

New people probably will play their first few hands, about an hour of instruction, with the meetup organizer and selected players before playing at-large with the rest of the group.

results.description:
The immigration crisis in Europe has brought this question in focus: ‘Is too much immigration without enough integration bad for the host country?’ Angela Merkel and some other EU countries have declared the Multicultural approach ’an utter failure’.

Author Kenan Malik says ‘The experience of living in a society transformed by mass immigration, a society that is less insular, more vibrant and more cosmopolitan, is positive". But he contrasts this with the political process of multiculturalism, which "describes a set of policies, the aim of which is to manage diversity by putting people into ethnic boxes, defining individual needs and rights by virtue of the boxes into which people are put, and using those boxes to shape public policy."

England’s approach is to box in minorities and create separate and competing factions that vie for a slice of the political and social pie. Germany encourages minority groups to stay separate and keep their foreign identity. America has been the most successful at integrating as well as tolerating multiculturalism. Multiculturalism without assimilation causes polarization and the rise of nationalistic political parties.

Group identity forms out of social interaction, i.e. a job, a club or a neighbor. If the interaction is missing, either through forced ‘ghettoization’ or discrimination, real integration is impossible and even undesirable for many immigrants.

Let us explore this complex issue. For further reading please see:

The failure of multiculturalism

In the U.S., Immigrants Find Acceptance; in Europe, Ghettos

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2sJ7eMUBBzc
results.name: Is Multiculturalism Dead in Europe?

You can pay online in advance when you RSVP, and save time for drawing during the session.  Please customize the amount you're paying online according to whether you've paid your membership this month or not ($10 for members, $25 for a one-time drop in- which can be converted to a membership should you come back that same month). You may also pay your $25 monthly membership when that comes due each month online either together with the payment for the drawing session or separately through the link to the left on the sidebar.

Parking is on-street legally for two hours for people without Somerville parking permits, BUT WE PREFER THAT YOU PARK IN THE LOT AROUND BACK, WHICH IS OPEN till about 11PM.  The building is a working factory, so the lot is monitored and safe, though it is a bit of a walk around the building to the front door.   Please do not leave your car in the lot past 11pm or so, or on Saturdays past three pm, as they lock the gate if there is not late shift and your car will be locked in until the next shift starts at the factory.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Please RSVP if possible; helps everyone to know others are coming.  Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from the cubbies, if available) at 7 PM.  We usually wait 5-10 minutes for people to show, but if you arrive later and miss us at the table,  check the small whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what the Event Host (see RSVP list) is wearing that day, and come find us on the walls.  Don't be shy, make an effort to ask around and find the group; we're all friendly.

(NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive by 7, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (usually the round one, furthest from cubbies, if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Tema di discussione: Europa. Quale futuro?

Alcuni dati: La percentuale di italiani fiduciosi nell’UE e’ scesa dal 57% nel 2000 al 30% nel 2015. Inoltre, il 33% degli italiani vorrebbe ritornare alla Lira.
http://www.demos.it/a01216.php?ref=HRER2-3

Siete tutti invitati a postare nello spazio dei commenti (in basso) link ad articoli di giornale o blog sul tema di discussione e contribuire alla discussione online prima dell'incontro.

Come e’ strutturata la serata?

• Mezz’ora per salutarci e ordinare cena (Di norma ci incontriamo per cena)

• Un’ora di discussione sul tema di discussione

• Un’ora di discussione su temi vari di piu’ recente cronaca proposti dai partecipanti

• Varie ed eventuali

Quali sono le regole per la discussione?

1.  Apprezzare la diversita’ di idee

2.  Basare la discussion su fatti e numeri

3.  Sforzarsi di capire il punto di vista degli altri

4.  Criticare i fatti e le politiche, non le persone o i politici

5.  Dare a tutti la possibilita' di parlare

6.  Promuovere un clima di amicizia

(Adattato da: http://ctb.ku.edu/en/table-of-contents/lead...)
results.name: Discussione: Europa: Quale futuro?

results.description:
This month we will be reading The Humans by Matt Haig. 

 From Goodreads, "Our hero, Professor Andrew Martin, is dead before the book even begins. As it turns out, though, he wasn’t a very nice man--as the alien imposter who now occupies his body discovers. Sent to Earth to destroy evidence that Andrew had solved a major mathematical problem, the alien soon finds himself learning more about the professor, his family, and “the humans” than he ever expected. When he begins to fall for his own wife and son--who have no idea he’s not the real Andrew--the alien must choose between completing his mission and returning home or finding a new home right here on Earth."

We meet at the Newton Public Library on the 3rd floor in the rear crescent.  Plenty of free parking available. 

Be sure to check out our goodreads page at: https://www.goodreads.com/group/show/161102-newton-library-scifi-book-club
