"Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic" - Arthur C Clark

In this biweekly meetup, we will explore a wide variety of multimedia and technology based art. Come out to learn and play with programmable lighting, cameras, projectors, generative visual applications and interactive hardware. I am excited to collaboratively explore topics and learn with others. 
Bring projects you are working for feedback and help from members at the end of class. 


-----------------This Week-------------------- 
Cost: $5 donation to the makerspace.

Session 2: Introduction to projection surfaces and Traditional Projection mapping techniques.

We will be introducing the idea of projection mapping and the effects of different projection surfaces, as well as basic mapping with physical masks and VLC

Track 1:
We will be projecting onto different parts of the building outside to see the effects on the projected image.

Track 2:
we will use a circular timelapse slider and various objects (that will be painted white) to film and create something akin to  Michael Naimark's Displacements:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMDr_CFFgWE

Track 3: (If we have a smoke machine)

We will attempt to create dynamic projection surfaces with smoke machine.

Bring:

- Projectors (if you have them) 
- Interesting projection surfaces. 

- Items that have been painted white.
- Smoke/Fog Machine? 
- Bead Curtian
- White paint (Gesso is best)
- Objects to paint white
- Plastics

- Black Paper 
- Laptop 
- Camera
- Download VLC Media Player 
- Paintbrushes/Paint

Inspiration:

Tony Oursler: 

https://youtu.be/DZSOJe2wu-c

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bMDr_CFFgWE

results.description:
This coming Monday the unstoppable Lamont Price headlines at Cityside Bar.

Lamont Price is a hilarious oxymoron. His comedy is edgy and laidback, off the beaten path and anchored in social consciousness. He doesn’t care in that cool sort of way, and he doesn’t hold back. His commanding stage presence electrifies the crowd.

Price’s love for comedy started nearly a decade ago with a stand-up comedy course, and has become an obsession with winning over a room. He’s shared the stage with comedy powerhouses Dane Cook(Opened for him during his platinum selling "Retaliation" recording, Pablo Francisco, Patrice O’Neal, Tommy Davidson and John Witherspoon, Bill Burr, Rich Vos, Donnell "Ashy Larry" Rawlings to name a few. He’s gotten ink The Boston Globe, The Boston Herald, The Dig, Performer Magazine etc. A regular at the Wilbur Theater, Nick’s Comedy Stop and Comedy Studio and Comix at Foxwoods, and on campus at many colleges, Price’s star is rising…and heading west.

In New York, he’s performed at Stand-Up New York, Gotham Comedy Club(Where he won the New York Underground Comedy Festival), and NY Comedy Club. Next stop, Hollywood. While entertaining the likes of Johnny Knoxville at the Sam Adams Grill & Groove Summer Jam, he met a director with a script. Price stars in Liquid Lunch Productions’ feature Overserved, an unapologetic comedy about working in a Boston bar.
Price has been invited to the prestigious Aspen Rooftop Comedy Festival and Montreal's Just For Laughs Festival as well as being named one of Comedy Central's "Comics to Watch". Price can also be heard regularly on Sirius/XM

results.description:
Please note, this event is being hosted by the Resident Design Committee of the Boston Society of Architects. While an RSVP is not required to attend, the BSA has requested that those signing up RSVP on their event page so they can help plan the event more efficiently.

Tiny Houses

Aiming to save money, reduce environmental impact, or just to simplify life, many people are joining the tiny house movement. The average size of an American home is about 2500 square feet, whereas tiny houses typically range from 100 to 400 square feet of living space. To make that small of a space livable, clearly good design is crucial.

This month we welcome two guests, both architects, who have designed tiny houses. Addison Godine has designed a few tiny houses for Getaway, a Harvard startup that rents out tiny houses a couple hours out of the city for $99/night. Tracey Powell designed her own tiny house which was featured at ABX in 2015. Both will speak about the specific challenges of designing tiny houses, including systems, material, and dimensional constraints.

Breakfast will be provided by ASSA ABLOY.
results.name: Boston Society of Architects Tiny House Presentation

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
New Parents' Support Group (0-6 months) - $5 paid to Mama & Me

The first months of parenthood are a wonderful time to meet new friends and make connections in your community. The New Parents' Support Group is a forum to connect with other new moms and dads by discussing issues and challenges related to being a new parent. This group provides an open forum to acquire information, share ideas with other parents, and reflect on your own process of adjusting to parenthood. Guided discussion topics will emerge based on the interest of parents in the group. Experts will visit periodically to address relevant parenting topics such as breastfeeding support, sleep issues, cloth diapering, baby sign language, introducing solids, etc.

Mama & Me provides a clean, safe space for you and your baby, complete with a nursing and diaper changing area, free parking and elevator access. If needed, please bring your own boppy (BYOB) for comfort. Visit our neighbor Ula Cafe, for a child-friendly space to meet up with friends for lunch after the group has ended.

More information at http://www.mymamaandme.com/new-parents-support-group/

********
Note from Robbie: Jess & I started attending this weekly drop-in when our little one was just 2 weeks old. We may not be there every week, but the facilitator is great and the group is friendly.
results.name: New Parents' Support Group (weekly drop-in)

Publicity can provide any business with a massive advantage.. but how can you get it for free as a startup? Join this webinar to learn how to generate buzz for your company, how to work with reporters, and the latest strategies for getting publicity, from two serial entrepreneurs who have both been featured on some of the world's largest publications (for free). 

This webinar will be hosted by Adeo Ressi (Founder & CEO of the Founder Institute), and feature special guest Philip Kaplan. 

Philip has been a serial entrepreneur since the 90s, creating massive press for himself while starting companies like Adbrite (one of the world’s pioneering online ad networks), Tiny Letter (a free newsletter service acquired by MailChimp), and F**ked Company (a massively popular parody site that chronicled the dot.com crash in the early 2000s). Currently, he is the Founder & CEO of DistroKid (a service that musicians use to get their music into iTunes, Spotify, and other digital music stores). 

On this webinar you will learn: 

- How to generate buzz for yourself, or your business/ startup 

- How to work effectively with reporters 

- The latest strategies for getting free publicity 

We hope you will join us!

results.description:
Look forward to seeing everyone at Meadhall on February 23rd. We have reserved the upstairs bar area.  

Light appetizers will be provided by BGI.  

BGI was founded in 1999 as a nonprofit research organization. Over the years, BGI has grown into a multinational genomics company with significant global operations, including sequencing laboratories based in the US, Europe, Hong Kong and mainland China.

BGI has acted as a reliable outsourcing partner for the biopharmaceutical industry for many years, providing a wide array of regulatory-compliant genomic services for pharmacogenomics, including:
- Next Generation Sequencing services including: RNAseq, Whole Genome Sequencing, Exome Sequencing, Targeted Resequencing, and Epigenomics services.
- Tumor Profiling
- SNP, mutation and biomarker analysis
- Genotyping

Our experience in high-capacity, high- throughput instrumentation, bioinformatics capabilities, and our long history in large population–scale genomics and data analysis, means that BGI is uniquely positioned to support pharmaceutical companies throughout the entire drug development and production process, from the preclinical phase through to clinical trials phases I, II and III. This ensures that that our partners are able to develop drugs more efficiently, safely, and economically.

To learn more about our services or for a customized solution for your project needs, please don’t hesitate to contact us at [masked].

results.description:
CALLING ALL HEART PLAYERS!

                        Tonight we'll play HEARTS

        Bring your decks of cards and let the games begin!

Come join the C&C crew over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford for a night of HEARTS.  There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play a few tables of HEARTS.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome  new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games...

Although we start playing around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: HEARTS NIGHT  with  Good Friends and Food in Medford

Upstatement's in-house prototyping library, UpBase, and how it's evolved to 1.0:

http://upbase.upstatement.com/

We've been refining this for the last five years or so, and it's gone through a number of iterations. It's a system of simple functions and helpers for quickly building layouts and interfaces. We 'll talk about how we got here, how we use it, and where it might go next. 


Manipulating CSS with physical inputs

We've been experimenting with generative design systems and manipulating site design and aesthetics based on physical inputs. We'll go through how we built the hardware and what we might be able to do with it in the future!


There will be drinks and pizza courtesy of Upstatement. Thank you!


Gathering and networking at 6, talks start at 6:45. 

Presenters: 

Mike Swartz: Mike is a partner at Upstatement who has been tinkering with hardware and trying to make it do weird things to the web.

Andy Rader Senior Designer, Upstatement: Andy creates beautiful user experiences, combining his skills in design and code with his passion for typography and art. He's a self-taught man of many talents, plays more than a dozen musical instruments and lives for vintage tiki bars. @jarader

Nathan Hass Senior Designer, Upstatement: Multidisciplinary designer who fuels his passion for design with his curiosity and enthusiasm for creative problem solving. "Skate" is an up-and-coming Blades of Steel contender 'round these parts. @natronic

---

CASCADE BOS is a community for tech-minded designers and design-savvy developers. We aim to be a community where members can learn from each other about ever-changing front-end technology and web design trends. CASCADE BOS is run by volunteers.
results.name: "UpBase" and "Manipulating CSS with physical inputs"

results.description:
Join us as we continue to kick-off our Country Line Dance Lessons for 2016 in Braintree! Charleene's Country Line Dance Lessons take place Tuesdays in Braintree and Wednesdays in Weymouth and she has a great team helping her teach the classes. Beginner lessons @ 6-7pm and Advanced lessons @ 7-8pm. This is a fun way to learn several country line dances with others and get in a nice workout. You'll then be able to join in the fun when you are out and see other people line dancing. Cost is $10.

What to Bring/Wear:

~Water (they do not provide drinks and you will get thirsty)

~Cowboy Boots (if you have them), boots or shoes w/ heels; no sneakers!

~Comfy Clothes (Remember, you're dancing!  Layers will help as the room is cool to start.)

~$10 Cash


Please plan to arrive a few minutes early if this is your first time attending. 

Please note I am planning to attend no matter who shows up!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Country Line Dance Lessons in Braintree Kick-Off!

Tuesday, February 23rd @ 6-8pm

Sons of Italy

161 King Hill Road, Braintree, MA 02184

Phone #n/a

Website: n/a

Meeting Location: Please meet inside the hall. Pay and register (if it's your first time) at the welcome table and join us on the dance floor!


Host/Organizer: Angela 

Min/Max: None at this time as I am attending no matter what and the room can accommodate a few dozen people.

Guests: 2 Adults (21+) per Member
Price Range: $10pp for lessons

Cash Only Policy: Please bring cash! Paying for our meals in cash allows us to avoid the confusion of having the waitstaff run multiple credit card slips and generally helps to keep things simpler for everyone.

Cost/Fees: Cost is $10pp for the lesson. There are currently no fees associated with this event aside from paying for your food and beverages. If you want to make a voluntary contribution to SSHBSC I will be happy to collect and mail it to Roger.

RSVP Deadline: Tuesday @ 5pm

Inclement Weather Reschedule Date: TBD; FYI - This happens weekly and they don't dance if the governor says to stay off the road.

No-Show Policy: People who RSVP "Yes" to events are expected to exercise common sense and common courtesy. That means making your best effort to keep any commitments that you make, but if necessary doing your best to notify the Event Organizer or (preferably, if it's the day of the event) the venue if something comes up after the RSVP deadline. If you find yourself unable to attend an event that you've RSVPed "Yes" to and you cannot either change your RSVP or let the venue know, please do contact the Event Organizer when you're able to, just to let us know that you're okay and that you're still interested in attending events. Please be advised that any Assistant Organizer (AO) or the Group Organizer (GO) can remove a member from Social Fun who has 3 No-Shows in the past 3 months. Additionally, Organizers may disallow members with 2 or more "No Show" marks from attending their events. 

Hey, please attend if you say you are going to do so.  Please change your RSVP or, if you can't because it's too late to do so, please post a comment or message me if you are unable to attend.  It's the nice thing to do.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Parking: Free and ample parking on-site.

Directions/Location Overview: Located near the end of King Hill Road on the right-hand side, King Hill Road is located at the lighted intersection of Pond and Granite Streets. Luke's Convenience Store is on the corner in the intersection and BASE is being it on the corner of Pond Street.

From Route 93: Take Exit 6/Route 37 heading south towards 5 corners. At 5 corners bear right staying on Grnaite Street keeping Bertucci's/Panera Bread on your left and Dunkin Donuts on your right. Follow about 1 mile thru one set of lights. At next set of lights you will take a right onto King Hill Road. Follow King Hill Road till you get to the hall on your right.
results.how_to_find_us: Please meet inside the hall. Pay and register (if it's your first time) at the welcome table and join us on the dance floor!

results.description:
Hello Hardwarians! 

We're back with another round of companies for you!

It's all about the teams, so each month we have 3 hardware startups present. They have time to pitch, take questions, and demo.  This month's meetup will be located at Bolt in Downtown Crossing.

Sponsor

Microchip Technology Inc. (NASDAQ: MCHP) is a leading provider of microcontroller, mixed-signal, analog and Flash-IP solutions, providing low-risk product development, lower total system cost and faster time to market for thousands of diverse customer applications worldwide. Headquartered in Chandler, Arizona, Microchip offers outstanding technical support along with dependable delivery and quality. Local to Boston, Microchip sales and applications support a wide variety of companies from hardware start-ups to large, multi-billion dollar enterprises.

Format

6.00P: Arrival, food, drinks

6.30P: A word from our sponsor: 

6.40P: Presenter #1: Immedia

6:55P: Presenter #2: Skreens

7:10P: Presenter #3: Sense

8.00P: Kick you all out

Hope to see you there!
results.name: Boston Hardware Startup Meetup #27

results.description:
Bring your laptop, current project(s), and prepare to make some progress! Folks have walked away grinning from our previous project nights after solving problems that had been frustrating them for a while. We'll do introductions around 6:30pm to get a sense of the skill set in the room, then settle in to work.

These sessions are super-informal and low-key. We always have attendees of all experience levels--don't feel like you have to be "good" or know "something" before you can come hang out with us. If you feel like the term pre-beginner applies to you, project nights are a great time to meet other code-curious women and start figuring out what you need to learn to start working toward your goals. We guarantee that you'll meet someone who will nerd out about what you are interested in and make you excited to start tinkering.

On hand to help out will be:

Mel Choyce is a design engineer at Automattic, where she works mostly on design and front-end development. Feel free to ask her about UI design, UX and user testing, HTML/CSS, and any beginner WordPress questions.

Paige Eaton is a librarian turned Drupal developer. She loves sports, games, and long walks on the beach, but not too long. It's really tiring to walk on sand. Paige is helpful for questions about UX, HTML, CSS, some PHP, and is a good listener/sounding board for ideas & projects.

Jessica Pang is an interactive designer at ExtensionEngine, a web/mobile app development company. She has spent the past 3 years there working on projects from the ground up. Jessica has experience in wire framing, branding, user experience design, and user interface design.

Reasons why you should come work with us:

Accountability: it's the perfect way to get away from it all (other work, family/housemates, the laundry) and work.

Nerd friends: you'll meet other women who are coding and creating awesome stuff.

Practice: it's an opportunity to practice some of the skills you've picked up if you've taken some of our classes.

Brain exchange: you can ask your neighbor for help on a bug or teach a n00b how to do something you've mastered.

No agenda: Have non-technical work to do? Need a sounding board? Looking for feedback? Just want to get your inbox under control? You're welcome too!

Perks:

+ Fast, reliable internet

+ Fancy, schmancy (i.e., comfy) Aeron chairs

+ Way more fun than working in a coffee shop =)


Location

11th floor, Room Singapore

Cambridge Innovation Center

1 Broadway

Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall / MIT

Street parking is available, though limited, on Broadway St., Third St., and Main St.


Access

Please bring photo ID. Upon entering 1 Broadway you'll check in with security. Tell them you're visiting the 11th floor.

Doors open at 6:00pm; if you arrive before 6:00pm, please wait in the 1st floor lobby, as no one will be available to let you in upstairs.

Once you depart the elevator, you'll find glass doors that are locked. Look for the door sign.

We're meeting in the room labeled Singapore.

Join us for an exploration of how evidence can be gathered, and organized, and (most importantly) harnessed to create effective learning experiences. 


We promise a compelling conversation and hands-on Meetup that will dive into:

• A rationale for using evidence in a rigorous way

• An exploration of why many designers do not use evidence-based practices

• Different types of evidence critical to guiding design

• A look at the positive effects from using evidence in instructional design and development

• A process for gathering, organizing, and using evidence

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

results.description:
EAT TO THRIVE: 
10-week course to Life Long Healthy Habits Healthy Living 

, March 1 -May 10  6:00 – 9:00 pm

  Come be motivated to change your life!!

Where:  

46 Marcellus Drive, Newton ,MA

Upcoming course information – apply today – space is limited 
(online/phone[masked])  http://www.optimumhealthsolution.org

Info Session: Tuesday, February 23, 2016, 6:30 – 8:30 pm

EAT TO THRIVE COURSE OPTIONS/TRACKS AND PRICING

1. AUDIT: This is for students whose goal it is to gain exposure to the subject matter. Whether they have an illness or simply a thirst for knowledge of the subject matter, they will be permitted to attend, borrow DVDs and participate.  They will be required to prepare and contribute to the five course meal. However, there are no attendance or written/oral requirements.  Fee: $555

2. REPEATING AUDIT STUDENTS:  (returning graduates) Fee: $355

3. HEALTH EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: This track is for students whose goal it is to apply the knowledge from this course to a career path. Successful completion of this program will lead to an Optimum Health Solution (OHS) Certificate of Completion. Requirements for this course are attendance at 8 out of 10 classes; a passing grade on two take-home essay tests; and a presentation with hands-on learning for a group of at least 5 people (to be described more in detail on the website). Fee: $755 

4. REAL KIDS REAL FOOD HEALTH (RKRF) EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: 
This track is designed for teachers or students seeking a career path in teaching upper elementary to middle school-age children and want to gain expertise in the subject area of healthy foods. Students enrolled in this certificate program will have an additional 6 hours of one-on-one teacher training with master educator, Betsy Bragg; students will learn kid-tested recipes and techniques for teaching and presentation; students will have the opportunity to observe other master teachers, participate in a practicum, and design their own lesson plan. Successful completion of this program will lead to an OHS RKRF Certificate of Completion.  Betsy’s background includes 48 years of teaching Elementary through University levels, M.Ed Stanford and Harvard Universities, M.A. Boston University, licensed in Special Education Lesley University, licensed in English Second Language University of Massachusetts. Fee $800. Repeating students (graduates) Fee $600

5. Eat to Thrive Educator Training Certificate: This track is designed for repeating students who want to teach a section of the OHS Eat to Thrive Program. In addition to the 10-week program, students will be given an additional 6 of hands-on training in all aspects of the curriculum and administration. As OHS plans to expand its Eat to Thrive program to other locations in Massachusetts, paid teachers will be required to hold this certification.  Prerequisite: Students must have taken an Eat to Thrive course and hold the Health Educator Certificate. Fee: $650

results.description:
Unfortunately, tonight's speaker was taken ill and is not able to make the event. Instead, we'll have a round table discussion about agile marketing and programmatic marketing. Not quite the promised speaker, my apologies for the inconvenience. 


John Cass

PulsePoint's Francois de Laigue provides an overview of the technology how it can best be used by Agile Marketers

Having deep expertise in programmatic, Francois will break down the basics on programmatic and how agile marketers can take advantage of the data, scale and efficiency of programmatic for their marketing campaigns. Francois will explain the nature of programmatic, highlight successful examples of brands using it and explain what marketers should look for when partnering with a programmatic technology company. 

Francois de Laigue is VP of Operations at PulsePoint, where he leads account management and operations across the company’s global, programmatic platform. 

Prior to PulsePoint, Francois headed up data and operations around AudienceScience’s global trading desk, where he hired and managed a 70+ person team in charge of client services, campaign management, data management, ad operations and big data analytics across both AudienceScience's DSP and DMP.


Before AudienceScience, Francois was in charge of building out the analytics function for Microsoft's next generation of real-time bidding (RTB) and programmatic advertising platforms, working across the Microsoft Ad Exchange (MAX) and the Microsoft Media Network (MMN). While at Microsoft, he authored the first behavioral targeting model at Microsoft developed to identify upsell and cross-sell opportunities.  

Earlier in his career Francois held various positions at A6 Corporation, Accenture and Orange, and was a first Lieutenant in the French army.

Francois de Laigue holds a Master's degree in Management from MIT and a Master's degree in Computer Science from top French engineering school Ecole Polytechnique.

Networking from 6:30 PM to 6:45 PM

Speaker 6:45 PM

Location Sponsor:

We want to thank the folks at DistrictHall for their generous sponsorship of the location. 

Learn more at DistrictHall

Let's climb at Central Rock Gym in Watertown! Meet by the cubbies/bench facing the rock wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (JZ) am usually wearing bright green and have a blue harness and climbing shoes.  We usually climb for ~3 hrs and welcome all skill levels.  If you come late, come find us or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Tuesdays and can help you find the group.

You will need to fill out the rock gym waivers and TAKE their Belay test, if you haven't already.

Day Passes
- $20 Adult*
- $16 Student/Military
* There are also punch-cards available to get 10 Day-Passes for the price of 9 visits

Gear Rental
- $8 Full Package
- $5 Harness
- $5 Shoes
- $2 Chalk
- $2 Belay Device

February 23, 2016 at 6:30 PM
Belmont Media Center, 9 Lexington St, Belmont MA

Betul Kacar, Ph.D., Research Fellow and Astrobiologist, Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University. Dr. Kacar is also Global Science Coordinator of ELSI Origins of Life Network, Tokyo Institute of Technology, and Co-Founder of SAGANet.org, the online astrobiology grassroots network, an initiative of the Blue Marble Space Institute of Science.

Dr. Kacar discusses the young field of paleogenomics, and how researchers are able to unravel the genetic evolution of modern organisms. Genetic Time Travel

results.description:
For this meetup we are excited to be joined by Josh McKenzie, Cassandra Committer and Windows Lead for DataStax who will be discussing two exciting topics: Cassandra on Windows and Change-Data-Capture on Cassandra: a study in compromise.

What You'll Learn At This Meetup:

Cassandra on Windows: As of release 2.2, Windows is an officially supported platform for OSS Cassandra. It was a long road to get here and there's still some sharp edges, so we're going to cover how we got here, what to watch out for, and where we might explore in the future of Cassandra on Windows. We're also going to cover the elephant in the room: "Why bother?"

Change-Data-Capture: We'll spend some time discussing the design process that's gone into  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CASSANDRA-8844 and the difficulties we've hit, taking into account where C* falls with regards to CAP theorem.

About Josh McKenzie:

Josh McKenzie is a Cassandra Committer and the Windows Lead for DataStax. He led the effort in adding Windows support to Cassandra and isn't ashamed to be running Windows 10 on 5 machines in his home today. He cut his teeth in high performance code in the high frequency trading sector in Chicago but moved on to the complex world of Cassandra in 2014 and hasn't looked back since.


*Big thank you to Spotify for hosting! Food and drink will be served, hope to see you all there.
results.name: Cassandra on Windows: Doubleplusgood &  Change-Data-Capture on Cassandra

Join us for a panel discussion with Drafted, Intrepid, Medisafe, and TripAdvisor, plus time to meet other developers and mobile marketers over pizza and pops. We'll hear from our panel about topics like organic and paid user acquisition, social media campaigns, email and push tactics, best practices for measurement, discoverability and deep linking, ASO/SEO, and more.

The Panel
Brian Carr, VP, Medisafe

Vinayak Ranade, CEO, Drafted


The Plan

7.40pm Q&A from audience

The Sponsors
Localytics is the leading marketing and analytics platform for mobile and web apps. Localytics works with some of the world’s most well-known brands, like eBay, Salesforce, Microsoft and The New York Times, helping them create great experiences for their customers and maximizing profitability, engagement, lifetime value, and loyalty. Localytics provides analytics and marketing for 1 billion devices across more than 20,000 apps. Localytics’ headquarters are located in Boston, MA. Learn more at www.localytics.com. 

Founded in 2004, Brightcove is a pioneering force in the world of online video. We created and defined the online video platform category and have spent more than a decade helping the largest media companies and brands in the world to tell their story.

With our powerful solutions for delivering and monetizing video across devices, Brightcove helps more than 5,500 customers in over 70 countries achieve success with video.

Branch provides free deep linking technology to mobile app developers and marketers. We're on a mission to help you grow their business through deep linking, and allow users to discover content inside mobile apps. In 14 months Branch grew to a company with 50 employees and raised 18 million in funding. In the last year, Branch has gone from powering deep linking for 6 million users to more than 1 billion users.

Grow.co is a community of growth marketing professionals and brands, comprised of more than 7,000 acquisition and retention-oriented professionals. We serve the community through industry summits, a weekly newsletter, a jobs board, and an online forum.

Mobile Growth meetups are powered by Branch and Grow.co

results.description:
***PLEASE ADD YOUR TOPIC SUGGESTIONS TO THE COMMENT SECTION OR SEND A MESSAGE TO THE ORGANIZERS BY TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 23***

This will be the sixth session of our new Current Events meetup series (**NO prior attendance required). We aim to have reoccurring discussions moving forward so we can stay abreast of local, national, and global anti-racism issues together as a community. We have seen a surge in media coverage within the racial justice movement over the past year. It can get overwhelming trying to keep up with all the stories, events, anniversaries, policies, and debates that touch on racial justice in some way. Let's pool our collective knowledge and discuss what's going on - locally, nationally, and globally - within the realm of anti-racism. This will be a great opportunity to share our sources, our stories, and our knowledge to keep everyone informed of the way things are changing, and unfortunately, the many ways in which things are staying the same.

The topics will change from month to month depending upon what's happening in the world, but many stories may carry over. Have a current event you'd like to discuss at the meeting that isn't listed below? Have a helpful article you'd like to share? Want to look at a story from an unexplored angle? Know of a local story/action/event that may not be getting coverage? Great! Feel free to post in the comments section below or email one of the facilitators with your ideas. We hope you'll come to this session willing to share your thoughts and knowledge on the events of the past month. If not, feel free to listen, learn, and participate in some really important discussions. Looking forward to seeing you all there and continuing this new series! 

Possible February Current Events:

- Beyonce's halftime performance & BLM

- Black History Month...

- Oregon Standoff ends (with 1 fatality)

- Hollywood: OscarsSoWhite, white actor to play Michael Jackson, Meryl Streep response to lack of diversity

- GOP/Dems in NH & SC 

- Black Princeton Professor handcuffed for parking tickets

- Cam Newton superbowl celebrations backlash

Review from January:


- Flint Water Crisis

- Boston Latin Schools battle racism
results.name: Current Events February

results.description:
VerBaLizAtiOn presents


AFRO-CINEMA

Boston's longest-running (16th year) open mic gathering presents, Afro-Cinema: an evening of important films (movie or documentary) followed by a discussion about the film.

7:00pm SHARP (doors open at 6:30pm)
Free will donation
Light refreshments

FEATURE  FILM: BLACK POWER MIXTAPE[masked]

Released: April 1, 2011

Run Time: 120 minutes

During the rise of The Black Power Movement in the 60s and 70s, Swedish Television journalists documented the unfolding cultural revolution for their audience back home. They were granted unprecedented access to prominent leaders such as Angela Davis, the SNCC's Stokely Carmichael and Black Panthers founders Huey P. Newton and Bobby Seale.

Director Goran Hugo Olsson presents this mixtape, highlighting the key figures and events in the movement, as seen in a light completely different than the narrative of the American media at the time.

Talib Kweli, Erykah Badu, Abiodun Oyewole, John Forte, and Robin Kelley are among the many important voices providing narration and commentary, adding modern perspective to this essential time capsule of African-American history.

Snacks and drinks will be available however you're also welcome to bring food for yourself and/or to share.


For more information, contact

Vernon VCR Robinson at[masked]<a></a> or [masked]

results.description:
WATERMARK - Trailer
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QpvarPeJpkM&sns=em


How does water shape us, and how do we shape water? Come explore this compelling question by traveling around the world to discover how different cultures relate to the source of all life! Experience diverse stories from around the globe about our relationship with water: how we are drawn to it, what we learn from it, how we use it, and the consequences of that use. See massive floating abalone farms off China's Fujian coast and the construction site of the biggest arch dam in the world -- the Xiluodu -- six times the size of the Hoover. Visit the barren desert delta where the mighty Colorado River no longer reaches the ocean, and the water-intensive leather tanneries of Dhaka. Witness how humans are drawn to water, from the U.S. Open of Surfing in Huntington Beach to the Kumbh Mela in Allahabad, where thirty million people gather for a sacred bath in the Ganges. Meet scientists who drill ice cores two kilometers deep into the Greenland Ice Sheet, and explore the sublime pristine watershed of Northern British Columbia. Watermark is directed by multiple award-winning filmmaker Jennifer Baichwal and renowned photographer Edward Burtynsky, and is the third part of Burtynsky's Water project, which includes a book "Burtynsky: Water" and a major photographic exhibition. Filmed and produced by Nicholas de Pencier and three years in the making, this award-winning film was shot in stunning 5K ultra high-definition video and is full of soaring aerial perspectives. Come be immersed in a magnificent force of nature that is too often taken for granted! Start your visit at the Lowell National Historical Park Visitor Center on 246 Market Street where general information is offered. To get to our free parking lot, enter 304 Dutton Street, Lowell MA, 01852 as the destination.

Information about additional park sites can be found here.
Please note: Vehicle parking at most National Park locations is available only at city garages for a fee or on street metered parking. You are welcome to park at the Visitor Center parking lot for any park activities and either take the trolley (in season) or walk to these National Park sites.

Getting to the Visitor Center
From Interstate Route 495 take Exit 35C on to the Lowell Connector
From Route 3 take Exit 30A if traveling southbound, Exit 30B if traveling northbound.

• Take the Lowell Connector to Exit 5B Thorndike Street.
• Continue right on to Thorndike Street, which becomes Dutton Street.
• At the third traffic light continue straight under the overpass.
• At the next light turn right into the Visitor Center Parking Lot. Free parking is available here during Park operating hours in the gated section of the lot with ticket validation at the Visitor Center.
• From the lot, follow the set of steps located behind the flag pole and continue walking through the courtyard. The Visitor Center will be on your left.
The 2016 "Land, Air & Water" Eco Film Series is co-presented by Lowell Parks & Conservation Trust and the Lowell Film Collaborative with support from Lowell National Historical Park!

CLICK HERE to view the entire 2016 Eco Film Series Schedule
results.name: Watermark- new ECO Film

results.description:
Deepening into the practice of Speaking Circle turns will support you in continuing  to develop full presence in front of groups.  Being in Relational Presence with your audience is the key.

Relational Presence, the foundation of Speaking Circles, is a precondition for all masterful communication. When this state becomes your default mode of approaching every communication, you effortlessly step into a natural flow. 

Developing your capacity for Relational Presence is like strengthening a muscle that has been neglected. Unlike the struggle that physical workouts are for many, this exercise is designed to be highly pleasurable. There may be some initial confusion, discomfort, self-doubt but hang in there and do the reps no matter how it feels or what you are thinking.  With practice you will find . . . 

* Speaking Circles support you to access your natural public presence, along with your capacity to unselfconsciously express passion and purpose.

* Reach hearts, minds and souls every time through the practice of being in a Speaking Circle.

* Transmit your message and content with ease to groups of any size by practicing attunement with one listener at a time.

* Give up conventional notions of "public speaking" and discover the magic of authentic intimacy with audiences.
results.name: Deepening into Speaking From Presence

results.description:
Two talks about specialized tools for testing web applications, sponsored by Klaviyo and Twilio.


Michael Mintz, SeleniumBase: Reliable browser testing

Web applications have to be tested in real browsers to know they are working properly.  The most common tool for this is Selenium, but anyone who has used it knows that it can be cumbersome and unpredictable.  Michael will explain some of Selenium's pitfalls, and show us the layer he's written on top, SeleniumBase, which solves many of its problems.

Jay Luker, Pytest plugins and Ghost Inspector

Pulling all the pieces of a web test together can be difficult, using disparate tools and services to cover all your bases.  Jay has written a pytest plugin to connect pytest to a browser testing service, Ghost Inspector.  He'll walk through the whats, hows & whys of pytest plugins, and how his plugin lets you hook Ghost Inspector's test execution into the pytest framework.

Pizza will be provided, by Klaviyo.  Drinks afterwards at Meadhall, sponsored by Twilio.
results.name: February Presentation: Testing Web Applications

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.

Our weekly work session will be at the Cambridge Innovation Center in Kendall Square, on the FOURTH FLOOR, in the CAFE. These Hack Nights are our time to meet in person to work on and discuss civic tech projects. Come by to say hi and hack with us!

Transportation
The Red Line stop for CIC is Kendall. For those who drive, there is a pay parking lot underneath the building, and limited meter parking in the area. Additionally, the MIT Hayward St lot is free after 5pm. Please make sure to check in with security when you arrive.

Schedule
7:00pm - Opening remarks, project updates, announcements
7:20pm - New member orientation
8:00pm - Hacking!

During the event, join our Hackpad for announcement links and collaborative note taking.

To ensure that Code for Boston is a welcoming space for all, staff and participants are held to our Code of Conduct.
results.name: Weekly Hack Night

results.description:
64 Degrees on February 1st!!! With that rate we might not have any ice at all this season!!! Don’t you worry, here at East Coast Divers we have a solution!!!

This year we have decided to do something different. We are joining forces with Adirondack Scuba and traveling to 1000 Islands in upstate New York to dive great wrecks up there.

In addition to students who want to work on their ice diving certification, we extending this invitation to certified ice divers to explore with us wrecks of Alexandria Bay covered by amazing ice formations.

Join us for Ice Diving!!!

Learn the skills to safely enjoy the beauty of crystal clear water and Amazing Ice Formations. Learn how to be an effective site leader, line tender, safety diver, and dive buddy for your next ice dive. You never know what this winter is going to bring. Be prepared, and join us for this winter's ice diving course! 

Course Fees are $400 and includes the use of all Ice Diving Specific Tools, Instructor Fees, One Academic Session, and Four Dives Minimum (2 days). Personal Dive Gear, Accommodations, and Travel Expenses Not Included.


If you already ice certified, the fee to join is $100 for all 4 dives.

Please call the shop at (617)[masked] or send us email to (brookline at ecdivers dot com) to reserve your spot - NO SPOTS RESERVED ON MEETUP!!!

Dates of upcoming program:

February - MA/Alexandria Bay NY
Class - 23rd
Dives - 27th & 28th

results.description:
We've been talking about reading this book for a while, so I'm thinking we should do it! We'll meet at Asgard near Central Square - you all know how I like my restaurants to fit a theme. "Shadow is a man with a past. But now he wants nothing more than to live a quiet life with his wife and stay out of trouble. Until he learns that she's been killed in a terrible accident.

Flying home for the funeral, as a violent storm rocks the plane, a strange man in the seat next to him introduces himself. The man calls himself Mr. Wednesday, and he knows more about Shadow than is possible.

He warns Shadow that a far bigger storm is coming. And from that moment on, nothing will ever he the same..."

results.description:
Mind wandering is the opposite of mindfulness. But there is research to show that some (but not all) forms of mind wandering are helpful.

Join us for a meditation in which first settle ourselves by paying attention to the breath, and then we let go of that focus and allow our mind to daydream and to envision new ideas.

After the meditation, there will be discussion.

Then, if there is interest, some of us may go out for a bite to eat in Harvard Square.

This meditation came up in my dialogue with Gleb Tsipursky, author of Finding Your Purpose Using Science. The video can be found here:

http://www.patheos.com/blogs/gregepstein/2016/02/finding-meaning-with-science-and-mindfulness/
results.name: Intentional Daydreaming Meditation

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
EMBRACING IMPERMANENCE                                                                                                     a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | FEB. 9th - MARCH 8th


7:00 - 8:30pm

Learn how to remain happy when change feels like a dark storm cloud blotting out the light in your life, when a great relationship turns ugly, or when you find yet another gray hair. Imagine feeling completely relaxed and happy in all of those situations and being able to accept whatever happens in life with patience and calm.

By meditating on impermanence we can learn to keep a balanced and peaceful heart, even though things don’t last. 

Feel free to drop-in to any or all of the meditation classes in this series! No need to pre-register. 

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis


Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
The Arlington Street Church invites all OutBreathren to its Tuesday night Zen Center, on the 2nd and 4th Tuesdays of each month.

The evening includes several short sitting meditations; walking meditation through the gorgeous Arlington Street Church sanctuary and Public Garden; and discussion.

Prior to the Zen Center program at 7 PM is the Buddha' Belly Book Discussion Group at 6 PM.  The group will be reading and discussing Dan Goleman's new book, A Force for Good: The Dalai Lama's Vision for Our World.  OutBreathren who are interested are warmly invited to join the book discussion at 6.

Though not exclusively LGBTQ, this is a super LGBTQ-friendly event. The teacher/facilitator is ASC Senior Minister & uber-awesome lesbian, Rev. Kim K. Crawford Harvie. Rev. Crawford Harvie was previously minister of the UU Meeting House in Provincetown where she was named Provincetown Citizen of the Year. She teaches in the Zen Buddhist tradition.

http://www.ascboston.org/index.html

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

This is a free comedy show that takes place in the back room of Iron Furnace in Quincy each Tuesday night at 8pm.

Hosted by Shawn Carter*.

The show is always hilarious and it attracts the best and brightest young comedians in Boston as well as an exceptionally clever audience. While we already have a great group of regulars that come to this show each week we're always happy to meet more people that enjoy comedy.

The stand up show runs from 8-10 

Before the show there is a free writer's workshop for any aspiring comedians. 6:30.

After the stand up show we have another sort of comedy show that is open to anyone that would like to participate. At 10:15 we begin our comedy debate show. Hosted by Sean Rosa. Also free.


Feel free to join us on Facebook as well.

(*Shawn Carter quit his day-job in September of 2014 to pursue his dream of being a professional stand up comedian. Since then he’s taken his carefully crafted act to numerous comedy clubs around the country, but also to 80th birthday parties, bridal showers and first communions. Shawn’s not afraid to drop the F bomb in front of your 7 year old if that’s what it takes to make a buck. The perfect comedian to send to your enemies special day. )

results.description:
Click here for a free Online Webinar: 

https://www.innerengineering.com/online/webinars?signinsrc=Meetup-Boston

Inner Engineering is a resource that can help with your self-help and self-improvement journey whether you are a veteran or a beginner. Sadhguru, a yogi and mystic, and one of the foremost authorities on yoga, offers his characteristically pragmatic wisdom for a life of joy and fulfillment. Starting with four basic dimensions of the self –Body, Mind, Emotions, and Energy – Sadhguru introduces us to simple techniques to realign and transform them into a life of sparkling aliveness.

Inner Engineering is a method of enhancing yourself and emerging into the ideal way you want to be. It is a 7-session online course that provides tools and solutions to empower yourself to create your life the way you want it. It gives you the opportunity to intellectually explore the ABC’s of life using methods from the distilled essence of yogic sciences. The course provides a simple, easy to use, proven methods to empower yourself for self-empowerment.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

Register http://bit.ly/1ovrQFk

Many teams struggle with getting user stories small enough and sufficiently understood for planning and delivery. Slicing user stories so they are valuable and actionable is collaborative work – involving the Product Owner, Scrum Master and the team. See how slicing user stories accelerates ongoing backlog refinement, helps sprint and release planning, and increases delivered value.

Join the co-creator of Scrum, Jeff Sutherland, and the industry’s leading expert on story-slicing, Ellen Gottesdiener, Wednesday, February 24th at 11am EST for a free, hour-long webinar.

About The Speakers

http://i1.wp.com/startupproduct.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/jeff_headshot3.jpg?resize=150%2C150 Jeff Sutherland
foto Frank Bahnmuller

Jeff Sutherland

CEO, Principal Consultant and Trainer

“Scrum is an Agile method designed to add energy, focus, clarity and transparency to project planning and implementation. While some say Scrum is not a silver bullet, it can be a heat-seeking missile to outmoded business practices.”

Jeff is the inventor and co-creator of Scrum. He is a West Point graduate, former fighter pilot and cancer researcher, as well as CTO of eleven different software companies.  He launched the first Scrum team in 1993 and has shephereded its growth into almost every industry: finance, healthcare, higher education and telecom.

</a>His most recent book is <a href="http://astore.amazon.com/startprodu-20/detail/B00JI54HCU">Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time.

http://i2.wp.com/startupproduct.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/scrumbook.jpg?resize=150%2C150

http://i1.wp.com/startupproduct.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/EllenGottesdiener.jpg?resize=150%2C150

About Ellen Gottesdiener

Ellen Gottesdiener, Principal Consultant and Founder of 

EBG Consulting, Inc.

, is an internationally recognized leader in the collaborative convergence of agile requirements + product management + project management.Ellen coaches and trains individuals and teams, and facilitates discovery and planning workshops across diverse industries. She helps global clients excel with agile requirements and business analysis, product and project management practices, and collaborative workshops for product discovery, planning and roadmapping, team chartering, and retrospectives. She writes widely, and she keynotes and presents worldwide.

Her latest book, co-authored with Mary Gorman, is Discover to Deliver: Agile Product Planning and Analysis. Ellen is author of two other acclaimed books: Requirements by Collaboration and The Software Requirements Memory Jogger.

EBG Consulting is expert in helping you discover to deliver products your customers value. EBG helps organizations globally who want to leverage their strengths and improve their product development practices through coaching, consulting, and training services.

Note: this webinar will be free for all live attendees. The recording will only be accessible for Scrum Inc.’s ScrumLab Prime subscribers.

Webinars curated by

http://startupproduct.com/webcast

for your continuous learning. Subscribe and view upcoming webcasts at http://startupproduct.com
results.name: Webcast: Slicing User Stories

results.description:
Hi everyone!

Our third meetup is Wednesday February 24th from noon-2pm on the campus of Northeastern University - Behrakis Hall Room 317  (weather permitting of course!)

At this meetup, we'll continue our discussion of the process of commercializing a medical device. We'll discuss: 

• FDA Design Controls - how do they apply to different types of devices

• Creating requirements for a medical device - the hardest part of the job


 As we did last month, slides will be posted to DropBox for sharing!


Remember to register for the IEEE Short Course - Software Development for Medical Device Manufacturers, March 30-31 in Woburn MA. 

If you have questions or topics you would like to discuss, please send them to me.

Hope to see you all on Feb 24th.

Regards,

-Steve-

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Register http://oreil.ly/1nxoMHR

Guerrilla User Research has gotten itself a bad rap because the way in which it is often conducted is not methodical. Through a Hollywood café case study, this presentation will outline exactly how to plan, conduct, and quickly analyze measurable feedback through cost-effective qualitative field research. This technique is perfect for for stakeholders and teams with little time or low budgets, but desperate for answers to help determine if the value proposition of their digital product is on target.

About Jaime Levy

For over 25 years Jaime Levy has been a pioneer in the creation of innovative digital products and services. She heads a consultancy called JLR Interactive that caters to startups and enterprises, helping them transform their business concepts into innovative and scalable online solutions. Jaime speaks at design and innovation conferences worldwide and conducts public workshops and in-house training. She also teaches a graduate level course on UX design and strategy at the University of Southern California (USC) in the Viterbi School of Engineering. You can read more about Jaime on Wikipedia.

Read the book:

UX Strategy

How to Devise Innovative Digital Products that People Want

By Jaime Levy

User experience (UX) strategy requires a careful blend of business strategy and UX design, but until now, there hasn’t been an easy-to-apply framework for executing it. This hands-on guide introduces lightweight strategy tools and techniques to help you and your team craft innovative multi-device products that people want to use.

This webinar brought to you by O'Reilly

Presented by: Jaime Levy

Duration: Approximately 60 minutes.

Cost: Free

Product Leaders are constantly learning!

1. Check out upcoming free webinars for online learning at Webcast Digest

2. Browse the Product Excellence Book Store 

Brought to you by SUPA Product Academy

Please invite all friends and colleagues that would be interested.

Look forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street 
Mission Hill, Roxbury 
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops) 
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2). 

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).


We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm or so (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Use the T - #66 bus comes by - E-Line or Orange Line

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.
TALK with us FIRST !!
Looking for Gifted Marketers to
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag?

Portion Control

Bake...Don't Fry!

Roasted Veggie Stackers

No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream

Avocados!!!

Salad with Chipotle Hummus

Simple Cilantro Chutney

More $2 bags of Produce!

Drink your greens!

Question:
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks?

Answer:
For this operation, there are "No qualifications - no limits!"
We have way more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food.

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this.

Make us busy - very busy.

results.description:
Every spring, Harvard University's Museum of Natural History hosts a series of public lectures pertaining to evolution and animal/human behavior. Join us as Professor Joseph Henrich presents The Secret of Our Success: How Culture Is Driving Human Evolution, Domesticating Our Species, and Making Us Smarter. Henrich is a professor at Harvard's Department of Human Evolutionary Biology, and also co-director of the Centre for Human Evolution, Cognition, and Culture at University of British Columbia. He will be presenting material from his book, The Secret of Our Success, which discusses the role of collective human intelligence in the evolution and development of our species. He will also have copies of his book available for purchase and signing.


The lecture starts at 6:00. We will meet outside the entrance to the lecture hall, inside the building at 26 Oxford St., between 5:30 and 5:45, then go in and get seats There should be signs for the event. Doreen and I will be wearing Meetup pins.


NOTE: The entrance to the building is at the front on Oxford St. as shown here, not around the corner to the side as the map link at the top shows.


If you miss us before the lecture, just go on in, and we'll gather again in the hallway afterwards for about 10-15 minutes, then head to a nearby restaurant for food, drinks, and discussion. It shouldn't be that hard to find people and connect.


*** ABOUT RSVPs ***


Since it's an open to the public event, there is no need to RSVP to our event page if you just want to attend the lecture only - just come on by and say hello. Your RSVP indicates that you'd like to join us afterwards for the dinner and discussion. If we end up being a particularly large group, we may have to split up into a couple of groups to get seated at a restaurant. However, in our past experience of organizing events like this in other Meetup groups,  we have never had a situation where there were too many to be seated together. There are a few places in Harvard Square, such as Pizzeria Uno and John Harvard's, which can readily accommodate large groups. There are also a few Asian restaurants, and some other good choices. We will decide based on the size of the group.

Free parking is available at the 52 Oxford Street Garage (enter off of Oxford St. opposite Everett St. - you may have to tell the attendant at the gate that you're attending the lecture, and they should just let you in). Also, the lecture hall is a short walk from the Harvard Square Red Line station.

Hope to see you there :)

From the Harvard Natural Museum of History:

The Secret of Our Success: How Culture Is Driving Human Evolution, Domesticating Our Species, and Making Us Smarter

Date: Wednesday, February 24, 2016, 6:00pm

Location: Harvard Museum of Natural History, 26 Oxford Street

Joseph Henrich, Professor, Department of Human Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University and Co-director of the Centre for Human Evolution, Cognition, and Culture, University of British Columbia

Lecture and Book Signing 

The ability of human groups to socially interconnect and learn from one another has allowed us to create ingenious technologies, sophisticated languages, and complex institutions that have enabled successful expansion into myriad environments. Drawing insights from lost European explorers, clever chimpanzees, mobile hunter-gatherers, neuroscience, ancient bones, and the human genome, Joseph Henrich, author of The Secret of Our Success, will discuss how our collective intelligence has propelled our species’ evolution.

"Mind-stretching…Henrich’s book will take you on a prodigious journey through human nature and society." —Alun Anderson, New Scientist

Free parking is available at the 52 Oxford Street Garage

Free and open to the public

The Secret of Our Success, by Joseph Henrich
results.name: Lecture: The Secret of Our Success - How Culture Is Driving Human Evolution

In this spectacular action-adventure, the survival of mankind hangs in the balance as an unexpected mortal hero Bek [Brenton Thwaites] undertakes a thrilling journey to save the world and rescue his true love. In order to succeed, he must enlist the help of the powerful god Horus [Nikolaj Coster-Waldau] in an unlikely alliance against Set [Gerard Butler], the merciless god of darkness, who has usurped Egypt’s throne, plunging the once peaceful and prosperous empire into chaos and conflict. As their breathtaking battle against Set and his henchmen takes them into the afterlife and across the heavens, both god and mortal must pass tests of courage and sacrifice if they hope to prevail in the spectacular final confrontation.

results.description:
The Secret of Our Success: How Culture Is Driving Human Evolution, Domesticating Our Species, and Making Us Smarter

A Lecture and Book Signing with Joseph Henrich, Professor, Department of Human Evolutionary Biology, Harvard University and Co-director of the Centre for Human Evolution, Cognition, and Culture, University of British Columbia

Event link HERE. Free and open to the public. Free parking at 52 Oxford Street.

Wednesday, February 24th, 6pm

Harvard Museum of Natural History, 26 Oxford Street

:: :: ::

The ability of human groups to socially interconnect and learn from one another has allowed us to create ingenious technologies, sophisticated languages, and complex institutions that have enabled successful expansion into myriad environments. Drawing insights from lost European explorers, clever chimpanzees, mobile hunter-gatherers, neuroscience, ancient bones, and the human genome, Joseph Henrich, author of The Secret of Our Success, will discuss how our collective intelligence has propelled our species’ evolution.

"Mind-stretching…Henrich’s book will take you on a prodigious journey through human nature and society." —Alun Anderson, New Scientist
results.name: Culture & Evolution

results.description:
The Revolve Nation's Boston Entrepreneurs Network is the largest community of entrepreneurs and business owners in the city of Boston, offering networking, discussion groups, seminars, business plan hot-seats, and more!

Join us here, where professionals and entrepreneurs meet in mutual support of business to network, socialize, learn, and promote a thriving community of entrepreneurs. Wine and snacks provided!

Schedule:

6pm-6:30pm  -- Open Networking over wine and snacks

6:30-6:45pm  -- Meeting Called to Order and Introductions

6:45--7:45pm -- Open discussions on topics of interest to our members (examples; Getting funded, building a team, using mailing lists and their effectiveness, firing a difficult employee) Suggest your own topics as comments on the event, or simply bring them with you!

7:45-8:00pm  -- More Networking! (and wine!)

Like anything in life, what you put into a networking group is what you get out of it. The Boston Entrepreneurs Group is designed for entrepreneurs and professionals who are serious about building their business, investing in relationships, and helping each other to succeed.

The way the group seeks to achieve these outcomes:

1) Regular attendance

2) Dedication to coming prepared to contribute value to the community with expertise, experience, and networks.

3) Create a fun and supportive environment!

Price: FREE

SPONSORS: Revolve, Inc.: www.revolvethis.com

Exemplar Law: www.exemplarcompanies.com

See you soon!
results.how_to_find_us: Please be sure to enter on Summer Street, take the escalator to the second floor where you will present identification to security and then proceed to the 19th Floor.
