results.description:
Can we have FUN while letting go of stuff?  We might be used to the feeling of dread, we might even go "UUGGGGG" out loud whenever we think about our closet or garage or whole house! Are there ways we can make the process fun? If it wasn't something we hated doing would we spend more time on it and more often? Let's share stories and ideas on how we can make this fun!  

AND

What is stopping you from letting go of excess stuff? There are millions of excuses of why we don't move forward. By the end of the meetup, each participant who wants one will have a strategy to try out on their unique situation. 

Come join in the conversation!
results.how_to_find_us: Find us at the table with tape on it that says "Less Stuff More Joy."
results.name: Fun while letting go of stuff? What is stopping you? (JP)

results.description:
Are you the type of person who seems to know a little bit of everything - especially when it comes to the tech scene? Come show off your knowledge of Boston's tech market as we host our 3rd Annual Tech Trivia Night! 

Bring a team or come alone and we'll find you some friends when you arrive. Brush up on your tech know-how, knowledge of startups and entrepreneurs in Boston, and of course, Tech in Motion. 

Trivia not really your game? Join us anyway to network with fellow Boston Techies!

Emily Xie is our trivia host for the evening! Emily is a software engineer at Wayfair. She teaches women to code via Girl Develop It Boston, and in her spare time, enjoys cooking, portrait photography, and razing villages in Age of Empires II. You can visit her online at: xie-emily.com or on Twitter: @emilyxxie. 


Tech Trivia Rules and Regulations

No cheating! This means no cell phones and no reference materials.

Don’t shout out the answers.

Six participants are allowed per team.

One answer per team- your team’s answers must be turned in by the end of the countdown.

The answers that have been turned in are final- no corrections!

Each answer is worth one point. There is no penalty for wrong answers.

Rulings made by the Tech in Motion Event Coordinators are final. 

Learn More About Our Sponsor:


TriNet is a leading provider of a comprehensive human resources solution for small to medium-sized businesses. Our HR solution includes services such as payroll processing, human capital consulting, employment law compliance and employee benefits, including health insurance, retirement plans and workers compensation insurance. At Trinet, we understand there is a difference between running a business and employing people. Our model allows you to focus more on your business, and lets us help you manage your people.

Foodler is providing food for the evening! 

Foodler is a Boston based online food ordering service that connects consumers and companies with a wide variety of restaurants for immediate delivery. Delivery via Foodler is available from more than 12,000 restaurants in 48 states across the US. Breakfast, lunch and dinner options are available as well as alcohol, catering, desserts and more. Foodler has a top rated customer service and an industry leading rewards program.
results.name: Tech Trivia Night

results.description:
We have a really special event coming up next Wednesday, February 24th.  Our friends at the office of UK Trade & Investment at The British Consulate in Cambridge are playing host to a panel discussion on investing in security for the Internet of Things. 


This very special meeting is taking place at the British Consulate, One Broadway in Cambridge from 6:00 to 9:00 pm on Wednesday, February 24th. Food and beverages will be provided by the Consulate and by our good friends at CyberSN. 


Our guests: 

• Deidre Diamond, Founder and CEO, CyberSN.com

• Eric Davis, Partner, Americas Growth Capital

• Jeff Fagnan, Partner, Accomplice

• Brad Gaynor, Founder and CEO, Lexumo

• Sean Kagan, Vice Consul, Information Communications Technology

• Moderator: Paul Roberts, Editor in Chief, The Security Ledger


Agenda: 

6:00 - 6:30 Guests arrive & networking

6:30 - 6:50 Opening Remarks & the infosec job market: Deidre Diamond CyberSN

6:50 - 7:00 Short break

7:00 -8:00 (ish):  Securing the Internet of Things: An Investor's View. Panel features: 

•  Eric Davis, Partner, Americas Growth Capital

• Jeff Fagnan, Partner, Accomplice

• Brad Gaynor, Founder and CEO, Lexumo

• Sean Kagan, Vice Consul, Information Communications Technology

• Moderator: Paul Roberts, Editor in Chief, The Security Ledger 

8:00 - 8:10 Concluding remarks 8:10 - 8:45(ish) Networking, wrap up

Some thoughts: It goes without saying that the Internet of Things will transform the information security industry, just as it transforms industries from manufacturing to healthcare. Countless security firms (and fortunes) were built on the premise of securing PCs - fat, powerful (and power hungry), multi-purpose devices from a short list of threats: viruses, worms, hacking, denial of service attacks and so on. 

But in the coming Internet of Things, endpoints will not look or act anything like the PCs of yore. Ubiquitous, geographically dispersed, low power, connected endpoints may well interact and communicate autonomously. The possibilities by which an attacker might move from any one, low value endpoint to other, sensitive IT assets will be impossible to enumerate. What will the information security solutions of the next ten- or 20 years look like? What new kinds of capabilities and technologies will be needed to tackle the security and privacy challenges of the Internet of Things? 

Join us for a great discussion Wednesday evening! We look forward to seeing you there. 

Paul
results.how_to_find_us: Please bring ID. You will need it to be admitted to the Consulate
results.name: Securing the Internet of Things: An Investor's View

results.description:
Share a room and the web with anyone in the world! Attend or create events, share web content with others in real time, browse the web, and play web powered 3D apps. AltspaceVR is a shared VR experience - a communication platform focused on natural communication, intuitive UI, and real-time sharing of web content. Users in AltspaceVR can watch Netflix or YouTube, play tabletop games, or give a presentation - together and entirely inside of VR. Developers can use the AltspaceVR SDK to easily build VR apps and experiences. AltspaceVR has raised $15.5M in funding from investors including Tencent and Google Ventures.

Bruce Wooden, Head of Developer Relations at AltspaceVR, will be giving an overview of some of the newest features of AltspaceVR along with a live coding demonstration of the AltspaceVR SDK. The AltspaceVR SDK enables developers to rapidly build contained VR experiences and apps using the power of three.js and web code.

Bruce is known in VR circles as Cymatic Bruce, an active industry evangelist since 2013. He has participated in more than 700 VR experiences and accrued millions of views on video and live-streamed content. Bruce co-founded Silicon Valley Virtual Reality (SVVR) in May 2013, which has grown to 3,000 members and hosts an annual conference.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CQtQGoMRXaI

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A5H735GHbMI

PLEASE NOTE: Our venue requires our guests to sign in with a photo ID at the security desk. When you RSVP you'll get a pop up question; please enter your full name as it appears on your ID. Thanks for your cooperation.

Schedule

6 - Doors open, demos begin, pizza is served thanks to AltspaceVR

7:00 - 7:30 Lightning Talks


7:30 - 8 - AltspaceVR Presentation

8 - 8:15 - Demo intros & announcements

8:15 - 9:45 Demofest!!

9:45pm - Come with us to the afterparty at Firebrand Saints (it's right downstairs!!)

Lightning Talks

Scott Evernden - Infinite Stores is social shopping entertainment designed for people who love browsing and exploring. The first VR shopping world will be built by an army of Etsy sellers, each eager for increased exposure and traffic.


Mike "Dr.Claw" Piantedosi - @party is a computer art festival focusing on real-time rendered computer graphics productions called "demos".  Various "demo" techniques translate well into VR experiences.  This year's @party
will feature a VR competition and will take place June 3-5 at
Artisan's Asylum in Somerville MA, http://atparty-demoscene.net.  Come listen to my talk for more information!


Jono Forbes - level design in room-scale VR.

Demos

Black Hat Cooperative - multi-player co-op Oculus game - Richard Cody & Nick Garza


Intern Astronaut - - GearVR chaotic spaceship piloting game - Broken Door Studio 

Lost Loot - treasure hunting game - Michael Schenck

Archean  - VR world building - Jono Forbes

Perception Neuron - full body motion tracking - Paul Umbro.

VRDoodler - an online 3D drawing tool that's open source - Cindy


360Heros - Gear VR based 360 video - Matt Sheils

Parking

If you're coming to the afterparty, Firebrand Saints offers free validated parking for entry after 5pm. If you enter through the garage keep going into the parking lot so you don't have to go through security again after the garage closes. Please note that the validation is temporary; once they swipe your ticket you should exit the lot immediately.
results.how_to_find_us: Come up to the 5th floor

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.

results.description:
Our Topic This Evening ....

...will focus us on using forgiveness to give us greater peace, contentment, and joy. Some of us may have held onto deep, and possibly well-justified, resentments for years. What if holding onto resentment is blocking us from achieving the peace, love, joy, and presence that we yearn for?


How can we treat ourselves with greater kindness?


What if a few simple techniques could dissipate enormous negative energies we have bottled inside, making room for peace and calm to flow back in?


Join us as Kevin Martin guides us through techniques to clear out memories, thoughts, and feelings that interfere with our emotional (and sometimes physical) health. Give the gift to yourself of greater peace and contentment.


Enjoy the shift in the room when everyone lets go of anger and resentment and replaces it with peace and contentment.


Preparation


1. What are some of your favorite, oft-related stories of people doing you wrong?


2. Do you have any 'triggers' of ill feelings? Ie. seeing a specific person or place; hearing a certain voice or phrase.

3. What is it that you would most like to release?

Our Leader This Evening Kevin Martin, a PGN organizer, is an author, professional speaker, a hypnotist, a master practitioner of NLP, and the organizer of Greater Boston NLP & Hypnosis meet up. He has practiced Ho'Oponopono for 5 years, adding his own wrinkles. He has just returned from Hawaii where he spent 10 days learning Huna - Hawaiian Energy and spiritualism. Through doing so (using Ho'Oponopono) , Kevin has found that his perceptions of others and his own situations have changed dramatically for the good. He has also found incredible moments of pure inspiration.


Kevin is a passionate evangelist about Ho'Oponopono and has taught the Ho'Oponopono prayer to hundreds of people. "No matter what technique you use, releasing these feelings of resentment, anger, guilt, and judgement, can only be a good thing." Kevin believes that Ho'Oponopono is one of the easiest ways to let go of these feelings.


Links

Most Important:   
  * Calendar of Other Heartbeat Salons. 
  * HeartBeat Salon on FaceBook

For Newbies:

results.description:
One of our members suggested adding shows to our range of activities.  Therefore, I am posting this unofficial event.

Merrimack College presents a free classic film series on selected Wednesday nights at their Rogers Center for the Arts.  On February 24, they are showing the 2013 French film Gabrielle.  The screening starts at 7:00 P.M. and includes a brief introductory lecture.  Its synopsys is below:

A young, musically gifted woman living with Williams syndrome falls deeply in love with a boy in her choir, though their budding romance is thwarted by the misguided loved ones who believe they lack the emotional capacity to maintain a healthy relationship.  Meanwhile, as the choir prepares for an upcoming performance at a prominent music festival, the emotionally-fragile girl longs to experience true independence.

I plan to arrive around 6:30 P.M.  For anyone who wishes to sit as a group, I will be standing around the refreshments table wearing a MeetUp name tag.  You are also free to attend as an individual if you prefer.

This event has no attendence limit since the theater seats several hundred people and has never been full.
results.name: International Film:  Gabrielle

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford Presents Two Headed Giant Night

Learn Android software development with the Udacity Android Development for Beginners online course and a local study group. Why a study group? Less than 12% of the people who start an online course by themselves finish it. We’ve seen over half of the people who signed up for an online course and commit to meeting in a study group complete the course.

What to expect

We’ll all meet for the first time at the Signup Evening on Wednesday, February 24 at 6:30PM at Hatch Fenway (401 Park Drive in Boston). We’ll review the course, what’s expected of you and how these study groups have been run in the past. We'll also help you start setting up your environment. Fully informed and with your questions answered, you can sign up then on Eventbrite. 

Each week for 4 consecutive Wednesdays, March 2, 9, 16 and 23, at 6:30PM, we’ll meet at Hatch Fenway (401 Park Drive in Boston) to review the lesson you prepared. Experienced study group leaders will have completed each lesson and prepared a review of the lesson. Each session will last one and a half to two hours. We’ll serve some food so you don’t have to stop on your way from work.

Study group leaders will step through each lesson and will facilitate a discussion amongst the attendees.

Before each meeting you’ll complete the lesson of the week. On average, this will take about three hours per week to prepare.

Attendees who complete all lessons and attend all classes will receive a certificate of completion.  

Who should attend?

Everyone who is would like to learn mobile Android programming. You don’t need software development experience.


Cost

Free

Tesora CEO Ken Rugg will give an ‘Introduction to OpenStack Trove". This presentation will include an overview of the Trove project and Database as a Service (DBaaS), explain how to interact, install and deploy different data stores, as well as detail the architecture behind how it all works. The session will conclude with a Q&A.

The entrepreneurial bug bit Ken early when he left MIT’s computer-science program early to join an artificial intelligence startup. Ken has 20 years in strategic planning, business development, mergers and acquisitions, product definition and development. He has shown expertise in innovative go-to-market strategies, growing technical solutions into profitable businesses, building high-performance teams and pushing sales.

We will begin at 6:30 with pizza, soft drinks and time for networking.  The presentation will be begin at 7.

Are You Concerned about Co-Parenting During and Beyond Your Divorce or Separation? How to Keep Your Parenting Strategies on Track.


Please join us for a special evening focused on learning and implementing parenting skills through your divorce or separation. This seminar, led by seasoned Divorce Attorney, Mick Judge, from Burns & Levinson LLP and Parenting Coach & registered nurse, Kathy Whitham, is intended to help you and your family have a smooth and easy transition. Mick will cover important legal issues for both newly separated parents as well as parents with existing agreements. He also will provide sample parenting plans and discuss other co-parenting issues such as flexibility, holidays, travel and new significant others. Kathy will guide you through essential strategies to help your children have a sense of stability during and after this transition. Together, they will provide you with resources that will aid in creating a bright future for you and your children. 

There is no cost for attendance and complimentary refreshments & snacks will be provided for your enjoyment throughout the event.

results.description:
In conjunction with the PGN Heart Beat Salon workshops, we are pleased to present the all new Peace Through Forgiveness Workshop

Our Topic This Evening ....

...will focus us on using forgiveness to give us greater peace, contentment, and joy. Some of us may have held onto deep, and possibly well-justified, resentments for years. What if holding onto resentment is blocking us from achieving the peace, love, joy, and presence that we yearn for?

How can we treat ourselves with greater kindness?

What if a few simple techniques could dissipate enormous negative energies we have bottled inside, making room for peace and calm to flow back in?

Join us as Kevin Martin guides us through techniques to clear out memories, thoughts, and feelings that interfere with our emotional (and sometimes physical) health. Give the gift to yourself of greater peace and contentment.

Enjoy the shift in the room when everyone lets go of anger and resentment and replaces it with peace and contentment.

Preparation

1. What are some of your favorite, oft-related stories of people doing you wrong?

2. Do you have any 'triggers' of ill feelings? Ie. seeing a specific person or place; hearing a certain voice or phrase.

3. What is it that you would most like to release?


Our Leader This Evening Kevin Martin, a PGN organizer, is an author, professional speaker, a hypnotist, a master practitioner of NLP, and the organizer of Greater Boston NLP & Hypnosis meet up. He has practiced Ho'Oponopono for 5 years, adding his own wrinkles. He has just returned from Hawaii where he spent 10 days learning Huna - Hawaiian Energy and spiritualism. Through doing so (using Ho'Oponopono) , Kevin has found that his perceptions of others and his own situations have changed dramatically for the good. He has also found incredible moments of pure inspiration.

Kevin is a passionate evangelist about Ho'Oponopono and has taught the Ho'Oponopono prayer to hundreds of people. "No matter what technique you use, releasing these feelings of resentment, anger, guilt, and judgement, can only be a good thing." Kevin believes that Ho'Oponopono is one of the easiest ways to let go of these feelings.

Links

Most Important:
* Calendar of Other Heartbeat Salons.
* HeartBeat Salon on FaceBook

For Newbies:
* What is a Heartbeat Salon?
* Find a Heartbeat Salon Near You .
* Guidelines for Attending a Heartbeat Salon .

For Potential Hosts:
* Hints on How to Host a Heartbeat Salon .
* Topics from Past Heartbeat Salons .

For Potential Presenters:
* Hints on How to Present at a Heartbeat Salon .

Your Suggestions:
* Suggestions for a Heartbeat Salon (topics, locations, etc) . 8/04/15

results.description:
Want to learn a valuable skill that will keep you in demand and place you ahead of the curve in the tech world?


Version control is an essential technique used by web and software developers of all sorts to manage their code, keep track of changes, and collaborate with other team members.


Among version control systems, Git is the fastest growing and most popular open source system used today. It's useful whether you are working on a large distributed team or working on smaller personal projects. Git also pairs perfectly with the social code hosting service Github.


This session will introduce the basics of version control, using Git to keep track of your changes to a project, and using GitHub to store code and collaborate with other developers.

Prior coding experience is not necessary, just a willingness to learn something new!

TAKEAWAYS


This class will cover:


• Basic concepts of version control and Git workflow

• Setting up a Github repository


• Git commands for tracking changes to an individual project (adding, committing & pushing changes)


• Git commands for collaborating with other developers (branching & merging)


• Debugging and resolving merge conflicts


PREREQUISITES

No programming experience is required, however basic familiarity with the command line interface is helpful.


If you don't have command line experience, consider taking our Intro to the Linux Command Line class on Feb 17!


Tech Requirements:

• Laptop computer (Mac, PC, or Linux are all okay)

• Modern web browser (Chrome or Firefox)


• Text editor (we recommend Sublime Text 2 - it's free and available for both Mac and PC)

Before Class Begins:

• Download Git and install it onto your computer


• Create a Github.com account

LOCATION
Many thanks to Wellist for hosting this class! Wellist is located at:

125 Broad St, 2nd floor
Boston, MA
View Google Map


Someone will be available to let you into the building when you arrive.

Interested in hosting classes? Email us at boston[at]girldevelopit.com!

ABOUT THE TEACHER

Liz is a software engineer and UI designer at a small non-profit, where she builds web applications using PHP, JavaScript, Python and Drupal. She has a BS in graphic design and a master's in library & information science, and spent 3 years working as a technical trainer, teaching web development and graphic design, before making the leap to software development.


TEACHING ASSISTANTS

This course will be TAed by Amanda Muñoz and Sean Kelly.

If you are interested in being a teaching assistant, please fill out our volunteer form. TAing is a great way to practice what you know and to get to know members of our community.

FINANCIAL NEED

A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified shortly after the deadline. Class capacity does not impact scholarship students. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer.

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!
results.how_to_find_us: 2nd floor; MBTA: Downtown Crossing/South Station
results.name: Intro to Version Control with Git/Github

results.description:
Peter Nealon & Glenn Grant of G2 Technology Group

The Journey to an Agile DevOps Desk

The merging of a DevOps workload with the traditional Service Desk model presents some significant operational challenges.  Peter & Glenn will share with you how they’ve bastardized agile principles to develop the one DevOps Desk to rule them all.  Certified scrum masters, bring your earmuffs! 

Jeff Behl - Chief Network Architect, LogicMonitor

Jeff will share how his team took a specific app from manual build and deployment to continuous build and automated deployment.  

Jeff will cover what they expect from developers, how communication is handled, and how monitoring is an essential foundation for ensuring success. 
LogicMonitor is a company founded by, and largely targeted at, Operations teams, perhaps giving us a different view than some on DevOps.  

Lightning Talks:

Myles Steinhauser - The Benefit of Constraints

James Meickle - What We Know About Habits

Cody Mathiason - Binary is for Computers
results.name: Habits for Successful DevOps

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


To the left there is a chip-in feature. Your donations will go directly to the monthly dues and will allow MAC meetup group to keep going. Any amount would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs
results.name: Climbing at Central Rock (Watertown)

results.description:
EAT TO THRIVE: 
10-week course to Life Long Healthy Habits Healthy Living 
with Betsy Bragg

* Wednesdays, March 2 -May 11  6:00 – 8:30 pm

  Come be motivated to change your life!!

Where:  


Mystic Learning Center
530 Mystic Avenue
Somerville, MA

Upcoming course information – apply today – space is limited 
(online/phone[masked])  http://www.optimumhealthsolution.org

When: Wednesdays, March 2 -May 11  6:00 – 8:30 pm

Location:  


Mystic Learning Center
530 Mystic Avenue
Somerville, MA

Early Bird Special: Save $50 if registered by December 29

Fee includes 383-page manual, sprouting kits, DVDs to watch, 
and a five-course health-promoting meal each week.

Eat to Thrive

Class Dates: Wednesdays, March 2 -May 11  6:00 – 8:30 pm

Info Session:  Wednesday, February 24, 2016, 6:30 – 8:30 pm

Location: 


Mystic Learning Center
530 Mystic Avenue
Somerville, MA

EAT TO THRIVE COURSE OPTIONS/TRACKS AND PRICING

1. AUDIT: This is for students whose goal it is to gain exposure to the subject matter. Whether they have an illness or simply a thirst for knowledge of the subject matter, they will be permitted to attend, borrow DVDs and participate.  They will be required to prepare and contribute to the five course meal. However, there are no attendance or written/oral requirements.  Fee: $555

2. REPEATING AUDIT STUDENTS:  (returning graduates) Fee: $355

3. HEALTH EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: This track is for students whose goal it is to apply the knowledge from this course to a career path. Successful completion of this program will lead to an Optimum Health Solution (OHS) Certificate of Completion. Requirements for this course are attendance at 8 out of 10 classes; a passing grade on two take-home essay tests; and a presentation with hands-on learning for a group of at least 5 people (to be described more in detail on the website). Fee: $755 

4. REAL KIDS REAL FOOD HEALTH (RKRF) EDUCATOR CERTIFICATE: 
This track is designed for teachers or students seeking a career path in teaching upper elementary to middle school-age children and want to gain expertise in the subject area of healthy foods. Students enrolled in this certificate program will have an additional 6 hours of one-on-one teacher training with master educator, Betsy Bragg; students will learn kid-tested recipes and techniques for teaching and presentation; students will have the opportunity to observe other master teachers, participate in a practicum, and design their own lesson plan. Successful completion of this program will lead to an OHS RKRF Certificate of Completion.  Betsy’s background includes 48 years of teaching Elementary through University levels, M.Ed Stanford and Harvard Universities, M.A. Boston University, licensed in Special Education Lesley University, licensed in English Second Language University of Massachusetts. Fee $800. Repeating students (graduates) Fee $600

5. Eat to Thrive Educator Training Certificate: This track is designed for repeating students who want to teach a section of the OHS Eat to Thrive Program. In addition to the 10-week program, students will be given an additional 6 of hands-on training in all aspects of the curriculum and administration. As OHS plans to expand its Eat to Thrive program to other locations in Massachusetts, paid teachers will be required to hold this certification.  Prerequisite: Students must have taken an Eat to Thrive course and hold the Health Educator Certificate. Fee: $650

results.name: Eat to Thrive: 10 Weeks to Life-Long Healthy Habits and Healthy Living

results.description:
Let's make an Android app! Learn Android software development with the Udacity Android Development for Beginners online course and a local study group. Why a study group? Less than 12% of the people who start an online course by themselves finish it. We’ve seen over half of the people who signed up for an online course and commit to meeting in a study group complete the course. 


Girl Develop It, the Google Developer Group and Women Who Code are coproducing this event.

DATES

To officially sign up for this course, be sure to attend the signup evening on Wednesday, February 24th. After the signup evening, this class will take place over four evenings in March, as follows:

• Wednesday, Feb. 24, 6:30pm (Signup Evening)

• Wednesday, March 2, 6:30-8:30pm

• Wednesday, March 9, 6:30-8:30pm

• Wednesday, March 16, 6:30-8:30pm

• Wednesday, March 23, 6:30-8:30pm


TAKEAWAYS

In this course, you'll create an educational app that teaches 5 new things to a user on a certain topic of your choice. You'll learn how to:


• Work with Android Studio, a program used by professional developers to make Android apps

• Build layouts for Android apps

• Make an app interactive


• Work with the Android Framework and Control Flow

WHO SHOULD ATTEND?

If you are new to programming and don’t know where to start, then this is the course for you! This course is geared towards anyone interested in learning mobile Android programming. 

Note: All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct. 



WHAT TO EXPECT


We’ll all meet for the first time at the Signup Evening on Wednesday, February 24 at 6:30pm at Hatch Fenway (401 Park Drive in Boston). We’ll review the course, what’s expected of you and how these study groups have been run in the past. Fully informed and with your questions answered, you can sign up then.

Each week for 4 consecutive Wednesdays, March 2, 9, 16 and 23, at 6:30pm, we’ll meet at Hatch Fenway to review the lesson you prepared. Experienced study group leaders will have completed each lesson and prepared a review of the lesson. Each session will last one and a half to two hours. We’ll serve some food so you don’t have to stop on your way from work.

Study group leaders will step through each lesson and will facilitate a discussion amongst the attendees.

Before each meeting you’ll complete the lesson of the week. On average, this will take about six hours per week to prepare.

Attendees who complete all lessons and attend all classes will receive a certificate of completion.  

PREREQS & PREPARATION

No prior software development experience necessary.

We will use Android Studio to build our apps, so you should have access to a computer that can run Android Studio in order to follow along (see Android Studio’s System Requirements for details). Don’t worry, you do not need to install Android Studio in advance – we will provide detailed installation instructions as part of the course.

Access to an Android device is helpful, but not at all required.

LOCATION

A huge thank you to Hatch Fenway for hosting this event! Hatch Fenway is located at:

401 Park Drive
8th Floor (Hatch Fenway) 
Boston, MA 02215 
View Google Map


COST

Free. Food will be provided for the March sessions.

Interested in discovering classes like this, workshops, special events, giveaways, volunteer opportunities, and more? Sign up for our monthly newsletter!
results.name: Study Group: Android Development for Beginners

results.description:
Please come out and join us for a pleasant evening of competitive party bridge in  Newton Centre.  Wednesday night bridge here has been a multi-year Metrowest tradition; it is a nice quiet spot with a fireplace, good food, ample table space.  The more the merrier, so long as you know how to play bridge and love it.

This is officially canceled unless 5 players sign up by 5pm. We can still play with four if we re-confirm. Check this space at 5pm if quorum questions exist. Out of courtesy, please do not sign up casually, nor cancel out on the day of event except in emergencies.

You must know Contract Bridge rules and basic bidding to play this week. No formal training is to be offered, but this is a social, casual event. To assist novices, bidding advice and meanings will be openly discussed on any player's request.

ACBL Yellow Card is our group-standard bidding system; a novice should please take time to study all basic openings and responses shown above in yellow, plus standard Jacoby Transfer and Stayman responses to NT openings. We will expect a verbal alert on deviations an expert may make to these most-common conventions.
results.name: A Newton Center Bridge Party

results.description:
The book is Tiger Lily by Jodi Lynne Anderson.

A retelling of a classic children’s tale from a unique perspective.

Before Peter Pan belonged to Wendy, he belonged to the girl with the crow feather in her hair… Tiger Lily. When fifteen-year-old Tiger Lily meets the alluring teenage Peter Pan deep in the forbidden woods of Neverland, the two form a bond that's impossible to break, but also impossible to hold on to. As the leader of the Lost Boys, the most fearsome of Neverland's inhabitants, Peter is an unthinkable match for Tiger Lily. However, when Wendy Darling, a girl who is everything Tiger Lily is not, arrives on the island, Tiger Lily discovers how far she is willing to go to keep Peter with her, and in Neverland.

Told from the perspective of tiny, fairy-sized Tinkerbell, Tiger Lily is the breathtaking story of budding romance, letting go and the pains of growing up.

This is a great “romance” pick for February.

The venue is Pho Hoa in Chinatown, a reasonably priced Vietnamese restaurant with nice, round tables and a quieter atmosphere.
results.name: Tiger Lily at Pho Hoa in Chinatown

results.description:
Hey everyone, a few important updates regarding the Wigle Whiskey tasting this week:

1. The cost of a tasting (three 1/2 oz. pours) will be $13.  With our small profit from the koozie sales, we're going to put $5 toward everyone's tasting, which means $8 for each Yinz in Boston member joining us.

2. We're now doing the tasting at Champions in the Copley Marriott (private "Bullpen" room).  However, we're limited to 24 guests, and we have 22 signed up so far.  If you're still interested in coming, please RSVP ASAP.  If you've RSVP'd yes and changed your mind, please change your RSVP!  Since there are very limited seats for this event we'd really appreciate everyone who's signed up actually attending.

3. The bar won't split our checks for us, so I'll pay the bar directly and bring a credit card reader to split the checks myself.  This just means everyone will have to keep track of what they ordered.  Sorry for the inconvenience.

4. We'll shoot to start the tasting promptly at 7pm.

We're really pumped for this event and hope you are too!  Let's go Pens!

* * * * *

By now most of you should be familiar with Wigle Whiskey, a craft distillery in Pittsburgh that has been awesome enough to share samples with us at Steeler games and give away some free shirts at our holiday party.  We're now teaming up with them to do a Wigle whiskey tasting in conjunction with the next Penguins-Bruins game.  Come to Champions to watch the game with fellow Pens fans, while Allison from Wigle walks us through a sampling of some of Pittsburgh's finest bevies. 

We think this is a really unique Pittsburgh-themed event, so we hope everyone can take advantage of the opportunity!


-Billy, Andy, & Tim
results.how_to_find_us: Private "Bullpen" Room
results.name: Wigle Whiskey Tasting & Pens v. Bruins!

results.description:
RSVP now for Wed, Feb 24 - Learn valuable do's and don'ts for addressing an audience. Listen to first-time speakers. And discover how to get over that "anxiety hurdle."

Did you ever imagine speaking to a group could be fun?

Our Meet-ups continue to win rave reviews from first-time (and returning) guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

Wed, March  09, (6:45 PM)

Sat, March 5 "First Saturday" (9:45 AM)


                        ..............................

You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking (Beware - Metered until 8 PM !), There is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.

results.description:
Joel Fishbein will be leading this sound awareness meditation.  Our event start time is 6:45pm.  But please arrive early to settle in.  

Our schedule: 
6:30pm -  It's great to arrive early to ask questions and find a good seat.  We have chitchat time starting around 6:30. Come hang out with us and feel free to peruse the store. 
6:45pm - Class starts. 
Please note: We lock the door at 7pm.  At 7pm, you are already 15 minutes late for class, so please do not disturb the class by trying to enter or knocking.  
8:00pm - Class ends. 

What happens during class: 
   The 75 minutes that we spend together will include: 
           1) discussion about meditation and mindfulness 
           2) instructions on how to meditate 
           3) an experience of a sound awareness meditation 
The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 25 minutes long. No previous experience is required; the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand. 

More info: 
Our website has more information about the history of our Community Meditation Nights.  http://www.mindfulboston.com/classes/#/community-meditation-nights/

What to bring: 
It's fine to just show up as you are.  
Yet, please be aware that (as you can see in the pictures) most of us do sit on the floor.  Some folks choose to bring their own pillow for sitting on the floor, but there are no requirements to bring anything. 
If you require a chair for health reasons, make sure to RSVP and write "please reserve a chair for me" in the comments section below. We have about seven chairs, and typically 20 to 30 people participate.
results.name: Community Meditation Night- Sound Awareness Meditation

results.description:
Lower back pain is a very common affliction. As the NIH’s Back Pain Fact Sheet observes:

About 80 percent of adults experience low back pain at some point in their lifetimes. It is the most common cause of job-related disability and a leading contributor to missed work days. In a large survey, more than a quarter of adults reported experiencing low back pain during the past 3 months.


Mullein root is very useful in cases of low back pain, especially when due to misalignment.


While many of the primary causes of back pain are related to alignment, posture, and movement habits – and we’ll talk briefly about addressing them during this class – it’s just as common, in our experience, that fear plays a major role in the development of this problem, especially as it becomes chronic. Herbs can help. They might be employed to support the healing of injured muscles and the restoration of healthy connective tissues, or to provide direct relief from pain. They can also, though, help to change habits of activity and emotion that contribute to the ongoing struggle with back pain. Come learn how!

Wednesday, February 24th, 2016
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by filling out our contact form, emailing us at <a>[masked]</a>, or calling[masked]-5274.

http://commonwealthherbs.com/herbal-back-pain-relief-class/
results.name: Herbs for Back Pain

results.description:
Book Review by Murray Denofsky of Nick Lane's 2015 book.

The book explains the evolution of the first eukaryotic cells that led to all plants, fungi, and animals. Here is my view, Robin.

·  For 2 billion years only bacteria

·  Archaea evolved from bacteria to live in extreme environments

·  Cyanobacteria made free oxygen

·  Some bacteria evolved to breathe it

·  An Archaea lived symbiotically with such bacteria inside it

·  These bacteria became mitochondria in eukaryotic cells

·  A photosynthetic bacteria fused with eukaryotic cells to create plants

The high efficiency of mitochondria as energy machines led to: ·  Blossoming of powerful multicellular creatures

·  Homo sapiens with huge, power-hog brain that runs efficiently on ketones from fat during famine

·  Most diseases are caused by disorders of mitochondria, including cancer, which I will explain

Ring first floor bell, and someone will come to open the door. Bring your supper if you wish-- we will start with introductions and general conversation, then proceed to the talk about 7:30 or so, followed by questions and discussion till about 9:30 or 10 pm   --Murray E. Denofsky
results.how_to_find_us: From Porter T, cross Mass Ave past bagel place, turn right on Richdale, pass convenience store, enter at large 175 sign.
results.name: THE VITAL QUESTION: Energy, Evolution, & the Origin of Complex Life, Nick Lane's

results.description:
Hi friends,

I work at the Museum of Science, and my department puts on events approximately once per month. They're on science and technology topics, and they involve speaker presentations followed by guided discussions, which we call forums. I'd love if you wanted to come to one (or more!) of my programs, either to support me or because you're interested in the topic. They're free, open to the public, and have refreshments - what more could you want?

The February one is called Rising Tide: Planning for Boston's Uncertain Future. It's about sea level rise in Boston and what we might do to prepare. You can see a description here: http://www.mos.org/public-events/rising-tide

If you want to come, you should sign up here: http://www.eventbrite.com/e/rising-tide-planning-for-bostons-uncertain-future-registration-20708746418 and feel free to also RSVP on this meetup event so people know you're going :)

If you have any questions, feel free to post a comment or send me a message.

Thanks!

Caroline
results.name: Museum of Science Forum Event (Caroline's work) - Rising Tide

results.description:
ALEWIFE PANERA. $20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

1. Due to finite space, you must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.  Likewise, If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

3. Please save loud and/or big games (like those with real-time arguing) for after 9:30, when the room is less full.  This allows us to accommodate more people, and play a greater variety of games.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.

OTHER POLICY DETAILS:

If you would like to come but there are no spots, consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.  You can also sign up as "wants a spot" and receive emails from meetup if a spot opens up.

We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 24 hours, or constantly cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

If you use a "+1" spot, you are responsible for all of the above for your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Wednesday Night Gaming is our more-or-less weekly free-for-all of strategy gaming goodness downstairs at the Porter Square Panera. There's rarely a set agenda for these events but you are welcome and encouraged to hash out a plan beforehand in comments if you've got something you're dying to play. Nonetheless, you are not required to bring a game to play -- our only requirement is that you bring an open mind!

The event officially begins at 7 PM but people often trickle in early, so you're welcome to sit down to a filler game to get warmed up, or arrange to meet a little early if you've got a group looking to tackle an extra-meaty game.

Please be aware that Panera has been quite gracious about hosting us with minimal fuss -- in order to keep things this way, please respect the hardworking people who work there and, especially, their desire to get out after a long shift.

We'll see you at the gaming table!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and finite space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
Hello SCIPers!

Reserve your spot here!

I am excited to invite you to the first SCIP Boston chapter meeting! We will be holding the meeting at PTC HQ in Needham, MA on Wednesday, February 24th at 7PM. This first meeting will provide a great networking environment along with a range of content that I’m sure you’ll find worthwhile, I really look forward to meeting all who can attend! 


We have two guest speakers who will be presenting along with a discussion covering our featured topic on Mobile in CI. Our first speaker, Nan Bulger, the CEO & Executive Director of SCIP, will be sharing some insight on Best Practices related to CI & Mobility as well as some of the benefits of the SCIP community. Next, Derek Sugalski, Vice President of Competitive Intelligence at PTC, will provide some perspective on how PTC approaches strategy. 


Our goal is to enhance the success of our members by providing face-to-face networking opportunities & educational programs which promote competitive intelligence learning – this meeting will truly do that and I hope to see you there! 

Best wishes,

Kevin Cannon
Boston Chapter Chair
[masked]
@SCIPBostonKevin

results.description:
Ballroom Dance Basics Course
Learn the basics of social dancing.

Every 4 weeks we will learn a different dance.

Merengue – This easy to learn, fun & exciting Latin Rhythm is a real party dance.
Waltz – Elegant & Beautiful with slow gliding movements.
Foxtrot – Sophisticated & Jazzy. Think Frank Sinatra, Tony Bennett & Michael Buble
Tango – Passionate – Sharp and Dramatic
Swing – Energetic & Aerobic, Dance to Big Band era or popular music
Rumba – Romantic & Sensual
Salsa/Mambo – Sizzling, Sexy, Hot & Spicy

Learn the basic step elements, posture, poise, lead & follow, technique, etc.
results.name: Ballroom Basics: Learn the basics of social dancing.

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability, so you actually get your work done and turn your dreams into reality

• Ideas and inspiration to help you make something new or improve what you already have

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

These meetings tend to run between 1.5-2 hours.  Here's the way it works:

7:00pm Join the meeting here: https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea

First, new members introduce themselves, and existing members talk about what goals they hit and didn't hit in the past week.  This part usually takes about 15 minutes.  The remainder of our time is spent helping one of our members overcome any problems they may be facing by giving them a chance to sit on the "Couch of Insight!"  Long story short, with our dozens of years of experience and our huge diversity of current business projects, we give them brutal but constructive feedback on their plans and current projects, helping them get insights they could never get from their friends and family alone.

Anyone can join.  It doesn't matter where you are, how older you are, or even what stage of your business you're in.  Our regular members include everyone from total beginners who are just getting their feet wet all the way up to serial entrepreneurs who are already making six-figures or more in their spare time doing this stuff.
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.
results.name: Weekly Remote Mastermind Session

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapter 17: Indirect Exchange, of the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly reading and questions.

Please note the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. Our group meets in the private room at the back of the restaurant, the reservation is under Austrian Economics Group.

Please feel free to call Natalya @[masked], our Director of Events, with any questions.

READING: 

Part 4, Chapter 17: Indirect Exchange

QUESTIONS: 


1) What is indirect exchange, and what is referred to as media of exchange?


2) What is wrong with the equation of exchange?

3) Does objective use value influence prices?

4) What is the only function of money, and is money an economic good?

5) What is the problem of Hume and Mill?

6) What are goods-induced changes in purchasing power, and what are cash-induced changes in purchasing power?

7) What are the different stages of the inflationary process?

8) What are commodity and credit money?

9) In which cases does a surplus go abroad?

10) What is the purchasing-power-parity theory, and why does the mutual exchange ratio between various kinds of money tend to a final state?

11) Can the market rate of interest be permanently lowered by credit expansion?

12) Why will opportunities for earning profit for an entrepreneur appear in a world of falling prices as well as in one of rising prices?
results.name: INDIRECT EXCHANGE

results.description:
Now we begin our discussion of 2 Corinthians: "But thanks be to God, who in Christ always leads us in triumphal procession, and through us spreads the fragrance of the knowledge of him everywhere" (2:14).  

Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 and 2 Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 2 Corinthians!
results.how_to_find_us: We're meeting on the second floor in the Kuumba Library.  Enter the main entrance on Clarendon Street, take the spiral staircase to the right, and we're in the room to the right.  See you there!
results.name: Study 2 Corinthians

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
